channel.title: Partially Examined Life Citizen Feed
channel.description:
The Partially Examined Life is a philosophy podcast by some guys who were at one point set on doing philosophy for a living but then thought better of it. Each episode, we pick a text and chat about it with some balance between insight and flippancy. You don't have to know any philosophy, or even to have read the text we're talking about to (mostly) follow and (hopefully) enjoy the discussion.
Your Citizen feed from Patreon offers access to old episodes and part 2's and 3's that may not be available to the cheapskate public. Thanks for supporting PEL!

item.title: Ep. 381: Aquinas on Ethical Psychology (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
On selections about virtue and moral action from the Summa Theologica (1268) as collected by Timothy McDermott in Thomas Aquinas: Selected Philosophical Writings (1993).

What is the role of emotions in morality? Aquinas, following Aristotle, is well known for saying that reason is humanity's unique and primary virtue, but yet being reasonable is not just a matter of will but conditioning: education and practice, which involves not just the control of but the channeling of emotions, and all this is made possible by biological health.

These thinkers did not have our modern notion of psychology, of course, and approach the problem of virtue as a metaphysical one: Is virtue a disposition? Is it a disposition to be something, or to act in some way? Eventually Aquinas works up to a definition of virtue that he defends: virtues are good qualities of mind which dispose us to live rightly, which we cannot misuse, and which God works in us without our help. After defending each piece of this definition, he goes on to ask some technical questions about how virtue works within us. He concludes by asking what specifically virtue applies to: The intellect? The passions? The senses? The will? He distinguishes between those faculties which can actually display virtues (the intellect, the passions, the will) and ones which are merely preconditions for virtue (the senses, but also the rest of our biology; you can't be virtuous if you don't have a body).

His analysis of the will is particularly strange: He claims that for self-regarding virtues, we don't need the will. If we're conditioned to have self-control (virtuous passions) and to recognize the right thing (virtuous intellect), then we'll invariably just do that. But to love something bigger than ourselves, whether it be God or the human species, Aquinas claims that a virtuous will is required.

It's not essential to go back to our previous treatment of Aquinas before listening to this, but you might want to at least listen to ep. 378 part 4 on emotions . Our treatment of Aristotle's account of the various intellectual virtues was in our ep. 147 .

We bring up a bit of the moral action section to provide context for this but don't go into that in detail until part three of this discussion. The problem is how evil can really exist, given that God is good and only creates good things. The solution is that "evil" is really just something not coming into its full potential. We all aim to do what we perceive to be good, but if we don't perceive rightly or our will doesn't follow through, then we're falling short of being the rational, fully put-together human beings we could be.

Buy the reading , which was compiled by Timothy McDermott in 1993, or try it out online .

Image by Chris Warr (aka Solomon Grundy). Edited by Sonic Hustle .

item.title: Closereads: Hegel on Reason (Audio Part Four)
item.description:
We conclude our treatment (for now) of Hegel's Phenomenology , tackling the final two sections (238 and 239) of "The Certainty and Truth of Reason."

What is he actually talking about in these sections? According to Robert C. Solomon's In the Spirit of Hegel : "'Reason' refers to a sense of unity, between 'subject and object' in the jargon of the times, and this is the meaning that Hegel had learned from Kant and Schelling, in particular."

So Kant's separation of the Subject (the world of appearance) and Thing-In-Itself is something to be overcome: A separation of the thinkable from reality is unstable and unsatisfying, but it's not clear to us why this is the case. Wes thinks it's because appearances have to have their structure fed to them by reality: Even for Kant, things-in-themselves can't be truly divorced from appearances, because we have to have some data that we can process to create appearances. Mark thinks this is a probably true but irrelevant argument; that his objection to the intractable divide between subject and object is simply that this is not a way that we can live, and not how we treat the world of appearance.

So where Wes' argument would hold FOR Kantianism against a "pure" idealism that didn't include things-in-themselves, Hegel is arguing instead AGAINST Kantianism of any sort: There can't be mere Things-In-Themselves at all, even if as Kant says these are mysteriously related to appearances. This is similar to Hegel's argument in the previous section against skepticism, which also involves separation between appearances and an unknown reality, except that the skeptical self is sharply delineated as an isolated being in a strange world it can't know, whereas idealism defines the self as the creator of all appearances, the owner of all it beholds, which likewise leaves it adrift and unrooted. True, Kant's response does tie down appearances somehow, but in a very unsatisfying way by Hegel's lights; it still leaves one in a fundamentally skeptical position, floating rootlessly. (Fichte's idealism would also be dismissible on the same grounds: In distinguishing between the empirical (objective) and ethical (subjective) self, Fichte is creating an unnecessary, unbridgeable division.)

Read along with us , on p. 143 at the bottom, PDF p. 179.

item.title: Closereads: Hegel on Reason (Audio Part Three)
item.description:
Continuing on "The Certainty and Truth of Reason," now starting on sec. 236 in Hegel's Phenomenology of Spirit . Hegel has told us that there's something wrong with idealism as traditionally conceived, where the categories of being are all subdivisions of the "I." This leaves no room for fundamental "otherness," for the negative as a real part of the universe, which Hegel thinks is necessary for a fully adequate concept of Reason.

Remember that we're coming out of the previous section about development of the I through self-conscious apprehension of and by other people, so one of the dialectical oppositions here is the I as idealist ground for all existence and the I as an individual human being in a world with other humans. When it comes to the objective world explored by science, you and I provide different perspectives on these objects; we make them not just my solipsistic experience, but make them real, i.e. truly objective: things in opposition to any particular self. When it comes to mathematical and logical objects (e.g. the form of a syllogism), you and I are connecting to the same, seemingly unchanging realm of Reason a la Plato, though of course Hegel is going to ultimately see this experience as just a phase to be overcome, not as our connecting with and participating in the Divine. This section seems primarily focused on metaphysical objects: the Categories (substance, property, negation, number, etc.) and the Kantian Things-In-Themselves, which include the transcendental Ego (my Self as a metaphysical object). We don't see these things, so we don't have multiple perspectives on them as we do on ordinary objects; we think them, like the mathematical objects.

I'm not going to pretend we fully understand any of this, but we're trying!

Read along with us , on p. 143, PDF p. 179.

item.title: Ep. 380: Josiah Royce on Community (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
Continuing from part one on The Problem of Christianity (1913), talking about how communities refer to time-processes, both in the history of the development of that community (so a community can be much more ancient and wizened than an individual), and in the mythical history and looked-for future, such that the community, for instance, of Christians is defined by the death of Jesus (which, whether it really happened the way it was described or not, was certainly before Paul founded the church) and to a lesser degree by the end-times events described in the Biblical book of Revelation.

Whenever an American thinks "we fought the civil war," then that's an instance of community thinking, given that the current individual wasn't alive and so did not literally fight the civil war. Judaism is largely based on the idea of group historical experience. It's very different, then, when a group of Americans and/or Jews joins together to coordinate and celebrate some festival and when employees at a company work together to manufacture some product. In the latter case, there is likely not much shared identification of worker with company, though in some cases companies can foster this spirit so that workers feel they have a real stake and that their fortunes rise and fall with the company.

In the latter part of the reading, Royce praises the philosophy that he attributes to St. Paul (but which is very similar to Rousseau ) that contrasts the ability to cooperate in a community with the individualism that society instills in us. Primitive people without a lot of sense of self find it easy to blend into a community. Civilization makes us into individuals, makes us identify our own interests, cultivate our own unique personalities with our own needs and tastes, sharpens our individual wills, and puts us in competition with others for status and resources. Of course, it's better to be more developed in this way, but to get the benefits of community, we have to then get over ourselves. (This is similar to Ricoeur's account of a second naïveté .)

Royce want the Christian world community to be one not of sheep-like submen, but enlightened people that use their developed, individual talents and sensibilities to work toward the common goal of peace on earth and love among all people. Whether or not Paul actually preached this explicitly, Royce points to Paul as an exemplar of this. Paul also created the framework of interpretation that others could then understand and follow to form the community of the early church, though the believers were of course fixated on Jesus as their (physically absent) leader, not Paul. The paradox of the ideal community is that it doesn't exist yet, and certainly doesn't exist in its ideally loveable state, so how can one thoroughly love it already? For it to become this loveable community, you'd have to already have a bunch of loveable members (maybe everyone) loving each other. The leader therefore needs to be seen by the followers as having a great vision and a great love to get the ball rolling.

While this might seem to either doom the idea of such a community or at least marginalize it as only someone who already had faith in Christianity would countenance, on a smaller scale, it's a dynamic in starting any community: One can't participate in a community unless it pre-exists to join, yet since a community is by definition plural, a single founder can't just decide to have a community. So there is always some sort of initial faith in a leader by others, or perhaps something that is truly born cooperatively, but then at some point there's a schism such that one of the original leaders' vision wins out and other OGs leave the group (and maybe like Trotsky get killed)... something of the sort. Given the time period that this came out, which coincided with the birth of sociology (e.g. Durkheim), it may well be that a lot of what Royce is talking about here--group minds, the development of groups, individuals' devotion to groups--is not so strangely Hegelian but just a breed of early sociology.

Next episode : We return to Thomas Aquinas with a three-part discussion of his views of virtue and ethics: Passage 36 and the first 20 pages of Passage 35 in Oxford's Thomas Aquinas: Selected Philosophical Writings , compiled by Timothy McDermott in 1993.

item.title: Ep. 380: Josiah Royce on Community (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
On sections of The Problem of Christianity (1913) which establish Royce’s concept of a community of interpretation: individuals working together with a sense of shared history and expectation. He claims that such a grouping can be counted as a literal mind and that it solves the problem of human meaning. Which of our many social groupings and political affiliations share these uplifting characteristics? Mark, Wes, and Seth are joined for the beginning of the discussion by Westminster’s Kara Barnette , who selected our readings.

Royce’s thinking mixes pragmatism with Hegelianism, and we were particularly interested in comparing his idea of community with Hegel’s idea of “geist.” In both cases, a community is something that creates cultural products, and Royce uses customs, languages, and religions as examples of something that was not created by any one individual. Just as we know individual minds by their inputs and outputs, so we know group minds in this way. This is the one place we read where he’s showing his pragmatism… or perhaps behaviorism? Even in the individual case, we understand ourselves not through the momentary experience of consciousness (my current qualia), but based on a socially informed idea of our own history and character. Yes, I have a special relationship with myself (my inner life), but just about everything I can know or say about myself, you could also know or say about me. So it’s not entirely strange to say that we also know about our communities in this relatively externalist, socially and historically grounded way, even as we are part of them.

Royce points at psychologist Wilhelm Wundt whom he describes as comfortable applying psychological analyses to groups. A community will typically be smarter than any individual in it (having access to more total knowledge and skill), but can be as a whole smart or very slow (disorganized), good or evil, cheerful or filled with rage. Royce clearly seems the human telos (social animal) as aimed at joining in such collectivities that can make us feel part of something bigger that ourselves, though he contrasts authentic community with civic society that makes us compete with and resent each other.

So community becomes an ideal. We can see it embodied most clearly in, say, a musical ensemble or sports team, with everyone working together, each aware of the vital role that other members have in creating a sound that would be impossible for the individual alone. And far from these groups being tribal, aimed at hating opponents, Royce argues that this group loyalty naturally engenders a love of loyalty itself, so that you respect other musical groups or sports teams and see yourself as part of that larger music-or-sport-loving community. Ultimately, these authentic communities have within themselves a totalizing telos, so that you aim to see the whole world as united in a common endeavor.

This book is called The Problem of Christianity because he’s using this idea of an ideal community to describe what Christianity is aiming for: A universal community of believers united in love and fellowship. We didn’t actually read enough of the book to see how he develops this idea, but we got enough to learn that the goal is to create an ideally lovable community that everyone will thus love, but that loving something before it actually exists requires an act of faith, which he claims cannot be understood psychologically, so we have to invoke the concept of grace. He claims that no completely transformative experience, such as Saul of Tarsus turning into St. Paul, can be explained scientifically, because psychological explanations would look at pre-existing personality traits and how these develop deterministically, whereas love comes on like a whirlwind to sweep us up and make us into something new.

Putting aside the weirdness of this Christian ideal community that is supposedly the ultimate outgrowth implied by more basic forms of uniting in communities, how do we come to love and participate in an authentic community? Royce wrote a whole prior book called The Philosophy of Loyalty (1908) that he’s building on in what we read. For life to be meaningful, we need goals and projects that necessarily involve other people. Per Kierkegaard’s dismissal of the merely aesthetic life , we have a need for our actions to feel rooted in connection to others, and not just a few concrete others (your family), but a community that sets standards of responsibility and respectability and evaluates our behavior by them, such that you then conform to those standards like a stable adult instead of a whimsical child.

Read volumes one and two of the book online. We read sec. V and VI of "The Idea of the Universal Community," (p. 61-74) sec. I-VIII of "The Realm of Grace," (163-196) sec. IX-XII of "The Community and Time-Process" (volume 2, p. 35-53) and all of "The Body and its Members." (57-105).

Image by Chris Warr (aka Solomon Grundy). Edited by Sonic Hustle .

item.title: Closereads: Hegel on Reason (Audio Part Two)
item.description:
Continuing on "The Certainty and Truth of Reason" in Hegel's Phenomenology of Spirit . How can Hegel connect the discovery of self-consciousness with the development of Reason?

...By exploring Idealism: Per Fichte, realization of the self is realization of all of reality, because everything is in some sense part of your mind. Reason is how we can think about metaphysically real objects (prior to that point, we have perceptions and synthesize them into objects, but don't make the leap to assigning them a metaphysical status). Can one be an idealist and still allow for the objects of experience to be truly objective?

Read along with us , on PDF p. 176 near the bottom, partway through section 233.

Per my announcement at the beginning of this, there's no video for this episode. Also, I'd like to teach my Continental Philosophy class again and need to know who's interested, so please message me if you might be. The syllabus will be identical to what I taught in Fall 2004 .

item.title: Closereads: Hegel on Reason (Audio Part One)
item.description:
On Hegel's "Phenomenology of Spirit," Part C (AA) Reason, V. The Certainty and Truth of Reason. This section comes right after the self-consciousness sections, and so its big puzzle is why? Why is full recognition by another self-consciousness necessary for Reason, and consequently what is Hegel's conception of Reason?

Read along with us , on PDF p. 175, i.e. section 231.

Folks in the $10/month tier can experience this as ad-free video and will get additional coverage to this reading as it's released, along with all the other Closereads content.

item.title: Ep. 379: Egyptian Philosophy with Chike Jeffers (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
Continuing from part one on sources from ancient Egypt, finishing up the instructional literature: " "The Instruction of Ptahhotep," and "The Instruction Addressed to King Merikare," and then we move to the dialogues, ""The Eloquent Peasant," and "The Dispute Between a Man and His Ba."

A theme that runs through the instructions is humility and hence silence: the virtue of self-control. Despite class differences, wisdom might come form any corner, and if you're in a dispute with someone, you can probably stay quiet and let the opponent trip themselves up with their own folly. According to the ancient Egyptian metaphysics, people get what they deserve, so an opponent speaking evilly will invariably fail (in the long run at least).

"The Eloquent Peasant" is likewise an ethical exhortation, except in narrative form. A peasant (Khun-Anup) has been wronged and goes to complain to his magistrate, who is so tickled by the peasant's eloquence that before giving him back the property that was stolen from him, the magistrate makes the peasant continue to complain for several days and writes down these complaints to capture their literary merit. As with the instructions, Khun-Anup's ethical speeches urge the rulers to play straight, bemoaning that what is supposed to be the source of justice and straightness is instead itself a purveyor of crooked injustice. Does the eventual rectification of the initial wrong make the rulers just after all, or does their delay, which drives Khun-Anup to the point of considering suicide, compound the injustice?

Finally, we talk briefly about perhaps the most famous of these texts, "The Dispute Between a Man and His Ba," which is a man and his soul debating about whether suicide is morally permissible.

Near the end, Chike talks about another text, the Ipuwer . Hear Wes and Mark talk further about the Dispute Between a Man and His Ba .

Next episode, we're talking about select chapters within Josiah Royce's The Problem of Christianity : Look at volumes one and two online. We read sec. V and VI of "The Idea of the Universal Community," (p. 61-74) sec. I-VIII of "The Realm of Grace," (163-196) sec. IX-XII of "The Community and Time-Process" (volume 2, p. 35-53) and all of "The Body and its Members." (57-105).

item.title: Ep. 379: Egyptian Philosophy with Chike Jeffers (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
On some of the most famous surviving philosophical works from 2200-1400 BCE: "The Instruction of Ptahhotep," "The Instruction Addressed to King Merikare," "The Great Hymn to the Aten," "The Dispute Between a Man and His Ba," and "The Eloquent Peasant."

Mark, Wes, and Seth are joined by the co-author of the Africana portion of the History of Philosophy Without Any Gaps podcast (and a new book based on this). Chike also teaches at Dalhousie University in Nova Scotia.

Just as Socrates was responding to the Homeric ethics and the amorality of the gods as depicted in Greek mythology, in "The Great Hymn to the Aten" (our latest text, from the mid-14th century BCE) was an ethical reformer. He was a Pharoah (Nefrititi's husband, King Tut's father) who dictated that Egypt become monotheist, worshipping only the sun (Aten), and in this work he emphasizes not Egypt's superiority, but that all nations, with their various languages and skin colors, are alike under and nourished by the sun.

We discuss the concept of "maat" as it appears in these writings, which metaphorically uses the literal concept of straightness or evenness to characterize an ethical order the permeates the world. So in the instructional texts by royal vizier Ptahhotep to his king (possibly from around 2375-2350 BCE) and the subsequent one by Khety to his son Merikare (from the 21st or 22nd century BCE), we see lots of directives to deal in a forthright and just manner to everyone. These sort of kingly instructions are perhaps most familiar to Western philosophers through Machiavelli; though The Prince advises rulers to always appear virtuous but to ignore virtue when it's inconvenient, these texts present the kind of traditional view that Machiavelli was subverting. Still, they are not without moral nuance. For example, Ptahhotep advises that strong class divisions, i.e. a rich ruling class, will help ensure that government officials can't be bribed. Khety is particularly harsh on rooting out rebels.

In our second half, we'll talk about the narratives which at least one scholar also attributed to Khety: "The Eloquent Peasant," and "The Dispute Between a Man and His Ba." Mark and Wes take on the latter of these line-by-line in our latest Closereads episode .

We mainly used the translations from Miriam Lichtheim from volumes 1 and 2 of Ancient Egyptian Literature . Read volume 1 online , and volume 2 . We also looked at a bit of Maulana Karenga's Maat: The Moral Ideal in Ancient Egypt (2004), which you can preview online .

You can follow Chike's distinctions among the various historical stages in ancient Egypt with this handy History of Ancient Egypt page .

The relevant episodes in the History of Philosophy podcast are HAP 4-7 , and Chike's new book based on these with Peter Adamson is Africana Philosophy from Ancient Egypt to the Nineteenth Century .

Image by Charles Valsechi . Edited by Sonic Hustle .

item.title: Closereads: Dispute Between a Man and His Ba (Audio)
item.description:
In this famous, impossibly ancient (ca. 1900 BC!) Egyptian text, a man negotiations with the part of his soul that's supposed to help him in the afterlife. Can he kill himself now and still get all the benefits of an honorable death? His ba says no. Is this actually philosophy, or just a glimpse into the strangeness of a long-gone culture? You decide!

We discuss this and other works from ancient Egypt less thoroughly in Partially Examined Life ep. 379.

Read along with us .

item.title: Ep. 378: Aquinas on God and Mind (Part Four for Supporters)
item.description:
We’re completing our treatment for now of Thomas Aquinas: Selected Philosophical Writings , discussion sec. 15, “Feelings.” This recording features Mark, Wes, and Seth. Listen to at least part three first, also about the mind.

Passions are defined as passive (“passio” in Latin), and the puzzle again is how to fit the Aristotelian model of the soul (with its passive and active parts) with the Christian doctrine that says the soul is unchanging: It can’t undergo changes as any passive thing does.

The solution seems to be to say that while the soul is unchanging in its essential properties, it can have different incidental properties due to its connection to a body, which can of course be in different locations, can be alive or dead, and can undergo passions.

We then get a taxonomy of emotions, differentiating them by their being merely affective (feeling love, for instance) or aggressive (e.g. feeling bold), the latter of which means we don’t just feel something but take some action as part of the emotion toward the object, e.g. desire or boldness means we move through obstacles to obtain or fight something.

On another vector some emotions draw us toward an object (love), some away (hatred). Aquinas then asks if all emotions have an opposite, and concludes that most of them do, but anger is the exception due to Aristotle’s theory of anger (discussed in our ep. 144 ), which is aggressive, but yet doesn’t have any actual work to do, as the thing that makes you angry has already been done.

Aquinas’ story about how souls can be immortal (as mentioned near the beginning of this part) is given in our latest Closereads episode , which I suppose could be considered part five of ep. 378 if we were so perverse as to present it this way.

item.title: Closereads: Aquinas and Aristotle on Soul (Audio)
item.description:
From Disputed Questions in De Anima (1269) as presented in Thomas Aquinas: Selected Philosophical Writings (Oxford 1993), "Passage 18: Soul in Human Beings."

The question is how Aquinas, as an Aristotelian who therefore thinks the mind is the form of the body, can agree with the Christian doctrine that the soul exists after death. The answer is surprisingly weird: The body-less soul is incomplete, so we'd need to have the end-of-times full-bodily-resurrection of all the good people in order to have a truly satisfactory heaven.

Read along with us . The Aristotle chapter from "De Anima" (Part III, Ch. 5) is here , PDF p. 41.

There won't be a part two to this discussion, but to make sure you get all Closereads content, you'll need to be at our Patreon $10/month level or higher.

item.title: Ep. 378: Aquinas on God and Mind (Part Three for Supporters)
item.description:
We're now moving on to the "mind" portion of our discussion, starting with how reason motivates us and hence how free will is possible. This is sections 16, 17, and eventually 12 in Thomas Aquinas: Selected Philosophical Writings . Listen to parts one and two first.

As with the various causality-related arguments for the existence of God, we're wading into the complicated Aristotelian waters of causality that Aquinas is trying to interpret in a way compatible with Christian doctrine, which requires that we be free agents yet operating under God (who knows our actions in advance and is the ultimate cause of everything).

One might think that something is free if its causality comes primarily from within it. But Aristotle (unlike Plato) says that forms are within things, but if, e.g. a rabbit's DNA causes it to grow and behave in rabbit-like ways, it is still not acting freely, as the rabbit did not invent that form. This is unlike a person deciding to build a house, who may design the house, or even if he doesn't, he's deciding what actions go in what order to carry out the plan. So even if in some sense the person has to have the desire for the house to be built (the desire was implanted by culture, instinct, and/or God), even if the ways of building are restricted by various laws of physics and the person's own biology, the fact that there's flexibility in response means that the action counts as free.

Another way of putting this is that all human actions are motivated by some perceived good, but that doesn't mean that these desired goods determine our actions, because as creatures with understanding, we can see beyond the immediate good to the idea of good in general, and we can use this to change our strategy: to resist one good (the cake before me) in favor of some other (health). So this comes down to what's probably a familiar theory for anyone familiar with Aristotle's ethics: Despite our being part of a universal causal system, we can distinguish between simply blindly following an impulse (so eating the cake without reflection is not acting freely), and engaging in rational deliberation that can potentially wrench us from what would otherwise be a goal immediately given by desire.

But Aquinas is interested in bringing in Aristotelian metaphysics and philosophy of mind too, and so he has to describe how will fits into the mind, and how the mind itself is structured (with a passive and active part). Will itself has to be stimulated by something external, and none of us can escape the overall desire for happiness, but once it's been activated, we can consider it self-directing in choosing among options to achieve happiness.

Despite the free will section occurring earlier in this book than the introduction to mind, we covered that last here (and actually, our supporter-only part four will cover feelings). The question is whether the mind passive (like the passions). It is definitely something that has potential (e.g. the potential to think of something in particular) that is then repeatedly actualized (as we think of that thing), and this is on Aristotelian grounds exactly what it is to be passive. Yet for the account of free will to work there has to be an active part as well: an "agent mind" that is not merely affected as sense organs are, but which can choose, can cause things in the passive part of the mind, such as when you choose to look at (or imagine) one thing rather than another. Aquinas argues that while a sense organ can accept images, the agent mind is necessary to extract forms from them, e.g. to see a rabbit as a rabbit or to see the color green as being a member of a category of other green instances and shades.

Next episode: We'll talk about ancient Egyptian philosophy as discussed in episodes HAP 4-6 of The History of Philosophy Without Any Gaps podcast (i.e. the beginning of their Africana treatment) with the co-author of that effort, Chike Jeffers. The primary texts can all be found in Miriam Lichtheim's Ancient Egyptian Literature collection and include "The Instruction of Ptahhotep," "The Instruction of King Merikare," "Hymn to Aten," "The Eloquent Peasant," and "The Dispute Between a Man and His Ba."

item.title: Ep. 378: Aquinas on God and Mind (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
Continuing from part one on bits of Thomas Aquinas: Selected Philosophical Writings , completing our analysis of his arguments for the existence of God and then turning to eternity and the possibility of actually talking about God.

One theme that runs through all these is the incommensurability between empirical things (which Aquinas says are the things we actually know; he's surprisingly an empiricist) and divine things. So if we only see causality among physical things, how can we conclude that there is some first, infinite cause that is God? He answers that we don't have to understand from the physical evidence the nature of God, e.g. his infinity, but only that there has to be something that comes first. Maybe this wouldn't be enough by itself to establish God, but he couples this with arguments from necessity (if everything were merely contingent, i.e. might not be, that at some point there would have been nothing; so we need something that is necessary to ground all contingent things) and from design (the world looks designed, therefore someone must have designed it), etc., such that the combined implications of these arguments is that there's one unchangeable, necessary, self-causing designer, which we might as well call God.

Likewise for eternity: He insists that even though time is something that is cut up into moments, eternity is simple and whole (no parts), so counter-intuitively, eternity isn't just a name for "all time," but must itself be outside time. I claim that the only reason you'd have this weird idea about eternity being simple is because you're already committed to God being simple.

Our final question has to do with that simplicity. Christians want to say that God is good, exists, loves us, is all-powerful, all-knowing, etc., but if God is perfectly simple, necessary, and unchanging, then He has no contingent properties. His various qualities have to literally BE his essence. So when we finite beings try to pick Him out using these various attributes, we're engaging with a certain kind of illusion: Picking out God via his visible effects (e.g. the good things he created which point us to his being the source of all goodness). Not being infinite ourselves, we can't really know God in His essence; He's just too big compared to us. But nonetheless, Aquinas argues that we're not committed to being negative theologists a la Maimonides ; we can say He truly is good, exists, etc., though when we say He loves us or holds us in His loving arms, we're just engaged in metaphor.

In the third part of this discussion (featuring all four of us but recorded a couple of days later), we'll finish the metaphysical story here by bringing in the human mind and free will, and then you supporters will get a bonus recording where three of us finish up our assigned reading by dwelling on human emotions.

item.title: Ep. 378: Aquinas on God and Mind (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
On selections from Thomas Aquinas: Selected Philosophical Writings , mostly taken from the Summa Theologica (1268). Featuring Mark, Wes, Seth, and Dylan.

Given our flawed, finite human nature, how do we fit into the universe? In particular, how can we know and talk about things far beyond our experience such as God and eternity? Or maybe we just can't?

Aquinas is writing within a tradition where appeal to authority is paramount. Not that this substitutes for thinking, because authorities disagree. Each selection in our reading considers a different question and quotes authorities on both sides of the issue, always leading with the strongest argument he can find for the position he will ultimately be against.

We started out with Sec. 20 in our book, "There Exists a God," which first asks whether an argument for God is even necessary; perhaps it's self-evident? (Aquinas ultimately thinks not.) Second, is a proof available? (He says yes.) Finally, he gives the proofs themselves, which we had previously discussed in our ep. 43 (on J.L. Mackie).

This recording will have three public parts: We finish up God and eternity in part two, and then in part three talk about free will and mind. In the supporter-exclusive part four, we'll discuss Aquinas' view of feelings. At the beginning of this episode we talk about our plans to further discuss his views of ethics and law, but we've decided to push that to ep. 381 after Dylan's return from Europe.

Buy the reading , which was compiled by Timothy McDermott in 1993, or try it out online .

Image by Charles Valsechi . Edited by Sonic Hustle .

item.title: Closereads: Hobbes on Liberty (Audio)
item.description:
On Leviathan (1651), ch. 21, "On the Liberty of Subjects." Thomas Hobbes is known for defending absolute monarchy, so as you'd predict, he's not going to say we have a lot of "natural" liberties.

We do always have the right to self-defense, but that doesn't mean that the sovereign can't with complete justice command you executed (even if you're innocent). Yet Hobbes wants to say that even under a repressive regime we all have lots of liberty, in the sense of no one physically stopping us from doing what we will. And he wants to dismiss as unintelligible any other sense of liberty tied to non-physical obstacles, so this entirely rules out any debate about free will.

Read along with us : starting on p. 161 (PDF p. 197).

item.title: Closereads: Aristotle on Final Causes (Audio)
item.description:
On Aristotle's Physics , book 2, ch. 8 on "final causation," i.e. purposiveness as a natural explanation. Modern science doesn't much like this kind of explanation, but Aristotle found it essential, and here's his argument for it.

Read along with us .

item.title: Ep. 377: Emil Cioran's Pessimism (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
Continuing from part one on "Directions for Decomposition" from A Short History of Decay (1949). What is it that humans are inevitably trying to avoid that seems so bad to us? It's our existential separation from others, our essential, incommunicable solitude.

We further discuss why Cioran praises sloth and ennui. Most likely, post-WWII he was very skeptical of "great projects" that can slide into violence. Relatedly, we also talk about time and nostalgia; we have irrational desires for things to be different than they are that pull us out of time.

Finally, what is it to be a "traitor to existence," and is this good? He talks about The Buddha in this context: someone whose life was actually changed by something he saw (illness, old age, death) and who after rejecting desire and other worldly things ultimately rejected even salvation (escape from the cycle of rebirth) so can could come back and be a teacher.

Next episode: We're discussing Thomas Aquinas on our knowledge of God from the Summa Theologica as presented in  Oxford’s Thomas Aquinas: Selected Philosophical Writings , compiled by Timothy McDermott in 1993.

item.title: Ep. 377: Emil Cioran's Pessimism (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
On A Short History of Decay (1949), a pessimist/existentialist text from the most famous Romanian philosopher consisting of short, multi-paragraph, relatively independent sections. It’s aphoristic a la much of Nietzsche, but not of the one-liner variety. If you’re a fan of Nietzsche, Cioran (pronounced “cho-RAHN”) delivers similar scorching wit, but is harder to pin down in terms of what he’s actually recommending.

Like Camus and other existentialists, Cioran sees the human condition as a kind of fallenness: We inevitably avert our eyes from the human condition, scurrying into various socially suggested activities that distract us from the meaninglessness of our lives. But whereas the existentialists hold before us some sort of ideal of authenticity to be attained if we hold the line and avoid such distractions, Cioran claims that facing the truth about ourselves is simply unbearable. Life is suffering, and there is no point to doing anything.

The book is lengthy, and even the first essay, “Directions for Decomposition,” is 90 pages, which was too much for us, so our discussion is just based on the first 60 pages of that. There’s no apparent organization among the various sections within that, and we’re sure that we didn’t miss out on any grand conclusion from the end of the essay. But he does have a few themes that he keeps circling back to, and he turns his pessimistic world-view on a variety of topics for thought, including art, humor, God, salvation, time, nostalgia, mourning, death, disease, suicide, revolt, freedom, Buddhism, Daoism, and the role of the philosopher.

For Cioran, everything is vanity (see Ecclesiastes !), but we pretend it’s not. We cannot avoid hope. A thoroughgoing nihilist (or skeptic, as he often puts it) is a practical impossibility.

But if he doesn’t have positive recommendations for action, there are at least some actions he condemns more than others: Fanaticism is of course horrible (he was writing in light of the recent Nazi experience), and he claims that any kind of faith puts one on the road to fanaticism. So by contrast, he praises sloth.

Solitude at least keeps one free of some of the distractions to contemplating your own nature, while speech is a sure way to falsify that nature by trying to change the ineffable into something flat and public. (Philosophers do this!) He claims that artists at least are not living a total lie, as they try to express that ineffable without destroying it. He values individuality, and actually praises disease as something that makes us hyper-focused on ourselves: Suffering disease is an “occupation” which does not distract from the awful truths of life, but instead which is a direct experience of those truths. But this is of course hardly a fate that anyone could wish on themselves.

Cioran’s “recommendations” tend to be merely the less worse of bad options, and more often he just comments on these options without telling us which is to be pursued; no doubt he sees this as up to one’s individual taste, and he says that no one is really in a position to judge others (though of course we constantly do). For example, being an artist seems a good way to cope, but Cioran describes it as a valve by which artists keep the human condition from building up. By contrast, someone without artistic talent can become in some way a greater person, with more force of will, ready to explode in a fantastically tragic fashion. We would invariably choose the first of these options, but there is something admirable (or at least impressive) about the second.

Rather than put forth an attainable ideal, Cioran occasionally talks about how we “could dream of” some better way to be. In this sense he sounds like a Beauvoir’s definition of a nihilist: A disappointed idealist. He remembers some sort of ideals he used to have, and he talks about not being able to dispel Hope from consciousness, but these will clearly not be achieved. One might hope to be a thoroughgoing skeptic or cynic, or someone able to be satisfied just gazing honestly into the void (so some kind of Buddhist sage), but these are at least not goals he seriously thinks he can achieve.

Buy the book or try this online version .

Image by Chris Warr .

item.title: Closereads: Horkheimer and Adorno on Enlightenment (Audio Part Three)
item.description:
We complete our treatment of "The Dialectic of Enlightenment," continuing for a while their comparison of the progress of science through the Enlightenment with the progress of mythology through the ancient world.

Then, impatient with this analogy, we jump to the final paragraph of the essay to learn that yes, the point of this is that we moderns thought ourselves liberated but have instead become enslaved by technological/economic destiny.

item.description:
Continuing on "The Dialectic of Enlightenment," hearing more about their critique of the enlightenment as not fulfilling its own requirements and ultimately dehumanizing us.

item.title: Ep. 376: Plato’s “Laws” (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
Continuing from part one on selections from this late Platonic dialogue. Starting in Book 4, Plato's characters are discussing how to create a new state ("Magnesia") from scratch. What sorts of laws should it have?

We discuss the marriage laws and whether Plato's presentation of this topic actually fulfills his requirement that laws have a rationally argued prelude for the law.

Plato also argues that there should be a law about believing in the gods, so that you'll then be law-abiding. (This interestingly seems to conflict with his argument in Euthyphro that ethics does not rely on religion.) He gives an argument for the existence of gods that he thinks everyone can accept in saying that mind (form) must always precede matter. Soul (psyche) is just defined as that which has motion in itself, and clearly, Plato argues, there must be such a self-moving motion before the passive things that only move when pushed. So it's a variation off of the cosmological argument (there must be a first mover), but has intervening steps.

We also talk about Plato's ruling body ("the nocturnal council"), why varying virtues are all actually virtue, punishments, and more.

Next Episode: We're talking about the beginning of Emil Cioran's A Brief History of Decay (1947).

item.title: Ep. 376: Plato’s “Laws” (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
Everybody reads Plato’s Republic , but is that dialogue really a political philosophy text (like the ideal type of government proposed there is what he really thinks we should and perhaps can have), or is he just using the political to illustrate something about the personal virtue of justice, as Socrates explicitly says in the dialogue?

Well, in this later (and longer, and much less popular) dialogue (from 347 BCE at the latest), we get a pretty straightforward question of what the purpose of government is, what a real-world government’s laws should look like, and how they should be established and adjusted as time goes on.

These doctrines do not come from the mouth of Socrates, but from an unnamed Athenian (some commentators claim it’s supposed to be Plato himself) on a long walk (mirroring the supposed walk that the Cretan founder Minos took to Zeus’ temple; supposedly Zeus helped him come up with the laws for the state) with a Cretan and a Spartan. While these other fellows start with the claim that the main purpose of a state is to make its citizenry fit to defend the country in case of war, the Athenian claims that it is to make its citizens virtuous, which is the same as thriving (eudaimonia). So they are not to be controlled, e.g. with a Noble Lie a la The Republic , but each law will in fact come with a persuasive prelude explaining why the law is necessary, and all citizens (not just an elite class of guardians) should be educated to be able to understand and obey reasonable laws.

While training people to resist fear (making them good soldiers) is part of being virtuous, they should also be trained on how to resist pleasure, and one can do this by exposing them to this through parties, letting people see if they can drink, but not to excess, and not to then do regrettable things. Like The Republic , there’s a lot in here about education, which should teach a perfect citizen how to rule and be ruled with justice. As with The Republic , part of this involves allowing poets to only teach moral lessons.

Though a real state can have no measures as radical as pulling children from parents into a general pool, Plato’s recommendations might look to us as quite totalitarian: All citizens are required to believe in the gods (again, he thinks they can reasonably be convinced of this, but if they can’t out they go), there doesn’t seem to be any limits about how much the laws can involve themselves with family life and employment, and punishments can be very harsh (for the “irredeemable,” Plato judges that death would be better for them than living no virtue). A good state won’t have its citizens covering in fear of the government, though, because the educational system would be all geared toward training good citizens. Punishments would be rare, and always designed to further improve people. Also, the Greek term for law (Nomos), refers to social conventions too. And of course we have customs about family and personal life.

A key analogy in the text that makes this less authoritarian is the difference between a slave doctor and a free doctor. A slave doctor (one who treats slaves, and is probably himself a slave… a more modern image might be a veterinarian) just delivers the treatment with no explanation, according to habit and training. A free doctor on Plato’s description understands the science of why a treatment works, and explains this to his free patients, who can agree or not to undergo the recommended treatments. So the latter is ideally what the relation between the rulers and the citizens are: The laws are rationally created to maximize flourishing, and these are explained to citizens who want to flourish and who have been educated to be able to understand the good arguments why they should cause flourishing. Finally, Plato recommends a “nocturnal council” that combines wise elders with young people who are gauging conditions on the ground, so if there are laws that aren’t in fact functioning to bring about flourishing, then this group can change such laws.

Read the 1979 Thomas Pangle translation that we read . Here are the parts we selected:

  1. I. 624a–632d — Opening walk & the “wine-test”

  2. Plus 643b-645c — Education, puppet string analogy

  3. II. 652a-63c, 660e — More education

  4. IV. 716c–724b — Preludes to laws (persuasion vs. compulsion)

  5. V. 727a–734e — The end of law is virtue

  6. IX. 853a–859d, 860d–864e — Crime, intention, and punishment

  7. X. 886a–897b — The theology of law

  8. XII. 961b–969d — The Nocturnal Council

We also recommend the Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy entr y on the text.

Image by Charles Valsechi . Edited by Sonic Hustle .

item.title: PEL Back-to-School Nightcap 2025
item.description:
Recorded 9/7/25, featuring Mark, Seth, and Dylan. We re-litigate the utility of Irigaray's feminist insights and relate this to the overall contrast between political and philosophical argumentation: One can approve of the political upshot of an argument without finding it philosophically interesting.

If one is ready to grant entirely the practical point that women should be encouraged and accepted as philosophical writers (and main figures in popular narratives, political leaders, etc.), and that in general a greater diversity of voices will yield a greater diversity of philosophical visions (which is good), is the rest of Irigaray merely an interesting literary exercise, or is there some real meat there that will change the way you think about metaphysics, epistemology, etc.?

Second, Dylan and Seth say more about Steven Pinker in light of his near absence in the Lincoln et al. episode despite the fact that he was on the reading list. We are right now reading Emil Cioran, who will provide some pessimism to answer Pinker's optimism. This leads of course to some discussion (and a fiery rant by Dylan) about current politics.

Here's the Freakonomics interview with Deneen that Seth mentions .

item.title: Closereads: Hegel on Stoicism (Audio Part Two)
item.description:
On The Phenomenology of Spirit , section 198-201 in the section, "Stoicism, Scepticism, and the Unhappy Consciousness." We finally get to talking about Stoicism and not just about attaining a thick self, but Stoicism is not described in a way that Stoics would be very happy with: It's just a deficient moment in thinking about what your self is: It's something that's fundamentally unmoored from your world such that no values (or ultimately facts, though that's going to be the main issue in the next section on Skepticism) impinge on you.

Per actual Stoic doctrine, "bad" things might seem to happen out in the world, but they're not really bad for you unless you decide that they are. This is not to say that values are subjective/relative, because a Stoic will say that there is a thing called objective virtue that they are pursuing (which involves asserting this freedom from your environment), but insofar as there are alleged values of things outside of your own will, then these things are not really values at all; they have nothing to do with you (Epictetus).

Hegel's position can be seen as a flavor of Wittgenstein's private language argument (e.g. see Koorsgard bringing this to bear in our recent discussions of her ethics): Values involve something fundamentally public, something that implicates your engagement in a cooperative project of evaluation with other people. Hegel will go on to describe ethics as a "geist" (translation: spirit): as a cultural phenomenon, not primarily and individual one. Pretending that other people's judgments simply "have nothing to do with you" is just delusion, though it is a dialectical advance over having your entire self determined by someone else's judgments (as the slave's is by the master's).

Follow along with us .

item.title: Ep. 375: Luce Irigaray’s Feminism (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
On "Women on the Market" from The Sex Which Is Not One (1977) and other selections, continuing with guest Jenny Hansen from part one .

"Women on the Market" is a study and application of Marx's theory of commodities from the first chapter of Das Kapital . Just as for Marx, a commodity's value is abstracted from how useful it is to a market value, for Irigaray, a woman's intrinsic worth is ignored in favor of men's valuation of them. They are literally converted to a product that men will find attractive, and the trading off women between families as daughters are married off is the unacknowledged foundation of male society. She calls this relation of man to man through the mediation of women-as-commodities "hom(m)o-sexuality," in that "homme" is French for "man," and this is a strictly man-man relationship with women there only as objects to be traded.

It's difficult again to know how literally to take this, or even how well the metaphor with Marx works. For Marx, there's something natural about use value (how useful is this coat?) that is lost when we move to market value, which Marx sees as representing a social standard of average labor that went into the thing. So if you make coats slowly, that doesn't make your coat more valuable, and if your coat is more comfortable than another's, it's still more valuable only insofar as this can translate to market value (there are lots of reasons why some cheaper commodity might actually be better, at least for your individual purposes). For women, there's no comparable "man's labor" that goes into converting the women, such that the value of the woman is ultimately attributable to that labor. In fact, it's the natural "use-value" of women that should be at issue in treating women like objects for sex and reproduction. And while certainly the incest taboo requires that women (and men) not marry within the family, the frequency of "trading women" between clans as being foundational for politics, as with rich and/or royal families you've seen on TV, is pretty low among couplings overall, and such practices as getting the father's permission, dowries, etc. have been clearly on the decline for a long time. Jenny brings up trophy wives and Jeffrey Epstein to make this modern.

We eventually connect this to our final reading selection, "Body Against Body: In Relation to the Mother" (1993), which sets some limit to the trading of women, in that mothers are sacrosanct; we don't trade them and we don't treat them as sexual. In fact, Irigaray claims that Western intellectualism is profoundly uncomfortable with motherly sexuality because we want to deny our biological origins and just see ourselves as rational beings. In clinging to rationality, men project the irrational onto women, which then leads to misogyny and alienation of all concerned. Man's public life is hom(m)o-sexual and rational, whereas our fears and discomfort are relegated to hearth and home as represented by and embodied in women.

We also talk a bit about the most positive of these essays, which is an excerpt from An Ethics of Sexual Difference (1984), where she describes the role of wonder as an alternative to mechanistic objectification. We should regard our partners as fundamentally mysterious (wonderful) rather than predictable and hence boring. The essay still gets very flowery and metaphysical; we briefly discuss her comments on angels as stand-ins for that relationship between human and divine which we should get out of sex but don't.

In the remaining essay, "Sexes and Genealogies: Each Sex Must Have Its Own Rights" (1993), there's an analysis of Hegel's Phenomenology about the family as the foundation of society, and how (per Antigone , which the Phenomenology discusses in this context) woman as representative of home values (family as opposed to society) gets shafted.

The book Jenny recommends at the end is Genevieve Lloyd's The Man of Reason: Male and Female in Western Philosophy (1984).

Next episode: We're reading Plato's dialogue The Laws , specifically the Thomas Pangle translation (1980): Books 1 (624a-632d, 643d-645c), 2 (652a-653c, 660e), 4 (716c-724b), 5 (727a-734e), 9 (853a-859d, 86d-864e), 10 (886a-897b), and 12 (961b-969d).

item.title: Ep. 375: Luce Irigaray’s Feminism (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
On selections (1977-1993) by Irigaray as presented in the French Feminism Reader (2000), ed. Kelly Oliver. Returning guest Jenny Hansen joins Mark, Seth, and Dylan to discuss the introduction she wrote in this book, plus parts of Irigaray’s The Sex Which Is Not One (1977) and to a lesser degree An Ethics of Sexual Difference (1984), “Sexes and Genealogies: Each Sex Must Have Its Own Rights” (1993), and “Body Against Body: In Relation to the Mother” (1993).

What role should sexual difference play in philosophy and society? Irigaray is a “second-wave” feminist: First-wave ones just stress that we should treat women equally; third-wave ones (e.g. Judith Butler) think we should radically rethink or even discard notions of gender. Second-wave feminists instead stress sexual difference, in that justice demands that we do treat women differently because they have different needs than men: For instance, job structures need to take pregnancy into account.

Irigaray is more concerned with the intellectual and emotional contributions that she claims femininity can specifically make. Since nearly all historical philosophy was constructed by men, it incorporates a male point of view that has in effect “de-subjectivized” women: Women are never the thinkers, never the first-person point of view doing the phenomenological evaluation of experience. So when they are able to do philosophy, they have to articulate themselves by aping the male philosophers, expressing themselves through conceptual tools that are foreign to their femininity. Irigaray was trained in psychoanalysis and is making use of Jacques Lacan’s distinction between language as the “name of the father” and “the real,” which is all that slips between the cracks of our conceptual distinctions. What would be uniquely feminine in its expression is inexpressible in male-constructed language, so it’s up to creative women to innovate artistically to devise new forms of expression.

How does one use language to transcend language? Well, you can use the male language in a mocking, deconstructive way. So she plays with the format of delivering philosophy in a manner reminiscent of Nietzsche’s irreverence. Unlike Christine Korsgaard, who (per the method of analytic philosophy) tries to lay out her arguments as clearly as possible, Irigaray often tries to jar us out of traditional ways of thinking through purposefully inflammatory language. However, she shifts her style to meet the purpose of the moment, and she just as often is soliciting male cooperation: Won’t love and sex be better, fellas, if you treat your lady as a full subject with a point of view, and not as just an object to reflect back on yourself?

In our very first feminism episode (from 2011), Carol Gilligan explained how a feminine point of view can improve our notions: Away from seeing impartiality (per Kant and utilitarianism) as the goal and towards and ethics of care (see our recent episodes on sympathy/empathy). More recently, we discussed Donna Haraway’s feminist philosophy of science , where she questioned the notion of scientific objectivity and the overall “master mentality,” i.e. the controlling character of science, which she thought influenced what we consider legitimate scientific questions, methods, and goals.

Irigaray’s most concrete contribution to this strain is in the final selection, where she argues to a group of psychoanalysts that Freud’s models of development do not do justice to women’s experiences and wrongly point us away from investigation of our uncomfortable relationship to our biological (i.e. maternal) origins. Though Irigaray also tells us (e.g. in the first essay) that the feminine can cause us to completely redefine the project of philosophy, she is here more inspirational/aspirational than demonstrative. It is unclear what a new ground a specifically feminine perspective can open up that was unavailable to male innovators like Nietzsche, Lacan, Derrida, Foucault, Whitehead, Buddhist and Daoist thinkers, etc. Toward the end of this first part of our discussion, we do get into her cheeky metaphor that male-dominated philosophy uses a mirror to reflect on itself (i.e. not challenge fundamental historical assumptions), whereas feminists can add the speculum, which as curved doesn’t just reflect back the investigator but allows a survey of the surrounding (cultural, introspective, biological) environment.

This is related to a criticism often aimed at second-wave feminists re. essentialism: It was the point of first-wave feminism that the entire vista of human experience is open to everyone equally. It’s not just men who think they can connect with those of foreign dispositions through literature, art, conversation, and imagination, but this is in fact open to anyone: Women are not “aping” male philosophers any more than male philosophers are simply imitating each other. The distance between any two human beings is greater than the distance between “male” and “female,” and so one should be equally pessimistic about men understanding other men or women understanding other women than the sexes understanding each other. It’s not that women are from Venus and men are from Mars; we are all from our own individual planets, or alternatively, we’re all from the same planet facing the same basic, human challenges even while in unique circumstances. This is also why third-wave feminists might want to simply get rid of the notion of gender; this bifurcation simply can’t do justice to the diversity among us, even in the area of sexually-related self-expression.

Still, there are certainly ways to argue for the unique experiences and needs common to many women having been unfairly marginalized by the male-dominated intellectual cultures of the past, such that women should feel fully empowered to do innovative, creative work even when their instincts fly in the face of institutional norms, and Irigaray is a skillful rhetorician in this area. In addition to taking straightforwardly political lessons from works like this (e.g. don’t assume by default that a philosopher or just about any other role is a man), we should certainly question whether metaphysical and methodological assumptions we make in philosophy and social sciences have been covertly conditioned by gender norms (she mentions our traditional work-week and patterns of endeavor more generally as being shaped according to male libidinal patterns of tension and release in particular, a reference that I found frankly baffling), just as we should question whether these have been conditioned by our economic status (per Marx), religious assumptions (per Nietzsche), by our unconscious desires (per Freud), or other aspects of our cultural and psychological situation.

Read the text for yourself , or Buy the French Feminism Reader that contains it.

Image by Charles Valsechi . Edited by Sonic Hustle .

item.title: Closereads: Hegel on Stoicism (Audio Part One)
item.description:
Discussing the section on Stoicism in Hegel's "Phenomenology of Spirit," which is under "Freedom of Self-Consciousness," "Stoicism, Scepticism, and the Unhappy Consciousness."

This comes right after his famous lordship and bondage chapter, and explains how in reaction to being defined by the gaze of another person, we assert our independence, but in an immature and ultimately unsustainable way. So this is not a very charitable take on Stoicism; he's just focusing on this assertion of freedom that's at the heart of the philosophy, and you can think yourself about the degree to which this pollutes more thoughtful, developed versions.

Follow along with us .

item.title: Ep. 374: Discussing Liberalism (Lincoln, et al) with Walter Sterling (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
Continuing on the dangers to liberal democracy, including consideration of Patrick Deneen, Francis Fukuyama, and Steven Pinker.

Continuing from part one our discussion of the dangers to and weak points of liberal democracy, including consideration of Patrick Deneen’s Why Liberalism Failed (2018) and Francis Fukuyama’s “Liberalism and Its Discontents” (his 2020 essay ). We also read part of Steven Pinker’s Enlightenment Now (2018).

Is liberal democracy founded on people's virtue (as Lincoln stated), or must any effective government assume people's lack of virtue and guard against/channel that? Deneen argues that we need to return to "pre-liberal" focus on virtue, that liberal democracy loosens social bonds. He would prefer a society that unabashedly advocates a particular model of virtue over a Rawlsian "do what ever you want" ethos that undermines virtue.

Fukuyama's paper follows up on this by calling our attention (as he did when we spoke with him)to thymos, i.e. the spirited part of the soul that demands recognition of status and plays a key role in identity politics. This is a threat to liberal democracy, which in its Rawlsian form demands that the government be neutral with regard to favoring the values (and hence status) of particular groups (e.g. Christian nationalists, but also oppressed identity groups). Still, Fukuyama thinks that liberal democracy is the best system available, so he is not making a case against it as Deneen does.

We don't spend much time on Pinker, who claims that liberalism has achieved great progress, and there's no real problem with it. Seth accuses him here of being blind to history, which invariably involves regressions from the kind of progress Pinker proudly points out for us.

Next episode: We're reading Ch. 7 of the French Feminism Reader (2000, ed. Kelly Oliver) presenting selections from Luce Irigaray. Buy the book or check out the chapter online .

item.title: Ep. 374: Discussing Liberalism (Lincoln, et al) with Walter Sterling (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
What’s the crisis of liberal democracy? Dylan, Wes and Seth are joined by new St. John’s College President J. Walter Sterling to discuss Abraham Lincoln’s “On the Perpetuation of Our Political Institutions ” (1838) plus the beginnings of Steven Pinker’s Enlightenment Now (2018), Patrick Deneen’s Why Liberalism Failed (2018), and Francis Fukuyama’s “Liberalism and Its Discontents” (his 2020 essay , not his 2022 book by that name).

Our inclusion of Lincoln demonstrates that this debate over the fundamental adequacy of our form of government to meet our needs is not new; there are always social forces working against the idea that openness and participation will produce just political outcomes. (This was of course why Plato, Aristotle, and many other figures of the past were against democracy; why would one expect the majority to know and support what is best for a whole political community?) Lincoln warns against “mobocracy” demonstrated in lynchings, which were of course against the law.

Is a form of government that affords maximum freedom the most durable? We need to revere freedom, to be dedicated to protecting liberty, and what ensures that this reverence will be passed on to the next generation? Foreign influence and internal government corruption can undermine this ideal. Lincoln is worried about human nature too: envy and ambition can overwhelm principle. When the nation was being founded, all of our hatred could be pointed at the British, but in a time of peace, we are liable to turn on each other. How do we react when we think some of our laws are bad? Not everyone has faith in the democratic process (and the inevitability of moral progress more generally) to eventually lead to the outcomes that they consider just, so there will be political pressure to overleap our ineffective institutions and have a strongman fix everything or otherwise overthrow the current system. Lincoln argued that reason (imparted via a liberal education) and respect for the rule of law provide guardrails against all these dangers to the system.

Paradoxically, respect for law and reverence for freedom are not optional, freely chosen values in a stable state: Through education, we need to impress these values on children before their critical faculties have developed enough to freely accept these values. For adults, it’s important for freedom that people be allowed to advocate the abandonment of freedom, but we can’t let such views win out.

The response (represented here by Patrick Deneen, though similar things have been argued by Nietzsche, Leo Strauss, Michael Sandel, and others, claims that pure liberalism is against human nature, which is more communitarian than individualistic, and so was bound to fail. People do not want a fragmented society where people just do what they like; they want a society to support their values. They want to be empowered: to be free in the positive sense of able to live in an environment and lifestyle of their collective choosing, typically in accordance with custom, religion, etc., but this could also be in accordance with the best science. The positive way of putting this is that true freedom is life in accordance with virtue, which is different than freedom from cultural norms.

Read Lincoln’s speech online . If you enjoy this, see our past episodes interviewing Fukuyama and Michael Sandel .

Image by Chris Warr .

item.title: Closereads: Peter Railton's "Moral Realism" (Audio Wrap Up)
item.description:
We are concluding our treatment of Peter Railton's "Moral Realism" (1984), and given that you likely haven't listened to the seven preceding parts, or (like us) you've forgotten things from them, this discussion can serve as a standalone summary of not only Railton's view, but of our efforts to actually figure out what a plausible naturalistic, empirical account of ethics could amount to.

The first part of the paper is concerned with setting up the idea that individuals have objective interests, and that we can know something about these by imagining what we as individuals would choose if we had all the relevant information about ourselves and our situation. Because you with knowledge of physiology and the poisonous quality of various drinks would not choose to drink what is in fact poisonous, this shows that it is in your objective interest right now to not drink that poison, even if you don't know that it's poison and you really really desire it.

He then shifts to comparably saying that for societies, there is likewise such a thing as health, such that, for example, slavery is unhealthy and unstable: A society whose leaders knew all the relevant details about long-term stability would not choose a body politic with such an unhealthy characteristic.

So the question is, can he bring these two accounts together such that the wise, all-knowing version of you as an individual would choose not only what is in your individual objective self-interest, but you would also choose what would make you a good citizen of a healthy community. For the result to be full-on ethics, this would have to generalize not only to identification of your interest with that of your social group, but with all of humanity, and really all of creation (to allow for environmental responsibilities, for example). While Railton does not argue very much explicitly for this leap (he merely points out the intuitive plausibility that a mature person would so identify), we talk through how Hume, Kant, and Korsgaard handled this question, and whether their insights can complete Railton's account.

Read along with us , starting on PDF p. 42.

Watch the video , if you'd prefer.
