item.title: Ep. 373: Michael Walzer on Just Wars (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
Continuing from part one on Just and Unjust Wars (1977), ch. 5-6.

Ch. 5, "Anticipations" discusses times when it might be morally permissible to strike first, even when no immanent incoming attack is anticipated. These cases will be rare, and depending on what counts as a credible ongoing threat. If war is inevitable, and not attacking first would result in disaster, then this is permissible. He gives the example of Israel's 1967 six-day war, where on his analysis Egypt had gathered its forces on the border and engaged in economic embargo, which over time would have been untenable for Israel, so they were justified in firing the first shots. Incidentally, Walzer is on record in arguing that Russia's invasion was on the contrary obviously unjust; the abstract threat of Ukraine's potentially joining NATO and so destabilizing the balance of power in the region in favor of the West is exactly the kind of 18th century reasoning he is arguing against in this book.

Putin also claims to be invading in order to save Russians in parts of Ukraine from being mistreated, and Walzer does allow for interventions on humanitarian grounds, but again, the reasoning for this sort of interference has to be iron-clad, e.g. an obvious genocide a la Rwanda (and incidentally, Walzer has argued as of November 2024 that Israel is not committing genocide , though I don't know what is view is of the current situation), and Russia's claims of this sort do not hold water.

There are several issues here that Walzer addresses in Ch. 6 on Interventions: First, within a country, even if there is repressive leadership, other countries are not justified in invading for the purpose of "liberating" the country (the reasoning comes originally from Mill): Nations have to navigate their own way toward freedom in order to be in a state where it will persist. This explains why Afghanistan did not stay free after America's departure. Russia's thinking that Ukraine's government is corrupt is not by itself a reason for invasion.

Likewise, if a nation is engaged in civil war, other nations ought to stay out of it, except insofar as some other nation has already entered on one side; in this case, nations might get involved to counter the foreign influence. This could obviously escalate, and so is something to be cautious about, but is not in itself unjust.

But what counts as "a nation?" Territorial disputes often revolve around some region between nations, and Putin claims that some parts of Ukraine are ethnically Russian and should be part of Russia. For Walzer, this could not be something that Russia could unilaterally decide, but should be a matter of the self-determination of the population of the areas at issue. Still, even if such an area should want to secede (whether to become independent or join another state) and start a civil war over it, Walzer advises that other nations stay out of it.

Relatedly, it's also very hard for outsiders to get accurate information about what's going on in a region, what the populace actually thinks, and this is a good reason for staying out of it as a general rule.

Remember, though, that all this discussion is only about when it is justified to go to war, and not about what counts as just conduct within war (which is covered by the second half of the book, which we did not read). So the question of whether Israel is justified in defending itself is separate from whether its methods of war are ethical. (Clearly Hamas' methods of protecting its fighters by embedding them in civilian populations and seeking to prevent any aid from reaching its people that does not come from Hamas is unethical on Walzer's grounds, but so is any action by Israel that does not seek to minimize civilian casualties.)

Differences in people's assessment about the facts here frustrate our ability to straightforwardly apply philosophical theory to practice. Walzer can argue that in such and such circumstances, war is justified or not, but even in presenting his historical examples (he spends a lot of time talking about our unjust intervention in Vietnam), he understands that different historians and other observers may have different characterizations of events, such that he encourages readers to just consider them as hypothetical situations: If country X acted in such-and-such ways, that would be unjust. But has Russia, or Israel, or the United States, in fact acted in these ways? Walzer clearly has his opinions and thinks these to be justified, but we should not let differences about facts distort our widespread, basic agreement (Walzer claims) about the moral principles involved.

Next episode: Walter Sterling, the new president of St. John's College, will join us to talk about liberty via Abraham Lincoln's 1838 speech "On the Perpetuation of Our Political Institutions," plus bits from Steven Pinker (Enlightenment Now ), Patrick Deneen (Why Liberalism Failed ), and Francis Fukuyama (Liberalism and Its Discontents ).

item.title: Ep. 373: Michael Walzer on Just Wars (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
On Just and Unjust Wars: A Moral Argument With Illustrations (1977, updated in 2006), ch. 4-6 on "jus ad bellum," which refers to moral justifications for going to war, as opposed to "jus in bello," which refers to how war is conducted. Featuring Mark, Wes, Dylan, and Seth.

The short answer is that self-defense is OK, while aggression is not. But of course, this can be difficult to discern in real circumstances: Is Israel just defending itself, or is it going beyond that to aggressively take land? Many aggressors use past wrongs as justification, but Walzer says that is not relevant: Even if Israel or the U.S. or whoever stole its land in the first place, a population living in a place has a right to self-determination, to have its borders respected, even if these borders were formed in an arbitrary way.

This idea compares nations to individuals, acknowledging that an individual who is attacked can just call the police, but for nations, they have to be their own policemen and/or convince others to defend their rights. Walzer claims that nations have rights based on the rights of the individuals within them. This is against a position Walzer calls "realism" (e.g. Hobbes), which says that because there is no international government, then there really are no laws or even moral facts about the behavior of states toward each other. In the 18th century, Walzer says that leaders like Otto von Bismarck saw war as just a political prerogative, and that the natural condition of nations is for larger ones to take over smaller ones: Only the "balance of power" can keep nations from being aggressive, and when aggression succeeds, the victor writes the history and (legitimately) claims the action to have been just.

Walzer argues that this is nonsense, that of course we can and do judge the behavior of nations. He describes the "legalistic framework" that argues strictly that aggression is never permissible, and no nation should interfere in another's internal affairs. However, Walzer's own view is that there are acceptable exceptions: For example, if a nation is committing genocide against part of its own population, for example, other nations can and should intervene.

So nations can defend themselves, but must they? Do other nations have a duty to intervene when they witness aggression? Walzer says that no, the decision to fight is always up to the population in question, and there might be practical reasons not to resist or intervene, but it would always be morally good if someone did stand up to the aggressor, and appeasement to aggression, even if it saves lives, sacrifices goods that are worth being fought for.

Buy the book or try this online version . Read "The Four Wars of Israel/Palestine ."

If you enjoy this, check out our discussion in ep. 72 of terrorism .

Image by Charles Valsechi . Edited by Sonic Hustle .

item.title: Closereads: Peter Railton's "Moral Realism" (Audio Part Five)
item.description:
Here we emerge from talking about a wants/interests dynamic in the individual case to talk about the self-interest of societies and the comparable dynamics in how they improve towards social rationality. To allow this comparison, Railton defines a criterial theory of rationality: It is rational to build a roof according to criteria whereby it will function effectively as a roof. Likewise, it is rational for an individual to act according to objective interest, for a society to act set laws and norms to optimize social rationality, and ultimately we want to get to a theory whereby it is rational for an individual to act according to social rationality.

Read along with us , starting on PDF p. 21.

item.title: Ep. 372: Kant's Ethics Lectures (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
Continuing from part one on the 1785 course lecture notes Georg Ludwig Collins, as collected in the Cambridge edition .

We cover "Of Duties to Oneself," which are actually the primary ethical duties. This is not a matter of pursuing your desires, but recognizing your inherent dignity, and respecting that. When you do this, you'll have integrity, and will be in a good position to respect the inherent humanity in others. So don't kill yourself, don't sell your body (or parts of it), don't use yourself as a means to pleasure, and above all, don't abuse your own will by acting according to whim; you need to instead act according to some law, some reasons.

Even some actions that we normally judge due to their negative effects on others are to be condemned on the grounds that they violate the humanity of the actor. When you lie, even if it doesn't hurt anyone, you violate your own integrity. If you hurt animals, or have sex with them, Kant is not so concerned with the animals' pain (they aren't members of the moral community), but you are making yourself into a worse person. We found an unexpected emphasis on this text in honor and pride, which as emotions, do not determine what is moral, but they are important in motivating morality, especially when it comes to duties toward oneself.

The only morally legitimate sexual act for Kant is within marriage, as sex involves a revealing of the whole self, an opening to another person, and if you do this but yet try to be casual about it, you are engaged in self-contradiction, and you are debasing yourself and the other person. He is also against homosexuality, for the tedious reason that such sex is not procreative, and so gay sex runs counter to "the ends of humanity." By this logic he should condemn any sex that does not involve both parties being fertile and actively trying to conceive, but he doesn't get into this. Even though sex within marriage is OK, the very nature of the sexual impulse as desiring merely the body of another person is debasing. So yeah, Kant had some problems with the idea of sex.

When it comes to duties to others, Kant is surprisingly egalitarian if not actually socialist. It would be fair if material goods were spread equally among people, but since they aren't (due to nature but moreso unjust social arrangements), it is our duty to give charitably and help correct this natural injustice. So while other moralists might consider charity to be an imperfect duty, i.e. extra credit for which you'd be considered extra virtuous, for Kant, this is just what is due from us our of respect for others' basic humanity, just like not harming them.

So generosity is about duty, not about love, and Kant disapproves of overly soft natures that pursue goodness out of love. Ethical duties need to be recognized via reason, not emotions. Once we get in the habit of doing the right thing out of duty, then the feelings will typically follow.

Another implication of our owed respect for humanity is that we owe everyone basic good will, even while punishing them. We should honor the humanity in everyone, even if that humanity is occluded by their immoral acts. So condemning someone to death is not incompatible with wishing them well, and in fact capital punishment should only proceed out of respect for the perpetrator: We take your crime seriously, and ensure you pay the debt to humanity that you have incurred with your crime.

Next episode: After a part three covering a bit more of this text, for ep. 373 we'll be discussing ch. 4-6 of Michael Walzer's Just and Unjust Wars (1977).

item.title: Ep. 372: Kant's Ethics Lectures (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
On the 1784-1785 course lectures given in Konigsberg, via notes from Georg Ludwig Collins. We used the Cambridge edition (2013) picked what sections to read via a syllabus we found online . Featuring Mark, Wes, Seth, and Dylan.

We originally discussed Kant's ethics via his Groundwork (also 1785) back in our ep. 10 and wanted to revisit the ideas given our recent work on Korsgaard (a basically Kantian ethicist), and this work had been pointed out to us as being full of specific, practical ethical instructions, not just the abstract meta-ethical theories that Kant is famous for. Knowing that ethics can't pull from anything empirical is fine and good, but how does this, for instance, apply to friendship, which we seem to learn about by observing and experiencing what it is to have and be a good friend? Also, our prejudice about Kant was that his ethics is largely negative, pointing out what would be a moral violation (a violation of the Categorical Imperative), and not so concerned with positive guidance about being a virtuous person. So we wanted to see if that preconception was justified.

The early sections we focus on in this half of the discussion are a bit more high level, including introductory observations and then one called "The Supreme Principle of Morality." In the latter, he discusses the relation between normative ethics and descriptive psychology. While in his better known works, Kant is dismissive of discussions of psychology and human nature as irrelevant to normative ethics, here he acknowledges that of course, in addition to knowing ethical laws, we want to create ethical people, and so need to understand motivation. Like Hume, he acknowledges that passions are what chiefly motivates action, but he leaves a role for the understanding in tending us towards thinking of things in universal terms, which is a necessary ingredient in moral motivation.

The "supreme principle" in question is pretty much the Categorical Imperative (as described in his other works), though that term is not used here: "Morality is the conformity of the action to a universally valid law of free choice." To be motivated by a moral feeling, then, is to be affected by a moral judgment of the understanding. He says "Nobody can or ever will comprehend how the understanding should have a motivating power; it can admittedly judge, but to give this judgement power so that it becomes a motive able to impel the will to performance of an action - to understand this is the philosophers' stone." So he seems caught between Hume's theory of motivation and his own theory here; Hume says the understanding cannot be a motive, yet for Kant, ethical laws are entirely a function of the understanding. Yet somehow the rational recognition of ethics results in moral feelings, and we don't really understand how this works.

Image by Chris Warr (aka Solomon Grundy).

item.title: Closereads: Peter Railton's "Moral Realism" (Audio Part Four)
item.description:
Start with part one (audio for all three previous parts has been made publicly available to get you up to speed: parts two and three ).

In light of our recent contemporary ethics episodes, we return to try to finish Peter Railton's seminal 1984 essay. So far, he's just been giving us an account of our objective individual interests: What you would want for your current you if you had all the relevant knowledge. He had given an example of a dehydrated person who wants and enjoys milk, even though milk does not help with dehydration in the way that water does. If he had the relevant knowledge, he would water. More precisely, he would want his current self in the state of dehydration to want water, because who knows what such an all-knowing person would even be like or what his wants for himself would be?

We're still picking at the complexities of this as we resume progress in this essay; it's not until the end of this hour that we can even predict where he's going in terms of setting up actual morality, beyond mere objective self-interest.

Read along with us , starting on PDF p. 15.

Watch the video .

item.title: PEL Normative Nightcap 2025
item.description:
Yes, it is surely pleasurable to hang with Mark, Wes, Seth and Dylan trying to make sense of our recent episodes, but is it obligatory? Just because it will make you a smarter, cooler, happier person, is it something you can safely ignore without censure?

Well, given that you pay for PEL, and this Nightcap is part of the experience, not just in the usual way of Nightcaps, but in that we're grappling with (and even quoting!) the very same texts by Korsgaard, Foot, and (to a lesser degree) the accounts of empathy by Scheler and Stein, it would be illogical to skip this one.

So, on Foot vs. Korsgaard: Clearly Foot (like MacIntyre and Bernard Williams) is operating within a virtue ethics framework, and Korsgaard is a self-identifying Kantian, so we might expect that they're simply not talking to each other, and it's true that the reference to each other's work in these books is minimal. But Foot takes great pains to talk about what constitutes a reason for action for people, and of course her (and Aristotle's) idea of virtue involves human rational choice. The specifically human excellence for Foot is not just "reason" generically but a well-functioning human will ; so this all sounds very Kantian.

On the other hand, Korsgaard is a synthesist and explicitly tries to find what's right in virtue ethics (specifically Bernard Williams) to include in her account. We are not (as for Kant) merely vessels of choice, but choice refers to human identities, which are both required by and refer to human nature. If human nature were merely an empirical idea (i.e. we look at humans and generalize about how they act), then this would be very un-Kantian. Instead, human nature as virtue ethicists see it is teleological, i.e. directional: humans, when functioning properly, tend toward their excellence. The word "properly" is only a semi-empirical term, as it involves a guess from looking at a variety of people what they as organisms, and specifically as humans, are aiming at. Rationalists all the way back to Plato take this to mean that we need some kind of ideal (for Kant, "regulative idea") to explain the direction of effort built into our practices in virtually all areas: In mathematics, engineering, science, everyday inquiry, all sorts of actions, and even in language itself we are aiming at truth or goodness or what have you. So if per my human nature I need to identify, e.g. as a member of my family, then that idea has built into it what a good family member would do: support and love other members of the family. If I identify in this way and fail in the consequent duties, then I am being inconsistent. So though this picture from Korsgaard has some elements of Kantianism in it (in that a sinner is inconsistent, and in that ultimate identifications are not optional, but categorical), it also has a lot of virtue ethics built into it as well.

Though Korsgaard doesn't (I believe) talk about a "well functioning human" in the way that Foot does, this seems compatible with her talk of basic human needs including the need for identity and consequently the need to identify as a human being and treat other human beings with similar respect due to the humanity they share with the actor.

But can the idea of "well functioning" by itself answer the normative question that Korsgaard asks? Even identifying that I am a human, that I have certain tendencies (toward health and happiness), that I judge other people according to their standards of functioning ("what's wrong with that guy?"), does that normatively obligate me to act according to Foot's idea of well functioning? (Note that this is a separate question from, knowing what it is to be well-functioning, will that motivate me to be so?) This is easier to think about when considering an actual example. Foot says that well function includes acknowledgment of our fundamentally social nature: We are a cooperative species, so we should help each other rather than hurt each other, even when it would be in my self interest to do otherwise.

Certainly if I'm thinking about stealing, it wouldn't be an undeniable motive for me to think, "normal, well-adjusted people don't do this." But on Foot's account, this would be sufficient to establish an objective obligation for me not to steal. Or is the notion of obligation just fundamentally foreign to Foot, given that she's a virtue ethicist? Per our Closereads series on H.A. Prichard, it being a virtue to be honest (which involves not stealing) is fundamentally a different thing from having the obligation to not steal. Doing the right thing (not stealing) does not require having the virtue (being the kind of person who would never steal), and vice versa. So if being a well-functioning human being means being the kind of person who would never steal, we would expect then that such a person would not steal in most situations, though this would be defeasible such that in dire situations (stealing medicine to help a dying person) the person not only would steal, but it would be right to do so.

Perhaps Foot is just following in Hume's footsteps, establishing that morality motivates us in a standard way, and that we thus judge others and hopefully ourselves in line with these standard reactions. If someone feels totally immune to conscience and feels himself to be beyond good and evil, then the moralist can only say "Really? Look further within yourself and you will find conscience there." So normativity reduces to facts about human nature for Foot (or any virtue ethicist), and Korsgaard's demand for something additional to make this normative on individuals is simply misplaced. For Foot, you have an objective well functioning state, and reference to this is a legitimate reason to act according to that state and to fault those who do not act according to that state.

item.title: Closereads: H.A. Prichard on Ethics (Audio Part Three)
item.description:
Finishing up "Does Moral Philosophy Rest on a Mistake?" (1912). We finally get to the thesis: Just as global epistemic skepticism is unwarranted, so is skepticism about moral obligation. There is no need for moral philosophy to establish this, and even the contents of morality will largely be given and judged via intuition, with little room for philosophy. The only point of moral philosophy would be to establish these two facts.

Read along with us , starting on PDF p. 13.

item.title: Ep. 371: Christine Korsgaard on Normativity (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
Concluding our treatment of The Sources of Normativity . Listen to part one first, or better yet, start with ep. 370 .

We start by conveying Korsgaard’s interpretation of Kant, by which the categorical imperative (act such that your maxim can be a law) and the moral law (treat everyone as an end in themselves) aren’t actually the same, since the former could conceivably have a more limited scope; one could act in a lawlike (non-whimsical) way to consistently pursue one’s self-interest, for instance (this would be Ayn Rand’s “ethics”). To obey some law or other means operating from some identity or other, but this doesn’t tell us what identity we should pursue. Korsgaard suggests (following Bernard Williams) that we can rank potential identities as to the degree to which they promote flourishing, and she thinks that an Enlightenment identity whereby we are lawful citizens of the world is clearly better than blood-and-soil tribalism or honor-based identity.

We then explain Korsgaard’s invocation of Wittgenstein’s private language argument in claiming that reason-making and identities are fundamentally public. If it were purely personal, then it wouldn’t be possible for us to make an error; in any case of normativity (such as “this word properly has this meaning”), there has to be more than one person to establish the standard that one could then fail to meet. We don’t start by justifying reasonable behavior that is purely self-referential (a la Rand); if we were to do this, we would never then be able to extend this out to include other people. Instead, reasons are primarily social, and in fact anyone’s demand for our attention and regard is a prima facie reason to accommodate them, which of course could in most cases be overruled by other considerations.

We try to better make sense of this and how Korsgaard compares to Foot in a Nightcap discussion coming out within the next week. Next Time : We read the 1785 ethics lectures of Immanuel Kant .

item.title: Ep. 371: Christine Korsgaard on Normativity (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
On lectures 3 and 4 of The Sources of Normativity (1996), continuing our discussion of the book from ep. 370 .

Why is morality obligatory on us? According to Korsgaard, it's because we have a primary need for an identity (multiple identities, actually, or rather multiple roles that make up our identity), and this identity involves obligations. If I were to cross some ethical line, then I would no longer be the kind of person I thought I was, and that identity was what provided me with a coherent, meaningful basis for action.

While lecture three just establishes this fact about how identities and obligations connect, lecture four makes this explicitly ethical: Why should your identity necessarily imply respect for others? This is because we have a necessary identity as human beings, and this identity makes all the more specific ones (parent, citizen, member of whatever organization, holder of some office) possible. To identify as a human being is to respect humanity in general, which means respecting the humanity of every other person. So the upshot is a form of Kantianism, where we are supposed to treat people as ends in themselves. While one could identify as an assassin, with the code of an assassin (e.g. only kill the target, not civilians), this would ultimately be an incoherent and thus unsustainable identity, because assassinating fundamentally disrespects the humanity of the victims.

The phenomenology of this is that our self-consciousness divides our desires from our reflective side. We can think about and reflectively endorse some desire, which gives it our sanction: The reflective part commands the active part to follow that desire. When we convert a desire into a reason in this way, even though this consideration is going on in the mind of just one individual, it is relying on potentially public (typically linguistic) considerations. Something that is a legitimate reason is something I could explain to another person, and which could potentially likewise motivate that person. An identity itself (a particular role) is not something an individual creates, but refers to some social (public) entity: What it is to be a family member and have obligations to other family members is determined by a culture, not just by you as an individual. And typically I would be called to perform a family duty by another member of the family expressing some need. So I would feel a desire to help, and my (not necessarily conscious) consideration of my duties as a family member would lead me to consider that desire as legitimate, and so I'd move to help, and could explain (if asked) my behavior by reference to the family relationship.

If the situation is one in which the family member has murdered someone and wants me to help hide the body (or worse, to murder the witnesses), I will (hopefully) feel conflicted. If I identify solely as family member and do not acknowledge the humanity of the victim, then something has gone wrong. This mafia-type notion of family has become unmoored from its status as a subdivision of humanity that adds special duties of care. It's not supposed to suspend all obligations toward those outside the family, to change them into "Others" outside of my circle of moral concern.

Learn about Mark's online political philosophy class at partiallyexaminedlife.com/class.

Image by Chris Warr (aka Solomon Grundy).

item.title: Closereads: H.A. Prichard on Ethics (Audio Part Two)
item.description:
More on "Does Moral Philosophy Rest on a Mistake?" (1912). Prichard continues discussing the relation of motives and dispositions to morality. He highlights distinctions that he thinks are often overlooked in motivating ethics, e.g. between morality (doing the right thing) and virtue (the quality by which one typically does the right thing). So a moral action may not be a virtuous one, if it's done by someone for the wrong motives.

Read along with us , starting on PDF p. 7.

item.title: Closereads: H.A. Prichard on Ethics (Audio Part One)
item.description:
On "Does Moral Philosophy Rest on a Mistake?" (1912). Prichard claims that we feel certain actions to be obligatory, and that we have no justification for doubting those raw intuitions. The situation, he claims, is comparable to epistemology: We have no grounds for doubting globally a la Descartes, but only in particular circumstances where science demands we should go back and check again, but more carefully.

Likewise, we can be wrong about particular moral judgments, but the process of refining them is just to put ourselves (really or imaginatively) in the ethical situation and gauge the intuitions more carefully. So the only legitimate task of moral philosophy is to establish that global doubt is not warranted, and to get us to observe our intuitions more carefully and discuss them with others.

Read along with us .

item.title: Ep. 370: Christine Korsgaard on the History of Ethics (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
We dive further into the text of lectures 1 and 2 of The Sources of Normativity (1996). Start with part one.

Her test for reflective endorsement, which is a method that starts with Hume, goes through Bernard Williams and to Korsgaard's ultimate view, asks us to explain the origins of our moral sentiments, and asks us, knowing the origins now of your own sentiments, do you endorse them? If the view were a Marxist one that morality is just what the bosses have brainwashed you into believing, then realizing this would (hopefully) free you from those views. Even if out of habit, you still found yourself agreeing with them, you would know that they are not justified. For Hume, though, even though we know we come about our moral sentiments naturally (through evolution or whatnot), we still like that nature gave these to us, because they make our lives easier. So one way of endorsing the verdicts or morality is to judge them via another standard, such as self-interest: Hume says that of course we want to be loved, so it's great that we have sentiments that encourage us to help other people, which is likely to generate such love in return.

According to Bernard Williams, we have many such standards to choose from, corresponding to all the cultures and sub-cultures we're familiar with, so we can use one to judge another. We can judge some alleged ethical reason from the point of view of self-interest, benevolence, and even the point of view of that ethics itself (sometimes ethical commandments are internally incoherent). The standpoint that trumps them all, however, is that of human flourishing (eudaimonia). Moral progress is possible because we can judge what we have inherited from culture against the acquired human wisdom of how well these ethical practices have worked out in helping people maximize their potential.

Korsgaard concludes the second lecture by setting the stage for her own theory: According to Kant, an autonomous moral agent is one who evaluates their desires reflectively to see which ones can serve as reasons, which Kant characterizes as laws for action. In our next episode, we'll go into how Korsgaard interprets and tweaks the idea of a law of motivation, such that being a law of motivation is not sufficient for according with the moral law , unless the scope of the law ranges over other people (and unlike Kant, Korsgaard wants to include animals as well under the category of creatures we have duties towards). So a law of motivation could just be a commitment to act consistently and coherently, i.e. according to reasons, instead of just following each desire as it comes up (the law could even be "I will act strictly according to each desire as it comes up"!); this would fall far short of morality. So in our next episode, we'll describe how according to Korsgaard, consideration of others is built right into the idea of reasoning, which is an inherently public activity (per Wittgenstein's private language argument ).

item.title: Ep. 370: Christine Korsgaard on the History of Ethics (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
On The Sources of Normativity , lectures 1 and 2, which were delivered in 1992, published 1996. Featuring Mark, Wes, Seth, and Dylan.

How are facts related to obligations? Korsgaard's own view is a tweaked view of Kantianism , and we'll be laying that out in ep. 371, but she presents this view as the result and synthesis of a progression of previous views starting with Thomas Hobbes (and Samuel von Pufendorf ) who were grappling with the place of normativity (the "ought" quality that makes some actions obligatory) in a scientific world.

Whereas Plato and Aristotle had no problem with positing the essence of reality as something beyond and better than what you actually see, toward which things naturally gravitate, this teleological picture was banished with the scientific revolution. If the world is just made up of matter following natural laws, where is there room for the idea that situations or people or their actions "ought" to be some way other than they are? For "voluntarists" like Hobbes and Pufendorf, this could only come from someone commanding you do to things, and then backing up those commands with force. But as we know from existentialism, the fact that someone (even God!) commands something is not sufficient to justify its rightness for me. The presence of sanctions for disobeying is a motivation to obey, sure, but this still doesn't make the command morally right.

Korsgaard goes on to claim that Hume's view, if characterized by saying simply that we all have moral sentiments, is incomplete. The fact that we naturally have such sentiments does not make those sentiments justified, and Hume knows this. Something additional is needed: We have to on reflection approve of those sentiments (and we could of course be wrong in this reflection and require further reflection, ad nauseam, just as science can always continue to investigate something and improve its views). This is a core component of Korsgaard's own theory: Morality is characterized by reflective endorsement , where you have some desire to act in a certain way, and by thinking about it, you might make that desire into a reason. But what can ground such an endorsement?

Moral realists like G.E. Moore argued that there is room in a scientific picture of the world for a special class of entity, moral facts, which are not reducible to people's commands or their happiness or other sentiments. We intuitively recognize these facts as basic components of our experienced universe: We simply "see" that an action or principle is right or wrong, that a state of affairs or of someone's character is good or bad. This was famously countered by J.L. Mackie via the "argument from queerness": These moral entities and these moral intuitions sure do sound weird given our usual scientific talk!

Korsgaard will end up saying that moral facts are part of our experienced world (they are real), but they are a phenomena of our will, not part of physics and chemistry or biology. Only scientism--the insistence that humanistic things like consciousness, morality and art can only be understood in terms of these physical sciences--would cause us to reject the furniture of our consciousness as somehow unreal. We have to theorize about morality in the setting where we encounter it; if we try to reduce it to mere facts about human nature, brain chemistry, etc., we will lose sight of its normative character.

For Korsgaard, normativity, the obligatory character of some actions, ends up being real for us, insofar as we have certain human needs such as the need for what Bernard Williams calls a "thick identity" that involves certain actions being off-limits. So Aristotle ends up being right after all, just in that human flourishing is implicated in our reflective endorsement of moral reasons for action.

The key Kantian element here is that the fact on which value is based cannot be something outside of our own will. It's not that I note that some actions are likely to cause my flourishing (and/or the flourishing of others), and I realize that I want to flourish, and so I do that thing (this was more or less Philippa Foot's view), but that the act of considering and endorsing this pro-flourishing desire involves my subjugating the part of me that acts to the part of me that thinks, and for reflective endorsement to happen at all, I must act within various entities including most importantly my identity as a human being among other human beings, and in doing this, I give myself moral commands. So the voluntarists (Hobbes) were right that morality is a command, but it's a command we give ourselves.

If this is confusing, we'll lay it out in much more detail in ep. 370, but I wanted to point you in the direction she's heading in the part of the book we discuss here.

Buy the book or check out this online version of the original lectures .

item.title: Closereads: Parfit on Game Theory (Audio Part Two)
item.description:
Continuing on Derek Parfit's "Prudence, Morality, and the Prisoner's Dilemma" (1978). What's the rational thing to do when morality conflicts with self-interest? If everyone does the right thing, then we as a group do better, yet each of us as individuals does worse than if we did the wrong thing while everyone else did the right thing. Parfit calls this an "Each-We Dilemma."

Read along with us , starting on PDF p. 8.

item.title: Ep. 369: Philippa Foot's Naturalistic Ethics (Part Three for Supporters)
item.description:
Mark and Seth return to talk through the last three chapters of Natural Goodness , examining Foot's alleged difference between animal and plant goods on the one hand and specifically human good on the other. She locates the latter in our rational will, in our ability to make choices, though at the same time she does not share Kant's insistence that the only way in which we are "good," the only criteria that could best determine our actions, lies in our rational decision-making.

The chapter we ended part two on had to do with practical rationality, and argued that insofar as we are well-functioning humans, we make decisions based on rational grounds. We do not typically aim explicitly at being a well-functioning person, but when functioning properly, we aim at things at which a good person aims, such as doing good rather than harm to others. Foot disagrees with Hume that we are only motivated by desires and feelings; we can and should be motivated by reasons, even as our desires and feelings can be among these reasons. The source of normativity in the world, the "shouldness" of certain actions, is that we have reasons for doing certain things, we weigh and select among these, and decide what to do (what we "should" do) all things considered.

This picture gave us two concerns: First, does it make sense for the picture of ethics here to focus so much on rational choice given how irrational and undeliberate people typically are? Second, does this difference between human good (focused on a well functioning rational will) and animal/plant good (focused on health) undermine her whole Aristotelian thesis that virtue for humans is comparable to virtue for animals and plants? Foot does not seem concerned about the first of these issues; we're trying to say what the human good is, not how people typically act. But (Seth claims) it does seem a problem if very very few people are "well functioning" in Foot's conception, given that this is supposed to be empirical: We determine what adequate function means because this is how this type of creature (humanity, in this case) tends to look, not because we somehow divine a secret, virtuous destiny that few among the species actually achieve.

The second issue is one Foot addresses at length: Chapter Five is called "Human Goodness," and gives Aristotle's distinction at length between voluntary acts (the ones morality, i.e. evaluation of our adequate function as humans, deals with) and less voluntary ones, which includes not just cases like drunken action, but action through ignorance. Of course, ignorance may itself be voluntary, as when someone neglects to learn what one could reasonably be expected to. So having qualities such as conscientiousness, and more generally practical wisdom (phronesis) ends up being relevant morally, even though we cannot simply will ourselves to have them, so morality is is not all about voluntary choice but about being the kind of person whose choice capabilities are functioning well. While this is not an ability that animals and plants have, it is still part of our natural makeup; our virtue can be evaluated based on that makeup and not merely (per Kant) on the rightness of our motives in each case. This is all in accord with Aristotle, who of course had the idea of a telos (natural goodness) for each kind of creature, but distinguished humanity as the rational animal, and so our telos as concerning rationality.

Chapter Six is called "Happiness and the Human Good," and continues Foot's deliberations about whether moral fitness and the natural, ultimate object of our choice--i.e. happiness or in Greek eudaimonia--are always in harmony. In one sense, a former concentration camp guard or other villain might seem to be living a happy, peaceful life, but Foot claims that such people cannot have deep happiness, which extends to the underlying thoughts that they have about themselves and their lives.

Foot conversely describes those who defied the Nazis and wrote letters about this before they were killed. Such people's lives didn't "work out," but these (predominantly religious) people described themselves as satisfied with their choices: Happiness in the recognizable sense simply wasn't achievable for them, because it wasn't attainable by honorable means. If happiness meant accepting the Nazis, and happiness isolated from virtue isn't deep happiness, then they chose the "happier" outcome in dying for their beliefs.

The final chapter, "Immoralism," extends these considerations to consider whether, e.g. the view of Thrasymachus (Socrates' antagonist in The Republic who insists that virtue is just the dictates of the stronger) is compatible with real friendship (it is not). Our concern, addressed briefly at the end of our discussion here, is with her take on Nietzsche, whom she accuses of in large part not being an immoralist as he sometimes seems to claim, but just a moral reformer, questioning values such as pity as not actually in line with human goodness. However, when Nietzsche praises cruelty as a necessary part of human nature, Foot says he is confusing animal goodness (which may well involve zero-sum, carnivorous behavior) with human goodness. Foot denies Nietzsche's claim that goodness is not a species matter but wholly individualistic, so no action (even rape and murder) is simply wrong but needs to be evaluated in terms of the individual performing the action. Even more damningly, Nietzsche claimed that only that individual is in the position to legitimately evaluate their own actions: Individuals must create their own values rather than paying heed to anyone else. Foot thought that this view was simply not supported by observation. There are clear species-level matters of human good, such as the human need to be protected from oppressors, that Nietzsche failed to recognize.

item.title: Closereads: Parfit on Game Theory (Audio Part One)
item.description:
On Derek Parfit's "Prudence, Morality, and the Prisoner's Dilemma" (1978). What is a "prisoner's dilemma" and what is its relevance to ethics? In general, it's better for me if I break norms so long as others in general follow them, but if we all try to be free riders in this way, then no one gets to ride at all. Parfit considers variations of this situation and lays out legislative and ideological/psychological strategies for addressing them.

Read along with us .

item.title: Ep. 369: Philippa Foot's Naturalistic Ethics (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
Continuing from part one on Natural Goodness , getting more into concrete cases of moral reasoning. How and why do we decide to keep promises, even in cases where violating them would produce more utility? How do we take into account different kinds of grounds in moral reasoning?

We also refine Foot's account of specifically human goodness. To give one example: For most animals, not reproducing would indicate a deviation from the norm that indicates something's gone wrong. However, people can of course choose to not have children without moral defect, and even if someone biologically can't have children, this ability is not central to human goodness, which specifically has to do with the choosing will. Given that emphasis on a "normal" will, is there room in Foot's view for real moral excellence, going above and beyond?

Mark and Seth subsequently recorded a part three to complete our treatment of this book, which will be released within the next week or so, just for you supporters.

Next episode : We'll be recording two episodes on Christine Korsgaard's The Sources of Normativity (1996), the first of which will walk us through the history of ethical theory as it regards the question of what makes ethics obligatory; what gives an ethical command normative force?

item.title: Ep. 369: Philippa Foot's Naturalistic Ethics (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
On Natural Goodness (2001), Foot's only book (she died in 2010), which summed up her thoughts on ethics after publishing many influential papers in that area going back to 1959. Featuring Mark, Wes, and Seth.

Can we base ethics on the model of biology? Foot channels Aristotle in arguing that just as we understand what a healthy specimen of a plant or animal is that fulfills expectations for that species (i.e. nothing "is wrong with it"), so there is a natural way for humans to lack disfigurement. Of course, uniquely human capabilities make human goodness differ from that of other animals, in that we make reflective choices. According to Foot, if I were to, for instance, choose to be a free rider, relying on others to act morally while I do not, then there would be something wrong with me, specifically with the way in which I engage in moral reasoning.

Even when considering animals, Foot's take is a little different than Aristotle's, in that she emphasizes that not all characteristics that make a good specimen of the animal necessarily benefit that individual animal. An animal may naturally sacrifice some of its individual benefit for its offspring (may even routinely die in producing offspring!), but that's still a part of its natural goodness. Likewise, for people, we are not self-interest maximizers; I may be a faulty human being given our species' usual requirement for cooperative effort if I fail in these efforts, even if I end up in thriving health and joy. Still, she shares Aristotle's overall approach in treating moral virtue and non-moral virtues as not fundamentally different, yet in tying the distinctly human virtues to our ability to make reflective, reasoned choices.

Foot adds to this Aristotelian framework a way of talking about practical rationality from Hume and Kant: Morality is not just a matter of identifying what is good or virtuous, but of motivating people to do good and be virtuous. If I'm being a free rider (taking benefits without putting in work) and someone says "it's not normal for your species to act like this," will this convince me? No, but if I'm making a reasoned choice, and I have normal sentiments, then I will feel averse to being a free rider. For Kant, there's something about the very structure of the will itself such that I will see moral commandments as obligatory.

According to Foot, we can recognize and respond to motivating reasons whether our desires are involved or not. She rejects the Kantian Categorical Imperative but retains the idea (against Hume) that the will can be motivated by reasons, and (per Aristotle) that virtuous people will be motivated not by the reason that they want to be "normal" but by a complex of reasons that have to do with getting along and thriving in the world, which include self-interest, yes, but also sympathy for others, duty, what society tells them is moral, etc. All of these go into moral reasoning, so perhaps surprisingly, in some circumstances, a wise moral agent will find that acting in a typically moral way is not called for in some case, all things considered. For example, I have a moral obligation to keep an appointment, but I feel sick and decide to break that in order to stay home and feel better. Here, a fundamentally self-interested reason overrules a specifically moral obligation here, yet there's nothing immoral about this decision.

Buy the book or try it online . Here's her 1972 essay on hypothetical imperatives that we bring up.

Image by Charles Valsechi . Edited by Sonic Hustle .

item.title: Closereads: Spinoza on Emotions (Audio Part Two)
item.description:
Continuing on the Ethics , Third Part, "Concerning the Origin and Nature of the Emotions," describing how the view of emotions as passive and reason as active works given Spinoza's determinist metaphysics and the ultimate unity of mind and body.

We eventually just read through his propositions and notes, skipping several of the proofs, so that we can get through his points about will vs. appetite and pleasure vs. pain through his overall project of describing all of our complex emotions on the basis of simpler ones.

Read along with us , starting on p. 88 (PDF p. 134).

item.title: Closereads: Spinoza on Emotions (Audio Part One)
item.description:
On Spinoza's Ethics , Third Part, "Concerning the Origin and Nature of the Emotions."

We want to see how emotions ground ethics, but first, we have to explain what emotions are, which means explaining how mind and body (and causality) work together on Spinoza's account. A passion is being affected by something that we don't understand, whereas reason (which will yield ethical behavior) involves grasping a cause clearly and distinctly. The latter means it's in your individual mind, whereas even if you don't understand the cause, it's still in God's mind, which each of us is essentially a part of.

Read along with us , starting on p. 83 (PDF p. 129).

item.title: Ep. 368: Hume on Reason in Ethics (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
We conclude our discussion of A Treatise of Human Nature (1739): Book III, “Of Morals,” plus a bit more discussion of An Enquiry Concerning the Principles of Morals (1751). Listen to part one first, or better yet, start with ep. 367 .

How do moral sentiments fit into Hume’s overall philosophy of mind? Hume famously our conscious experience to be composed solely of impressions and ideas. Any sentiment would have to be an impression, but like many impressions, a moral sentiment contains reference to something in the world, i.e. the behavior or whatever that we’re morally judging. Yet Hume’s point is that even though “this is good” is a sentence that looks to be about that referent, it’s made true by sentiment lying in us. And if ethical claims are really about ourselves, then they’re just expressive and can’t actually be true or false. Someone’s moral sense can be stunted or otherwise faulty, but morality is still fundamentally a matter of taste. So does this make Hume a relativist?

We talk about sociopaths, animals, incest, consent, ethics vs. beauty, moral luck, and more.

Next Time: We’re reading Philippa Foot’s Natural Goodness (2001), especially chapters 1-4.

item.title: Ep. 368: Hume on Reason in Ethics (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
Continuing our treatment from ep. 367 , we talk a bit more about David Hume's An Enquiry Concerning the Principles of Morals (1751), specifically on the conclusion and Appendix I, "Concerning Moral Sentiment," and add some parts of A Treatise of Human Nature (1739): sec. 3 "Of the Influencing Motives of the Will" within the third part of Book II, "Of the Passions," and the first two sections of Book III, "Of Morals."

Can reason by itself motivate moral action? Hume says no: All ethical reasons must point ultimately to sentiments, which we can generalize about (saying that in general we approve what brings about utility, for instance) but which are themselves epistemically basic. We can't tell what's good or bad without these feelings, and even if we could, the feelings are required to get us to act.

Hume claims that obligation can't be something divorced from human motivation. Though some individuals may be morally insensitive in some respects, a moral sense is a fundamental part of human nature, and this doesn't require further explication (as, for instance, evolutionary biologists might give us). In fact, if we say that we only feel such sentiments because of some specific fact about human nature or development, this is interesting scientifically, but ethically irrelevant: Knowing that most people feel this way or that we are typically programmed to do so does not provide a justification for you to feel this way if you don't already; this is an instance of Hume's vaunted fact-value distinction. To say that morality can be grounded in matters of fact is to deny this distinction. Instead, it is grounded, irreducibly, in nothing but itself. (We can see how this would later lead G.E. Moore to define a class of specifically "ethical facts" detectable by ethical intuitions, irreducible to any facts about happiness, health, pleasure, etc.)

Of course, moral evaluation and decision-making involve recognition of (and so reasoning about) many factual issues, such as "Did this person really perform that action, and with what motive?" But knowing such facts (i.e. using reason to ascertain them and their relations) would not be sufficient to generate the moral evaluation without moral sentiment contributing.

Here's an online version of the Treatise , and here again is the Enquiry .

Image by Chris Warr (aka Solomon Grundy).

item.title: Closereads: Scheler on Personhood (Audio Part Three)
item.description:
On "Formalism in Ethics and Non-Formal Ethics of Values" (1916), Ch. 6 "Formalism and Person," sec. 3, "Person and Act."

Parts one and two of this series were mostly about how Scheler rejects Kant's idea of the transcendental ego. It's fine if you haven't heard those, as we're more or less starting fresh: skipping several pages from our last installment to start with section 3 on the recommendation from a member of the International Scheler society, hoping that at least we will find out what makes a person: What makes each of us unique and worthy of moral respect?

Watch the video .

item.title: Closereads: Edith Stein on Self (Audio Part Three)
item.description:
Concluding our treatment of "On the Problem of Empathy," ch. 4 "Empathy as the Comprehension of Mental Persons." We finish the lengthy sec. 3, "The Constitution of the Person in Emotional Experiences" on the relation of willing to the self, then the shorter sec. 4, "The Givenness of the Foreign Person" and 5, "Soul and Person," which finally gets us to Stein's idea that we have some core personality that would be the same even if our environment was totally different, that contains potential that can be fulfilled or not, and that this is what love latches onto and what demands our moral respect.

Read along with us , starting on p97 (PDF p117).

item.title: Ep. 367: Hume on the Foundations of Ethics (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
Continuing from part one on An Enquiry Concerning the Principles of Morals (1751). We dive into ch. 2 on justice: Hume says that the idea of property is not natural, but is an artificial construct created for utilitarian purposes. This means that property laws will be different in different societies based on what is scarce enough to require regulation and protection.

Hume's idea of "utility" is very wide; there are some virtues Hume says we have moral respect for which are not socially useful, but only personally useful. We admire when someone has strength of mind or other qualities that are merely pleasing to that has them. This means that Hume does not draw a sharp line between moral and non-moral types of excellence. However, he does want to distinguish, e.g. strength of mind from avarice; avarice could be a quality that will benefit a person (financially), and in general financial benefit is a type of utility, yet we don't morally admire avarice.

We talk about who is a member of the moral community according to Hume, moral progress, his relation to social contract theory, relativism, utility vs. beauty, sympathy, how to deal with a truly malevolent individual, and more.

Next episode: We'll wrap up our treatment of this book (the conclusion and first appendix) and bring in Hume's earlier work, A Treatise of Human Nature (1739), specifically looking at two sections: Book II: Of the Passions, Part 3 Of the Will and Direct Passions, section 3, “Of the Influencing Motives of the Will"; and Book III: Of Morals, Part 1 Of Virtue and Vice in General, sections 1 and 2.

item.title: Ep. 367: Hume on the Foundations of Ethics (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
On David Hume's An Enquiry Concerning the Principles of Morals (1751), featuring Mark, Wes, Dylan, and Seth. What is morality, and how can we know it?

We've been discussing the bases of morality of late: Are fundamental principles revealed to us by reason (perhaps "rational intuition"), or by sentiment (e.g. our feelings of empathy with others. Hume is a chief voice in the latter category: We simply find ourselves approving and disapproving of various things, being attracted to or repelled by them, even when we're just hearing about them and they won't personally affect us. We feel indignant when we feel about atrocities happening wherever they may occur, and we feel admiration for hearing about some great benefactor, even these benefits were bestowed centuries ago.

So Hume sees his task as scanning these basic moral sentiments and looking for patterns, and in general he sees us admiring actions and people that do great good for many people: the principle of utility. You might have thought that we have, for instance, a particular, fundamental sentiment in favor of justice, but justice is only good insofar as it is serving this utility function.

This all raises some questions for us (and Hume's various critics): Why, for instance, if justice is only as good as the utility it brings, should we affirm the judgments of justice when they produce a bad outcome? Socrates' jurors were justly appointed, and his trial was not fixed, yet the condemnation of Socrates by these wheels of justice was (by most accounts) unjust, and certainly didn't seem at the time to be a net boon for Athenian society or the world. Moreover, even if we want to say that selective violation of law is too corrosive to society to allow, why would Socrates himself feel obligated (as he says he is in the Crito) to go along with the verdict? Socrates' reasoning in the Crito is that he made a deal with society by accepting its boons, so he owes it his allegiance even when it has yielded the wrong verdict. Hume's utility-based reasoning can't seem to make sense of this.

So Hume is claiming that moral rules, though based on our sentiments, are still binding on us, i.e. are still moral rules. This means that reason does have a role here, even though it's not the ultimate source of morality. Once we've determined that our sentiments support utility, then we can apply reason to counter-balance our self-interest in cases where our own benefit goes against the common good. Hume stresses that our basic sentiments are not entirely oriented according to our self-interest (as thinkers like Hobbes claimed); we do experience empathy as a basic part of our moral feeling. But still, there are many illusions in moral perception just as there are in visual perception: A far-away tower looks small, yet we know it is not. Likewise, the greatness or vileness of actions distant from us as individual look to be of less consequence than those that happen nearby, yet we can use reason to correct this distortion.

So even though morality is fundamentally based on feeling, it is a cool feeling of evaluation, which should overrule hot feelings of revenge, ecstatic love, etc.

Buy the edition we used or read an online edition .

Listen to our previous episode (#45!) on Hume and Smith to get some context for how moral sense theory gets applied.

item.title: Closereads: Edith Stein on Self (Audio Part Two)
item.description:
Continuing on On the Problem of Empathy , ch. 4 "Empathy as the Comprehension of Mental Persons," sec. 3, "The Constitution of the Person in Emotional Experiences." How do emotions expose, or perhaps even constitute, the self?

This is partly a matter of the value judgments present in emotions, so we are defined by what we love and loathe. When someone loves you, they use your emotions and values to fix their love onto you, yet since love is supposed to be unconditional, it will persist even if you change your mind and value different things. However, if you were being deceitful, and someone loved you because of that, then when the real you is exposed, their love can recede, because they were loving only a phantom, not via your real emotionally revealed values.

Read along with us , starting on p92 (PDF p112).

item.title: Closereads: Edith Stein on Self (Audio Part One)
item.description:
Mark and Wes discuss "On the Problem of Empathy," ch. 4 "Empathy as the Comprehension of Mental Persons," starting with section 2, "The Mental Subject" and into section 3, "The Constitution of the Person in Emotional Experiences." (So this is the same book as PEL ep 366 , so you can consider this a continuation of that discussion, even though Wes wasn't on it and hadn't heard it.

We're trying to figure out what these early 20th century German phenomenologists think a "person" is as someone we're able to empathize or sympathize with and which is morally worthy of respect. Stein does this by saying what the "I" (the self) is. It is the thing that "has" experiences, but also something that we understand in terms of a network of motivations, which are different than mere causes, in that they're supposed to be rational. Our self gains definition, Stein says, when we have emotional experiences, which can of course be shallow and undirected (mere moods) or can be very deep and self-revelatory.

Read along with us , starting on p. 87 (PDF p. 107).
