item.title: Ep. 366: Edith Stein on Empathy (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
Continuing from part one on The Problem of Empathy (1917). We start out by thinking more about what "primordiality" means, such that we have a non-primordial relation to those experiences of other people whom we're empathizing with as well as our remembered experiences and the not-immediately-visible but implied sides of the objects we encounter.

Next, we map out her strategy in the bulk of the book in presenting a phenomenology of the individual that then allows empathy relations to occur. People have to be explicable by a network of motivations, which are different than mere causes. We can't empathize with a rock even if we understand its physical dispositions (e.g. from gravity it "wants" to descend). When people (or animals?) act, they do so for reasons that we can latch on to and empathize with. These networks of reasons give us the means to expand our horizons; because we assume that people have understandable motivations, when they act or react in a way that is strange or unexpected, we can potentially learn why a person might see things they way they do.

Finally, we try to get clearer on how Stein disagrees with Scheler despite the similarities in their views. It seems that Stein allows us to better understand how people can deceive each other about their emotions, as well as how reciprocal empathy allows us to build a "we" that is the subject of a shared experience.

Despite Stein's use of phenomenology, which is not supposed to be natural science, we relate her discussion to our interview with Michael Tomasello on the origins of agency .

Next Time: We're reading David Hume's Enquiry Concerning the Principles of Morals .

item.title: Ep. 366: Edith Stein on Empathy (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
On The Problem of Empathy (1917), featuring Mark, Seth, and Dylan. What is empathy, and what is its significance?

Stein was Edmund Husserl's research assistant, and this book adapted her doctoral dissertation (so long before she became a Catholic saint and died in the Holocaust). It was very much in dialogue with Scheler's book on sympathy (among his other works), whose first edition Stein had read and is responding to, and whose second edition in turn responds to Stein.

Stein agrees with Scheler that empathy and sympathy are not types of egoism; I really am feeling someone who is irreducibly another person (not just a reinterpreted extension of myself), and in fact Stein accuses Scheler of having a phenomenologically false developmental picture whereby you start by having ideas or experiences which are not attributed explicitly to oneself, and then come to differentiate your thoughts from those of other. This idea fits with Scheler's idea that we can acquire thoughts, habits, and practices from other people through "contagion," e.g. thinking a certain way just because your parents did. Stein does not deny that this takes place, but even if your thought came from your parents, Stein still insists that you always know that it's yours; there is no confusion between you and other people.

Whereas for Scheler, sympathy is a one-stage process whereby I take someone else's emotional state as my object, for Stein, empathy has three stages, of which Scheler's sympathy is only the first. Yes, I take someone else's sorrow (for instance) as my object of consideration, but then I am drawn in and instead focus on the other person's object (e.g. the thing the person is sad about). Finally, I withdraw and have a richer understanding of the other person.

Scheler probably wouldn't like the second stage of this, which sounds too much like "putting yourself in their shoes," i.e. identifying with them. Stein compares this process of contemplating another person's emotional state (and the objects of that state: what the person is sad about) with your own process of memory, and she introduces the distinction between primordial and non-primordial experience. If I go to the zoo, I have a primordial experience of the animals and such. If I then remember going to the zoo, I am taking my past self and its experience as an object. I can summarize the experience or try to re-live it step by step, but either way, I am relating non-primordially to that experience. Likewise, in empathy, when I consider the other person's sorrow, that other person is having a primordial emotional experience, and I in turn in my observational and imaginative exploration of that experience am having it non-primordially.

At no point do I mistakenly think that I'm that other person, or twist the experience so as to imagine how I would act in a similar situation (or how I have reacted in the past to similar situations). I really am focused on the other person's experience as theirs, but I nonetheless am relating myself to it in a pretty direct way. I don't have to look at the person's expression and merely infer that they're having such an experience. I just read the expression as a partially concealed event that's happening in the public world. (It's partially concealed because I could be wrong about it, e.g. maybe the person is suppressing or hiding their sadness, but I still use the same empathic techniques to see through such moves.) So empathy is not just me making up something about the other person, but witnessing it, in a way that involves my (imaginatively) entering into it while never getting confused about what I'm doing. Per Scheler's arguments, for Stein I don't get infected by the experience (it does not become mine, or if it does, that's not part of empathy but something else), nor do the lines between the other person and me get otherwise blurred.

Stein claims that Scheler in describing sympathy just doesn't believe that Stein-type empathy is possible; the "entering into the experience" would inevitably involve violating the requirement that the Other remains Other. For Stein, empathy as she describes it is the necessary precondition for grasping other people on a deep level. The bulk of the book is a phenomenological analysis of what it is to be a person in the world (prefiguring similar though much longer analyses by Heidegger and Merleau-Ponty ) such that other people could thus connect with you.

We talk about what phenomenological method is for Stein and how it relates to science, how this public presence of emotions works (how facial expressions, for instance, signify emotions and how we encounter emotions as part of the other's "living body"), and whether this idea of "primordiality" makes sense.

Buy the book or try this online version .

Image by Charles Valsechi . Edited by Sonic Hustle .

item.title: Closereads: Scheler on Personhood (Audio Part Two)
item.description:
Continuing on Ch. 6 "Formalism and Person," in Max Scheler's Formalism in Ethics and Non-Formal Ethics of Values (1916), section 2, "Person and the 'Ego' of Transcendental Apperception."

Scheler is still at this point trying to explain how his concept of personhood differs from Kant's. For one, Kant regards people as valuable (i.e. as people) only insofar as they are rational subjects, which is not where Scheler is going to go. The ego is not just something we have to posit to account for the unity over time of what we experience, but is itself a part of the experienced phenomena.

Read along with us : starting on p. 375 (PDF p. 408).

item.title: Ep. 365: Scheler on Love (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
We conclude our treatment of Max Scheler's The Nature of Sympathy (1922). We briefly revisit Part I to connect sympathy to love: If you love someone, you can't help but have sympathy with them when they suffer. Feeling sympathy without love, i.e. mere pity, will actually injure the pride of your object. Listen to part one first, or better yet, start with ep. 364 where we start discussing this book.

We then get into more of the text of Part II on love and hatred. Re. hatred (which we're more interested in than Scheler seems to be), Scheler's formula dictates that we're descending the ladder from higher to lower value: You see the worst in someone, and you want the worst for them, and this typically has a negative effect on both of us. But do we really hate without reason? How are love and hatred so closely related, such that someone you love can become someone you hate? Scheler does not explore these issues in any serious way.

Scheler says that love is creative, and hatred is destructive. We are essentially adding or subtracting value to our object: We make someone or something better than worse; this rather sounds like Nietzsche's "creation of values," yet not in an ungrounded way. Per Brentano, values are objective things that we discover, so love is a way of making yourself more sensitive to the goodness in someone or something, and by loving, we make that goodness manifest, adding it to the world.

Scheler clarifies that we do not in this process love goodness itself; that abstract quality is not something that can be an object of love, and in fact we are adding goodness to the world by loving, so loving the good wouldn't make sense. We in fact don't like any qualities that people have, but love their "personality," which is a curious notion in Scheler that we will explore a bit further via Closereads. "Personality" is a technical term which does not refer to the qualities people exhibit ("I love your bubbly personality."), nor does it (contra Wes on here) refer to one's abstract personhood qua membership in the human species (our "species being" per Feuerbach ). We love something that is unique to our loved object, yet it's not those tangible qualities that can change over time, but something essential about them. Scheler says it's something that we can never know directly and in full (only God can), so it must have something to do with the other person's inner life or soul, but he doesn't give us a good picture in this book of what this is and how we can relate ourselves to it. Its inaccessibility means that we treat it as irreducibly Other to ourselves, but we clearly can know it enough to love it, i.e. to note and increase its evident value.

We conclude by talking about our love for our pets. What would Scheler say?

We will talk more about how we relate to others' inner lives with our next episode , which will be on Edith Stein's On the Problem of Empathy . This was her dissertation, and came out in 1917, so she'd read the first edition of Scheler's The Nature of Sympathy (1913), but then he responded to her thoughts in his subsequent 1922 edition that we read.

item.title: Ep. 365: Scheler on Love (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
On The Nature of Sympathy (1922), Part II: “Love and Hatred.” The end of part I on fellow-feeling clarifies that we can only sympathize at the deepest level with someone if we love them, so what is love exactly, and how does it relate to ethics?

For Brentano (Scheler’s chief ethical influence), love was amoral in itself but is a component in our ethical intuitions: Something is good if we understand that we love it rightly. So love is a necessary part of the toolset we use to understand morals, but does not in itself tell us what is right (we could wrongly love a villain).

Scheler’s story is a little more subtle: Love is a primitive, spontaneous movement from lower to higher values. When you love someone, you see the best in them, and the light of receiving that love gives them power to more fully realize that excellence. It is not a statement that the loved one is valuable, but a performative that aims to climb the ladder of value, rather like in Plato’s Symposium , though Scheler has a more tolerant attitude towards sensual love. For Plato (i.e. the character of Diotima in the Symposium ), sexual desire is transformed by love into something more spiritual and ultimately not sensual at all; it’s ultimately about the love of Good. For Scheler, the goodness is not separable from the loved on in all their messy materiality.

While Scheler is dismissive of pure lust, sexual love is for him a legitimate kind of love in its own right, attempting to grasp and elevate someone in their deepest being. Scheler emphasizes that there are just fundamentally different types of love, and Freud is wrong in trying to derive motherly love, filial love, and love of home and country from the sexual (libido). Scheler also wants to allow for the possibility that we can love art or God, even though the dynamics in such love would be different, as there’s not some individual loved person that could be in any way improved by your love for it in those cases. Even in the case of love for your child, the case is a little difficult to state, though quite familiar to experience: It’s not that love is conditional, i.e. “I love the person that I think you will grow into, so if you don’t in fact grow that way, I will be disappointed and realize I was wrong,” and neither does it ignore the condition of growth, i.e. “I love you just the way you are” or “I don’t care how you develop over time.” It is a catalyst and support for good growth.

There is a limit to what we can love; he says we can love art but not food, though he does not tell us much about art to distinguish this. Spinoza said that love is just being pleased by something and attributing it the pleasure to that cause. For Scheler, this is absolutely wrong; love is fundamentally different than merely being knowingly pleased by something. Presumably, then, if I love art, I am connecting with the personal creativity in it, which he thinks is not present in food (though perhaps he should allow for gourmet food to have such a soul, whereas commercial art does does not). Suffice it to say that love of a person is the paradigm case, and so love of art or or God, or a motherly love by a woman who does not yet have children (maybe a longing for children), or a “love of love” among a romantic who does not have a partner… All these are borderline cases that tell us something about love as a dispositional attitude and not just an act aimed at a specific loved object that can potentially love you back.

Scheler emphasizes that love is always a free, spontaneous act, even when it’s in response to the other person’s love for you, or even when the loved one is very attractive. Nothing can force us to love someone or something. When we say “I love X because Y,” those reasons Y are typically post-hoc rationalizations. Likewise, hatred is a positive act and not just a reaction, and we likewise look for reasons for a hatred that is fundamentally unreasonable. (We take issue with this assertion, but unfortunately Scheler doesn’t get into enough examples of hatred to give us much specific to chew on here.)

Image by Chris Warr (aka Solomon Grundy).

item.title: Closereads: Scheler on Personhood (Audio Part One)
item.description:
Mark and Wes read through and discuss Ch. 6 "Formalism and Person," in Max Scheler's most famous work, Formalism in Ethics and Non-Formal Ethics of Values (1916). Ethical Formalism is Kant: What makes something ethically correct is just something about the type of act and willing involved. Non-formalism pays attention to the content, e.g. our sentiments (a la Hume).

As we've been studying on PEL, phenomenologists starting with Brentano sought to merge the two: Things in our experience just present themselves as intuitively praiseworthy, and this is sufficient to establish ethical obligations. We have been reading about how Scheler relies in his ethical theorizing on our experiences of sympathy and love, but we wanted to learn more about what it is about particular people that we love and respect: What is it to be a "person" in the moral sense?

This book moves very slowly, so in this part he's still just distinguishing himself from Kant when it comes to saying some basic things about your relation to your own selfhood.

Read along with us , starting on p. 370 (PDF p. 403).

item.title: Closereads: Schopenhauer on Ethics (Audio Part Two)
item.description:
Continuing on The Basis of Morality (1840), Part III: "The Founding of Ethics," Ch. 5: "Statement and Proof of the Only True Moral Incentive."

How can we actually perform moral acts given that we typically feel and so are motivated only by our own "weal and woe?" Schopenhauer insists that we can feel other people's suffering directly (interestingly, not their joy), and so the cardinal virtues are to hold our own predations (and emotional burdens) in check to refrain from harming others (the virtue of justice) and also to positively act to relieve others' suffering (the virtue of compassion). These correspond to Kantian "perfect duty" and "imperfect duty," but Schopenhauer insists that ethics is not founded on duty at all but this fundamentally emotional reaction. However, once we've established through compassion that consideration is owed to others, we should establish ethical principles, i.e. duties and other obligations, so that we continue to act morally even when we don't feel compassionate or just.

Read along with us , starting on p. 171 (PDF p. 199).

item.title: Ep. 364: Max Scheler on Sympathy (Part Three for Supporters)
item.description:
Mark, Wes, and Dylan reconvened for one more hour on Part I, "Fellow Feeling" (ch. 3-4) in The Nature of Sympathy (1913/1922). Start with part one of the discussion.

We continue to try to figure out the razor's edge of "fellow feeling proper" that does not rely on the sympathizer identifying in any way (including comparing himself to) to object of sympathy. Ch. 3 ("Genetic Theories of Fellow-Feeling") includes many psychological remarks on various phenomena by which people live through the lives of others or control them (making them identify with the master).

Ch. 4 ("Metaphysical Theories") departs from psychology to look at what monist metaphysics is posited according to identification theories like that of Schopenhauer . This whole chapter (beyond a short section about Schopenhauer) was added in the second (1922) edition of the book, and one might wonder what the point of its inclusion is here, since this is not a book of metaphysics, Scheler's phenomenological method won't let him rule definitively on one metaphysical system over another (he's just describing our experiences, not the world beyond that realm), and he's already made the point that we have to experience other people as separate in order to non-egoistically feel sympathy with them.

I don't know that I have a good answer for that, but this is the chapter where he affirms the "vital unity" between people while denying their metaphysical (spiritual) unity. In other words, we're all part of the animal kingdom, with its strivings and sexual urges and other hungers. Contra Schopenhauer, this does not include inorganic matter; we should not see the movements of gravity and electricity and such as expressions of some fundamental Will. The unity of animal life is sufficient to allow us to identify with other creatures, and it provides the fundamental herd mentality from which we then emerge as individuals (per Hegel ). Mother and in-utero child are literally the same being, and this identification between them persists to various degrees. Scheler is not denying these phenomena; he's simply saying that they do not explain fellow feeling, which (as we'll get into at the beginning of ep. 365 when we cover the final chapters of Part I) is deepest when aimed not at the external circumstances or animal desires of the other, but when aimed at the person, i.e. the spiritual core. Scheler insists that phenomenology reveals that yes, there is a unity that we can acknowledge and identify with between people on the vital level, but we are absolutely separate as spiritual beings. Each person is an unknowable Other to all others, and in fact the only way we can truly relate to this core is by reference to the one Being that has epistemic access to our innermost selves: God.

Note that this part will be shared with the public on 4/14, which will bump the release of ep. 365 to the following week. We did this to give ourselves more time to read, and because we thought that the material here was important enough that we didn't want anyone to get lost with the next ep. You can tide yourselves over by listening to the relevant Closereads episodes, including one on Husserl that sets up our Scheler treatment and another on Schopenhauer that goes into this view that Scheler is objecting to. Spoiler: We find that perhaps Schopenhauer's view is not as different from Scheler's as Scheler is characterizing it.

item.title: Closereads: Schopenhauer on Ethics (Audio Part One)
item.description:
On The Basis of Morality (1840), Part III: "The Founding of Ethics," Ch. 5: "Statement and Proof of the Only True Moral Incentive."

Everything up to this point in the book has been negative: Morality can't be founded on pure reason as Kant thinks, or on the idea of the good life (eudaimonia) per Aristotle. Schopenhauer tells us that all actions are motivated by someone's "weal" or "woe." We are naturally self-interested (motivated by own own weal and woe), but such actions will not be moral. So Schopenhauer's puzzle is: How can I be effectively motivated by someone else's weal and woe? I must somehow identify with that person so that the Other's suffering induces my compassion. This is the only source of moral value.

Read along with us , starting on p. 165 (PDF p. 193).

item.title: Ep. 364: Max Scheler on Sympathy (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
Continuing from part one on The Nature of Sympathy (1913/1922), Part I: "Fellow Feeling," Ch. 1-4. We look more closely at the text, getting further into how fellow feeling relates to ethics, and why the moral sentimentalists (like Hume ) were wrong about this.

We also get more into the types of fellow feeling, from "genuine fellow feeling" that takes the other person's mental state as your emotional object, to various kinds of identification and infection, where someone else's feelings cause feelings in you involuntarily and/or due to your considering the other person as someone unified with you. What does it mean to "share a feeling" when we experience something together? Are we not still locked off from each other in isolation, even if we are feeling qualitatively similar things and can feel comfort in that solidarity?

Scheler critiques Nietzsche's take on compassion and pity as merely immiserating everyone concerned. Nietzsche might be correct if pity were just a matter of seeing someone's suffering and "catching it" to suffer with them, but according to Scheler, this is backwards: I note that someone is suffering, and this does not make me sad; If this were to happen, I would likely just run away. Instead, my pity for the person, expressed as compassion, makes both of us feel better. (Suffering shared is suffering halved.)

We subsequently reconvened to record a part three to this episode, which you should see within the week. We'll then use ep. 365 to treat Part II of the book on love and hatred.

item.title: Ep. 364: Max Scheler on Sympathy (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
On The Nature of Sympathy (1913, expanded 1922), Part I: "Fellow Feeling," Ch. 1-4, featuring Mark, Wes, Seth, and Dylan. What is it to feel sympathy (or as Scheler repeatedly calls it "fellow feeling") for another person?

Scheler was a phenomenologist highly influenced by Husserl and his teacher Brentano , who immediately before this work had written a lengthy ethical treatise The Formalistic Principle in Ethics and the Non-Formal Ethic of Value , which argued (like Brentano) that values are real, objective, and clear within our experience. They are not equivalent to any state of feeling, so contra the "sentimentalists" Hume and Smith, ethics does not derive its validity from feelings of sympathy that we actually have.

On the contrary, ethics is prior to feelings, and allows us to judge some cases of sympathy as bad (as when we rejoice along with a villain). Moreover, we have some ethical duties to ourselves, so sociality can't be the sole origin of ethics.

This current book is thus not precisely an ethical treatise, but more an exploration of the phenomenology of how we can have fellow feeling for each other, getting into the psychology of neighboring relationships and ultimately the metaphysics that Scheler describes as underlying his opponents: Those who think that we only have fellow feeling through an act of identification with another person. I say that I in some sense am you, and so feel for you. Maybe we are part of a larger cosmic Oneness, or I simply imagine myself "in your shoes." According to Scheler, views like this reduce fellow feeling to an a priori egoism: People only value themselves, and so the only way we can extend our circle of concern is by relating others to ourselves.

Instead, Scheler argues that fellow feeling is a native ability whereby we directly relate ourselves to another person's mental state. We understand the other person's joy or sorrow, and beyond that, we feel joy or pity toward that person's emotions. This is different from being "infected" by the other person's emotions, such that I'm really still focused on my own reactions. My emotions could be quite different from yours, and I might not be able to relate directly to the thing that you are emotionally reacting to, because I haven't had that experience, can't even imagine it, and/or don't share the attraction or aversion that is driving your emotion. But I do see that you are emotional about it, and so I "feel for you." It's fundamentally a relation to another person that acknowledges that this person is irreducibly Other to me; this separation does not keep me from sympathizing with you, but on the contrary is the precondition for fellow feeling.

Buy the book or try this online version .

Image by Charles Valsechi . Edited by Sonic Hustle .

item.title: Closereads: Husserl on Perceiving Minds (Audio)
item.description:
On Edmund Husserl's Ideas, Vol. 2 (1928), Section 3, "The Constitution of the Spiritual World," Ch. 1, "Opposition Between the Naturalistic and Personalistic Worlds."

Given Husserl's method of "reduction" whereby he sets aside the metaphysical status of objects in the natural world (are they mind-independent or merely ideas?), we wanted to see how he accounts for our ability to directly perceive other people's minds. We don't just perceive their bodies and our own bodies and deduce that others must be like us, but we perceive both our minds and those of others as strata (aspects) of physical bodies.

Read along with us , starting on p. 183 (PDF p. 101).

item.title: Ep. 363: Franz Brentano's Moral Epistemology (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
Continuing from part one on "The Origin of the Knowledge of Right and Wrong" (1889), where starting on section 15, Brentano is getting into how we measure the comparative goodness of goods, actions, and purposes. We know that an action is appropriate if it fits and end we have, but how do we measure the values of ends?

Like Aristotle, Brentano looks to what we actually will as an ultimate end, i.e. eudaimonia (flourishing): the good life. We do not on reflection act ultimately in pursuit of pleasure, nor are we all hopelessly selfish.

At the same time, Brentano (still like Aristotle) wants morality to be absolute and objective, such that if in a particular society, "common sense" favors cannibalism over kindness, we can reasonably pronounce that society perverted. And Brentano provides us explanations with how some kinds of perversion can occur, such as when a miser through habit comes to see the good of money, which is inherently just a means to other goods, and a good end in itself. Perhaps, comparably, a society of extreme scarcity might develop practices out of necessity like cannibalism, infanticide, or killing old people as soon as they aren't maximally contributing, and then these come to seen as not just unfortunate emergency measures, but as expressing the vital spirit of the society, i.e. as good in themselves.

Still, there's a tension we're trying to grasp about whether moral intuition is a basic detection capability grasping a sui generis category of goodness, or whether some practice is good because it "works," i.e. whether there are non-moral criteria we can identify that explain why the detector goes off to label some things good and others bad. I think the first of these is likely correct, but that of course, the good that we detect shows signs of its goodness it does in general make things work out for us, just as it also appears beautiful to us and is (presumably) beloved by any gods that might exist, even though these latter characteristics likewise do not define goodness. As Brentano has told us, evolutionary contingencies also tend to aim societies toward the good, and non-moral prudence tends to aim individuals this way. These things do not provide ultimate moral justifications, but they do help explain why goodness is as prevalent as it is, even among those who lack solid moral intuition.

A key characteristic of moral intuitions for Brentano is that they are "summative": the good of a whole will be greater than the good of part. Summation doesn't mean that all forms of goodness can be quantified in the manner of Bentham's utilitarianism; Brentano's position is akin to Mill's, which allows that there are higher and lower pleasures that cannot be quantitatively compared (like the proverbial apples and oranges). Even among lower pleasures, how many tasty French fries is equivalent to an orgasm? The question makes no sense.

But clearly the good of one person is going to have less weight in our moral calculations than the good of many people. We can sensibly legislate based on the greatest good for the greatest number without having any sort of quantitative measure of the good for an individual. Even at the individual level, the good for me at a single moment is obviously less than the eudaimonia of a whole life. And within a conception of eudaimonia, a life with beauty and knowledge together will be superior to a life with just one of those goods. Surely we can and do make such comparisons, reflecting on relative amounts of good for ourselves and others, to determine which actions are choice-worthy.

Next episode s: We're discussing Max Scheler's The Nature of Sympathy .

item.title: Ep. 363: Franz Brentano's Moral Epistemology (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
On "The Origin of the Knowledge of Right and Wrong" (1889), featuring Mark, Wes, and Seth.

Brentano was a descriptive psychologist best known for coming up with the idea that all mental states are "intentional"; they all point at something or other. You have a believe THAT [some proposition], or you perceive [some object or state of affairs], or feel an emotion about [some situation]. This is a key idea behind the subsequent German philosophical school of phenomenology, which claims to describe our experiences in a theory-free way.

Though that framework does come up in this work, it's a lecture instead about the foundations of ethics in particular, and we're using it to kick off a series on moral phenomenology. Phenomenology in this (or any) area is supposed to be an advance from traditional rationalist and empiricist approaches. Brentano, like the rationalists Plato and Kant, believes that moral truths can be known with the same certainty as mathematical truths; they are objective. But like the empiricists Bentham and Hume, Brentano also believes that morality is given immediately in our experience: in our feelings and observations; it is not a result of some reasoned calculation like Kant's Categorical Imperative , which Brentano dismisses as a cheat and a fiction, and it's certainly not an innate idea as a Platonist might think of it. But can something given in experience offer the certainty that the rationalists were looking for? (In saying yes, Brentano was also prefiguring G.E. Moore, who both thought that everyday knowledge claims could be absolutely certain and that moral truths are intuitively given .)

Brentano is trying to make ethics properly scientific. Scientists tend to give empirical explanations, including genetic accounts of the origins of morality, e.g. it was evolutionarily advantageous for us to cooperate, political authority was psychologically internalized to become conscience, etc. While these stories may be correct as far as the development of humanity goes, they don't actually, for Brentano, provide justification for moral claims. Instead, if we've become by whatever mechanism the kids of creatures to rationally evaluate our situations, these claims are just given to us as evidently true. We can all rationally see, just as we can see that 2+2=4 or that the law of non-contradiction holds, that the good of the many is greater than the good of the few. We can likewise be sure that knowledge is better than ignorance, joy is better than suffering, and so helping people is better than hurting them. The fact that some incompetent, savage, or degraded people might not be able to see this doesn't undercut the evident validity of these facts. The course of evolution and culture has on the whole made us into the kinds of creatures who are open to rational intuition of this sort, but they have not determined what we learn through moral insight, and so a different sort of conditioning wouldn't change these moral facts; it would just make us blind to them.

Brentano acknowledges that different rules rightly apply in different societies with different cultural circumstances, but insists that the basic moral principles underlying all of them are universal, that we are all by nature oriented toward the good and apt to come up with the same foundational moral judgments no matter what (sufficiently mature) society we are born into.

Brentano's task then becomes distinguishing between those principles actually given to us by rational intuition from other principles that we simply find ourselves compelled to believe, e.g. through personal habit or acculturation). In the area of general epistemology, we find ourselves naturally compelled to believe when we see a physical object that the object is there, in the external world. But philosophy reveals that this is not something we should be certain about. Per Descartes, we can be certain that there is some content to consciousness, but not that this corresponds to something in the external world. In the area of moral epistemology, we can be sure about fundamental abstract principles, but not about how to best apply them in real situations, when we might be wrong about the facts. For instance, gratitude is always a fitting response to generosity, but how can I tell that someone is actually being generous in this case?

So certain judgments have the character in our experience of "rightness" (not unlike for Descartes they can have the character of clarity and distinctness), and in the moral realm, certain loves have the character that we are rightly loving. Whereas for moral sentimentalism (Hume or Smith), the very fact of our having affection for something is prima facie evidence for its goodness, and all judgments of goodness ultimately have to be founded on real sentiments by real people (compared to each other to make them consistent and rational), Brentano thinks that we are well aware that some of our affections and desires present themselves as "lower" and some as "higher," intrinsically inferior or superior, so, for example, we can tell that the pursuit of pleasure, even though this is someone everyone experiences, is not intrinsically valuable, and certainly not as morally good as the pursuit of meaning.

Read the lecture .

Image by Chris Warr (aka Solomon Grundy).

item.title: Ep. 362: Ecclesiastes: Biblical Existentialism? (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
Continuing from part one on Ecclesiastes with guest Jesse Peterson, getting into some more close reading of particular sections. We make some connection from the author's observations to ancient Greek Skepticism, Epicureanism, and Stoicism. How is the world "absurd" according to this book; is this the same claim we get later from Camus ?

Qhoheleth considers the life of pleasure, great accomplishments, and even the philosophical life, and considers them all absurd. At the same time, there are benefits in this life to having wisdom, and we do have the capacity to orient ourselves intelligently given our limitations. Still, this seems overshadowed by the fact of death and the injustice that whatever you accomplish, you can't enjoy it beyond the grave, and inevitably your legacy will be mismanaged, ruined, and forgotten. Given this crushing eventuality, we might as well enjoy our work without an eye for what it accomplishes.

Next time : We're discussing Franz Brentano's lecture “The Origin of the Knowledge of Right and Wrong ” (1889).

item.title: Ep. 362: Ecclesiastes: Biblical Existentialism? (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
Ecclesiastes is often cited as one of the most philosophical books of the Bible, so we approached it in that spirit with the help of Jesse M. Peterson from George Fox University , whose soon-to-be-published book is called Qoheleth and the Philosophy of Value .

First, who is Qoheleth? It’s the Hebrew word typically translated as teacher or preacher (liberally “gatherer” or “assembler,” as in assembling people together to preach to them), which is how the book identifies the purveyor of wisdom in the book. The book also, however, gives details about this person’s life that uniquely pick out the Israelite King Solomon (10th century BCE), so in Bible studies courses, they’ll usually say this is who wrote the book (also purportedly the author of Proverbs and Song of Songs). However, aspects of the language used make it clear to scholars that Ecclesiastes was written much later (maybe 250 BCE), so we should just consider the authorship anonymous.

The book as a whole is highly nihilistic, rejecting daily human work and even the endeavors of powerful, free people as “hebel,” which is often translated as “vanity” but more closely means fleeting (literally “vapor”), meaningless, absurd, or futile. Even the famous verses about there being a time for everything under heaven is not expressing a peaceful sentiment about everything in its due time; it’s mourning the fact that anything good that anyone accomplishes is just going to get undone eventually. The traditional Biblical interpretation of the book is that, yes, this nihilism does follow if you’re only looking to the secular world (“everything under the sun”) for comfort, but God’s supernatural presence makes it all better. For various reasons we get into in the podcast, this is probably a bad reading: Scholars are pretty sure that the end of the book that most directly makes this point was added by a later author to make the whole thing more palatable. Though the existence of God is not in question in the text, and there are positive points within it that urge us to enjoy the time we’ve been given (by God), these elements are already taken into account when the world is judged as hebel.

What makes this particularly existential is the emphasis on death: Whatever great deeds you accomplish, you’re just going to die, and everyone who might remember you will die to, so it’s ultimately all for nothing. Importantly, there’s no indication in the book that yes, actually you and many others will live on in heaven, so we just need to get through this temporary, meaningless life to get to where it’ll all be made right.

So we all die, and the author’s reaction to this says something about how death is considered to be a harm and what would make life meaningful, if anything could, i.e. if our accomplishments could make a lasting social impact, which clearly this author’s did, even if we don’t know who he was! But according to the text, it would still be a point of annoyance with him that we future people now own his text when we didn’t work to create it, and undoubtedly we’ll for the most part muck it up in translating, interpreting, and trying to apply its wisdom to our lives.

Read the NRSV Bible version of Ecclesiastes that we read . Jesse’s book is forthcoming and looks to be priced strictly for academic library purchases , but maybe you can recommend that your library get a copy. We concentrated on ch. 2 and 3 of that book, the first of which had to do with “hebel” and draws heavily on an article Jesse recommends: “The Meaning of Hebel for Qohelet ” by Michael V. Fox (1986). Ch. 3 went through different theories on why death is bad. Jesse’s later chapters talked more about the positive messages in Ecclesiastes, but we didn’t read those, so our take remains pessimistic.

Image by Chris Warr (aka Solomon Grundy).

item.title: Ep. 361: Marx on Machines (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
To conclude our Marx treatment, we continue from part one , finally getting into his "Fragment on Machines" (1858). Shouldn't automating work free the workers? No! According to Marx, the (then-current) process of automation actually just makes labor conditions worse and certainly doesn't give people more free time, as the capitalist inevitably takes all the gains from greater productivity.

We talk machines vs. instruments, why mechanization is inevitable according to Marx, the relation of machines to social knowledge, and how AI might fit into all of this, and more.

Next episode , we're discussing Ecclesiastes, the Biblical book written around 250 BCE by an unknown author who presents himself (or his main narrator) as King Solomon.

item.title: Ep. 361: Marx on Machines (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
Yet more time spent on Karl Marx finishes up our treatment of Capital , Ch. 1, and throws in the mix "Fragment on Machines" (1858), which we'll discuss explicitly in part two of this. You should probably listen to our Marx series first, starting with ep. 359 .

In Capital , we finally get to the little bit that Marx says about actual communism, where there are no commodities (just as there aren't under feudalism or within a family structure); there's production, but not for the purpose of money exchange. Marx is so tight-lipped about this because he is wary of utopian thinking, despite communism being reputed as a type of utopianism.

So we have to think through some issues ourselves: Is sophisticated manufacturing even possible without capital, and is (problematic ) central planning required? Would getting rid of capitalism actually change our understanding of ourselves, such that we would voluntarily cooperate and not just lazily mooch off the system (because we're driven by appetite) or compete even more fiercely with others (because we're driven by thymos)?

Read "Fragment on Machines" online .

item.title: Closereads: Marx on Stirner (Audio Part Three)
item.description:
Concluding on Marx's "The German Ideology" (1846), now giving Marx's positive alternative to Max Stirner's account of the self-delusion of ordinary folks. Whereas Stirner thinks they have this false dichotomy between selfishness (bad) and selflessness (good) and should instead embrace enlightened self-interest as good, Marx thinks that all these ideas are a result of economic circumstances, i.e. ideology. Consequently Stirner can't, according to Marx, truly understand communism.

Read along with us , starting on p. 264 (PDF p. 260).

item.title: Closereads: Marx on Stirner (Audio Part Two)
item.description:
Continuing on the part of Marx's "The German Ideology" (1846) on Max Stirner's distinction between mere, common selfishness and Stirner's enlightened selfishness, and how the idea of selflessness is a mere illusion for both thinkers, but for different reasons.

item.title: Ep. 360: Karl Marx on Economic Value (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
On Capital (1867), Ch. 1, "The Commodity." This continues our discussion in our last episode introducing Marx's economic project. So how does one begin to explain a holistic system? Marx chooses to start with wealth, i.e. the thing Adam Smith was trying to explain in The Wealth of Nations , and wealth, for Marx, is represented in the commodity: stuff that we buy and sell.

So what makes a commodity valuable? Clearly, we each have different needs, and so a particular commodity will have different values for each of us (a different "use value"), but in the aggregate, the overall need for something as expressed in the willingness of someone to pay a certain amount for it determines its exchange value, and in this way, even though the uses of, e.g. a bunch of grapes and an iphone are different, we can measure the exchange value of one (at a given time in a given market) in terms of the other, and ultimately, we use a third thing, money, as the medium for making it obvious that any commodity can (in the right quantity) be in effect traded for any other.

So does this mean that value as abstracted over different consumers is just entirely a matter of demand, that commodities have no economic value in themselves? No, this is the error that Marx things political economists have fallen into. Marx thinks we need to look beneath the commodity into its production and locates its value in the labor that went into it. This is the "labor theory of value": Even though many things can be useful without any labor (you go out in your yard and the trees are just teeming with fruit waiting to be plucked), if something is a commodity, the difficulty of getting that fruit (or whatever) to market, and so the underlying value of that commodity, is a matter of how much effort it takes.

Marx makes it immediately clear that this not a matter of how much labor an individual producer puts in, such that someone weaker and slower has to put in more labor and so creates a more valuable product. Instead, Marx talks about the "socially necessary labor" that typically goes into a type of product, which is an average across producers. So if one producer is more efficient (e.g. gets a fruit-picking machine), that provides a temporary advantage for that producer, but typically any such innovation will spread through the industry, and so a new equilibrium will be reached.

This idea of socially necessary labor grounds his notion (not in this chapter) of surplus value: X hours are needed for a worker of average ability in a given industry to produce enough of a commodity to pay for his own salary, and everything beyond that is surplus, which ideally should be shared between the capitalist and the worker, but in practice goes entirely to the capitalist, and in fact the capitalist will make the worker work as many more hours as possible beyond that necessary labor amount to increase the capitalist's share. This is his fundamental critique: Capitalists are incentivized to exploit workers to maximize the return on investment. This means that even if a capitalist is very socially aware and generous in his private dealings, the majority of the way that his life concretely affects people is through this exploitation. We think we're just looking at business, at the market, at "what makes the world go round," but this "commodity fetishism" makes us overlook the laborers providing the value that makes commodities possible, and justice demands that the exploitation stop.

Read Capital online .

Image by Chris Warr (aka Solomon Grundy).

item.title: Ep. 359: Karl Marx's Project (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
We continue from part one on the introduction to the Grundrisse (1857), which is essentially a set of notes written in the composition of his major work, Capital , which we'll deal with explicitly in ep. 360.

What exactly is universal and natural about our economic patterns, and what is a matter of historical epoch? Marx claims we can't just see the distribution of goods and a historical accident but then see production and consumption as natural. Instead, all of these things are related, with the means of production aligning with (not "determining"; the causality is as of parts within a system) how people consume and how goods are distributed to them. Private property is not as Locke saw it something natural, rooted in our control of our own bodies, but is specific to capitalism: Our relationship to our bodies, or to our personal possessions (my clothes, my home), and the sort of ownership that people within a family or tribe have to their belongings, is different than our modern take on private property, where the state backs private ownership of even vast things, and no matter how much you use a resource (e.g. Locke theorized that land becomes owned when one works it), that doesn't give you any legal right to it if it started as someone else's. Key to modern private property is the idea that everything owned is potentially exchangeable, and so convertible into a government-backed currency.

How are production and consumption related in capitalism? A worker needs to consume (e.g. food and clothing) in order to be alive to produce, and what is produced creates consumers (including that same worker) who are adapted to consume certain products. So producers are consumers and vice versa; we are related to ourselves in these two roles via the mediation of exchange with others; this is essentially Hegel's story of self-consciousness, turned from something having to do with mind (I recognize myself through your recognition of me) into something having to do with people's actions, whatever those people might think of them.

Were I putting songs at the ends of these episodes still, "The Way it Is " by Nakedly Examined Music guest Bruce Hornsby would be my selection: The inequalities and economic patterns of our present are neither given by nature, nor are they unchangeable!

item.title: Ep. 359: Karl Marx's Project (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
On the introduction to Marx's Grundrisse , aka Foundations of a Critique of Political Economy (1857) with an appetizer of "Theses on Feuerbach" (1845). This is the first of three discussions we'll be having on Marx's "mature" work, and we were also assigned the first chapter (and introduction and 2nd edition afterward) of his Capital (1867), though we're not going to get around to talking about that much until ep. 360.

To transition us from Marx's earlier work influenced by Feuerbach , we start with this very short bullet-list paper that argues that Feuerbach, by continuing to write about religion and the life of the mind, is still being too abstract, whereas Marx was shifting his focus entirely to economics, and his goal was both to write a theoretical treatise that would improve on the analyses of earlier political economists, but also to make a real difference in the world.

These two goals were of course not unrelated. Though Marx had a great deal of respect for Adam Smith and David Ricardo, he characterized the followers of these economists as mere mouthpieces for business concerns. In Capital , Marx aimed to show that most of the wealth we possess comes directly from labor (the "labor theory of value," invented by Smith and developed by Ricardo), and that yet capitalists are incentivized to pay as little as possible to workers for their labor. According to his analysis, laborers typically produce value equivalent to their wages in just a few hours, and the rest of their day is spent creating surplus value, all of which goes to the capitalist. Marx saw this situation as fundamentally unjust and ultimately unsustainable.

A key element in this critique (and a difference Marx seems to see between himself and Feuerbach) is historical perspective. Capitalist economists starting with Smith (and even back to the Greeks) see division of labor and consequent trade as a natural part of being human, and the economy as essentially an outgrowth of nature. Marx argues that most of supposed natural economic laws are merely laws reflecting the logic of the particular historical moment of capitalism. So for instance, the idea of a social contract (Hobbes, Locke, Rousseau) presupposes that there are isolated, self-contained individuals who join together in political and economic activity, whereas Marx argues that this view of individualism reflects the situation of serfs recently freed from a collapsed feudal order, ready to then engage in "free" contracts of employment. Marx instead follows Hegel in seeing ancient humanity as a herd-like mass, with societies established by acts of domination, and economic exchange not coming into play originally between individuals, who are instead units within families and/or master/slave situations, but between such groups.

To present a picture of real-world economic dynamics that would help us to direct practical reforms is fundamentally different than the normative ideal-building that philosophy traditionally engages in. Marx describes this erection of ideals, even when done using strictly secular means, as self-alienating. Simply saying that capitalists ought to be more compassionate or that workers should adopt Stoic ethics is a hopeless strategy for achieving change in worker's material conditions.

In the Grundrisse , Marx gives us a systems approach to economics, where production, consumption, distribution, and exchange are all part of the same process, and so can't be studied in isolation, as (he alleges) other economists are doing by focusing on supply and demand (i.e. exchange). Still, however, Marx tells us that production is the primary moment of this unified process; we'll go into why in part two of this discussion.

Read "Theses on Feuerbach" online here and the Grundrisse here .

Image by Charles Valsechi . Edited by Sonic Hustle .

item.title: Ep. 358: Max Stirner's Egoism (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
Continuing from part one on The Ego and Its Own , focusing now on the sections "The Owner" and "My Power." Stirner lets us know that his egoism ("ownness") is not compatible with liberal egalitarianism, which he sees as just a continuation of the Christian project of perfecting humanity. He calls liberalism the religion of free states.

The humanist emphasis on what Feuerbach and Marx (following Kant) called "species being" is to Stirner just an unwarranted focus on one property that we have, our species, which is less important to us than our unique qualities. As a proto-existentialist, Stirner does not believe that there is a thing called human nature. My ownness, my activity, determines my being.

Anticipating Nietzsche and Freud, Stirner says that society goes against our instinctual nature and typically damages us as individuals. For Stirner, the notion of "right" is fundamentally social, not a way of protecting individuality but a cage for it. We only really have a right to what we have power over, because there is no God or other agency that endows us with rights; we have to claim them ourselves. This all sounds like a state of nature argument, but without the idea that a social contract is a good escape from it. We never escape from it.

So what positive vision comes out of this? It's hard to tell, and that was frustrating. Let us know what you think!

Next Episode : For eps. 359-360, we're returning to Marx, reading the introduction to the Grundrisse (1857) and the first bits of Das Kapital (1867).

item.title: Ep. 358: Max Stirner's Egoism (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
Continuing our trip through Marx and his influences, Wes, Dylan, and Seth read The Ego and its Own (1844), also translated as The Unique and its Property . Max Stirner was the pen name of Johann Kaspar Schmidt, and he went farther than Feuerbach in rejecting the status quo of a society driven by religion and traditional morality, prefiguring Nietzsche (though Nietzsche was aware of Stirner, there's no evidence that he read this book). After giving an overview, we mainly concentrate here on a section of the book called "Ownness."

He explicitly embraces a "might makes right" philosophy against the Christian tradition and equally rejects socialism and communism, sort of like an early Ayn Rand. His ideal is someone focused on "ownness" (i.e. egoism), which sounds like a precursor to Nietzsche's Overman, though a more nihilistic version of this (no living artistically).

Like Feuerbach, Stirner critically traces the history of philosophy through idealism to Hegel and rejects these latter developments of failing to escape the flaws of Christianity itself. But by embracing "species being," Feuerbach is on Stirner's account still a crypto-theologian, placing "Man" as fundamentally transcendent ideal above individuals. Unlike the social contract tradition that describes political life as an achievement of civilized humanity, Stirner argues that our excellence as human beings is to grow beyond our social (herdlike) origins. Even though the result is anarchism, he doesn't argue for this on the basis of personal freedom, he thinks is a notion that is actually derivative of moral right. It's not enough to be merely free from interference; we want to be owners . Being free in a liberal society really means being obedient to the law, so that everyone can be free of others' incursions. Freedom is only worth something, for Stirner, if you've earned it through exertion of your own power. To really be an egoist, you'll be a criminal, an enemy of the state without concern for others' rights. So basically, in rejecting the tyranny of morality, he's embracing the position of Thracymachus in Plato's Republic . "Justice" or any other word referring to the good of the collective is just nonsense; there's just us as individuals with our individual interests.

In the sections we read, he doesn't go into what this post-justice society would look like, but he says that animals don't need a government, so we shouldn't either. We also don't get much of a "therapy of desire" approach where we can use the book to optimize how we order and regulate our own wishes. Instead, we get a lot of negative talk about weaklings who are controlled by "conscience." A strong person will use the means at his disposal to get what he wants (which presumably includes violence, though again, he doesn't explicitly address this).

Read the book online . Here are the specific sections we read:

- All things are nothing to me (p. 5-7)
- First Part
- A human life: (13-18)
- The men of old and new
- The moderns intro (27-30)
- The Free: Human liberalism (111-129)
- Second Part
- Page 139 (intro to second part)
- Ownness (141-154)
- The Owner (155-166)
- My Power (166-187)
- The Unique One (320-324)

Image by Chris Warr (aka Solomon Grundy).

item.title: PEL ’24-’25 Transition Nightcap
item.description:
Recorded on 12/21/24, Mark, Wes, Seth, and Dylan reflect on our past year of PEL recording, catch you up on our habits and interests, and talk about what might come next. Happy Holidays and thanks for your support!

Our strategy here was just to look through our list of episodes starting in January when we were finishing up Kierkegaard, then worked our way through Aristotle, re-visited two types of non-Western philosophy, and more. We get into many of our ongoing concerns such as how much secondary literature we should be reading, whether we should do interviews, whether people like how we’re now dwelling longer on single works/authors instead of just hitting it once and moving on. How has Closereads bled into PEL? What did Mark discover in teaching Big Books in Continental Philosophy this fall that can redirect PEL’s selections? How do people’s varying work schedules and general business affect our tolerance for certain authors? Are we getting more nihilistic as we age, and how should you pronounce “nihilism,” anyway?

We conclude by talking about politics given that we hadn’t weighed in on the election since it happened. What could we read in the future that would help us make sense of what’s going on now?

Also, RIP Eva Brann , one of our favorite guests .

Scheduling note : We recorded this after Stirner, but we’re taking up a full week of our release schedule to make this publicly available, which means the Stirner discussion you might be waiting for will instead go up closer to next week. You can tide yourself over by listening to the latest Closereads , and maybe just start reading Plato’s Death of Socrates dialogues in preparation for the first session of Mark’s Core Texts in Philosophy class . The latest Pretty Much Pop on Santa Claus was strangely philosophical, in a fun way. The latest Philosophy vs. Improv features a long-sought philosophy guest , though perhaps not discussing the most philosophical topic in the most philosophical way.

item.title: Ep. 357: Feuerbach on the Evolution of Philosophy (Part Three for Supporters)
item.description:
A week after our final public discussion of Feuerbach’s “Principles of the Philosophy of the Future," Mark, Wes, and a re-joining Seth met to talk about sections 23-28 of the essay, which detail Feuerbach's case against Hegel.

Interestingly, F argues that Hegel's treatment of everything, including God, as Idea is given right in the ontological argument: If God's existence is proven by His causation of the idea of God in us, that means God is in the realm of the Idea.

F finds the notion of God as idea just grasping everything else as also ideas inadequate. There has to be something fundamentally other than God (or Subject generally) that the Subject grasps for the whole relation to have any substance. Only sensuousness (matter) can provide the contrast needed.

However, the result is not an insistence on mind-matter dualism, but on moving everything, including God, into the category of sensuous matter. Because objects (many objects, anyway) have forms (it's a dog or a sphere or whatever), this counts in that object as a logos, i.e. mentality. This sounds very much like functionalism in modern philosophy of mind: Thinking or consciousness is not some special mental substance, but a form of organization and activity in matter, so certain complex organizations of matter will count as mind, which can then recognize likeness in each other (Man recognizing himself and others as species being) and/or grasp each other as objects. When a human senses another human, we get both of these things: the grasping of an objectified Other which in turn enables a recognition of the common species and a consequent enrichment of self-knowledge: You are a person and so I am too!

But do we really want to say with F that every object is in fact a subject? Even if we don't want to say that a ball, because it's round, literally has a mind (something that determines the lawlike character of its roundness), F still may be a panpsychist: the ball qua being in space and time has a "perspective" on me and everything else around it, and these raw perspectives are the proto-conscious elements in his metaphysics that allows us to eventually have full-on consciousness. ...Or maybe we're reading all these modern ideas into F, and his metaphysics is simply underbaked!

item.title: Ep. 357: Feuerbach on the Evolution of Philosophy (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
We finally discuss Feuerbach's proposed new (post-Hegelian) approach to philosophy in his “Principles of the Philosophy of the Future” (1843). Listen to part one first, and probably before that, ep. 356 .

It probably doesn't sound that "futuristic" to us to claim that "My philosophy actually deals with real things in the world, with matter, whereas the old philosophy was just mind eating itself!" But the point here is to see how the dominance of idealism in Germany could have led then to figures like Marx and Nietzsche. We still get much more negation-of-the past in this Feuerbach essay than we get specific, positive philosophical assertions about justice, truth, and other traditional philosophical concerns.

Matter is something that must act as a limit on a knower. This is the basic phenomenological insight: Every perception is of something , and this something can't be just the same as the perceiver or the perceiving act. Even when thinking of a mathematical equation, its truth is something objective, independent of a person thinking it. According to F, if both the thinker and the mathematical object were just "thought," the two wouldn't really be distinguished, so materialism (as F understands it) must be just given right there in the phenomenology of perception and even thought. Concluding based on this that a mathematical truth must be fundamentally material seems a bit slipshod, but this is the clearest F gets about this.

Though F does not actually talk about math here, he does talk about the self, about love, and other intangibles as things that we directly sense. One might think that love is abstract, that it's conceptually loaded, but F claims that there's an immediately sensible core that presumably even animals without concepts can grasp, and F refers to "genius" as the ability to grasp (and convey) profound things in an immediate way.

Finally, he describes the fundamental thing we sense is "here-being," which means that sensing something as real means sensing it in a particular place. So not only is space (which implies matter as opposed to nebulous "spirit") central, so space in relation to you the perceiver, i.e. place. So F is again prefiguring a phenomenologist like Heidegger (and earlier Bergson) by prioritizing subjective space (and time) over the kind of space and time that science uses, where space is cut into standard, equal increments and no position in space is privileged. In sum, by insisting that reality is fundamentally sensuous, F transforms the idea of what it is to be sensuous to include a richer notion of reality than the one associated with philosophers like Descartes, Locke, and Hume, preparing the way for this move to be articulated by the phenomenologists 50+ years later.

Next episode: We're reading selections from The Ego and Its Own (1844) by Max Stirner, another key influence on Karl Marx, whom we'll get back to with ep. 359.

item.title: Ep. 357: Feuerbach on the Evolution of Philosophy (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
We’re continuing to look at Ludwig Feuerbach’s essay “Principles of the Philosophy of the Future” (1843). Now past his critique of theology in our last episode , Mark, Wes, and Dylan address F’s account of the history of philosophy from theism to pantheism to idealism to Hegelianism, and finally to F’s own “philosophy of the future,” which is a materialism that naturally flows out as the correction of Hegel’s system.

In a very Hegelian manner, F posits each of these stages as a corrective on the preceding. If traditional theologians really understood what they were doing and wanted to make their notion of God as all-encompassing consistent, then they’d make it include nature a la Spinoza’s pantheism. If Spinoza really knew what he was doing, then he’d have incorporated Hegel’s insight that God should be the Subject of experience and not just a special kind of object that has mentality as one of its aspects. And if Hegel really knew what he was doing, he’d realize that by making matter itself part of an all-encompassing Subject, then you’ve removed the distinction between matter and mind and should instead of calling the whole system Spirit (mind), just acknowledge that you’re talking fundamentally about matter: God (i.e. everything) is material, or more precisely sensual.

He doesn’t want to define matter a la Descartes as essentially extension, as this would be an abstraction. Matter is instead whatever it is that we sense in its wholeness on a daily basis, including things like love. Feuerbach doesn’t really explain what this means metaphysically, e.g. for the philosophy of mind (How are “ideas” matter? Because they’re brain states?). He does make it clear that there must be real multiplicity for relationships (e.g. between God and creation) to be meaningful; God can’t just be thinking Himself as is the case on Hegel’s account. If when a mind grasps some bit of matter, it’s just mind grasping mind, then the whole thing would lack reality, vanishing in metaphysical smoke.

Feuerbach’s sensual “philosophy of the future” strikes us as proto-phenomenological, in that the world that our senses take in is not the bare appearances of empiricists like Locke and Hume (e.g. a swatch of red), but is more holistic, including cultural matters. We sense (experience) the world as included and shaped by other people, nature as a home. We do not just experience sense-data and have to make conclusions about the real existence of entities causing those data, but we experience real entities in the a world that we are inextricably embedded in (yes, F prefigures Heidegger’s being-in-the-world).

We discuss that new, alternative philosophy (the end of the essay) in part two of this discussion, then we reconvened (minus Dylan, plus Seth) later for a part three recording to cover in depth F’s specific critique of Hegel (which comes at the end of this history-of-philosophy story).

Image by Charles Valsechi . Edited by Sonic Hustle .
