item.title: Ep. 356: Feuerbach Against Theology (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
We dig in and start our detailed treatment of Ludwig Feuerbach’s essay “Principles of the Philosophy of the Future” (1843). Hear our overview in part one . This is a very long essay, so we'll continue going through its various sections in ep. 357.

In this discussion, we largely keep to his critique of theology, which are the first 11 (out of 65) sections. Feuerbach claims that people don't realize that the entity they worship is really just whatever it is about humanity and the world that we value, wrongly posited as an independent entity. So God is a mirror for any given society: We depict what we take to be the essence of the human condition, the perfection of whatever we see to be our most distinctive qualities, whether that be love or justice or physical strength or whatever. While this sounds like (and Feuerbach describes it as) anthropology, he seems to want to retain what's good about religion: He wants us to worship, particularly through the medium of other people, and to value what's great about ourselves. This is also the time of Emerson , so the notion that we should all celebrate ourselves as divine was in the air; Feuerbach is perhaps just a bit more honest about this sort of view being atheistic when seen from the traditional point of view.

item.title: Ep. 356: Feuerbach Against Theology (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
On Ludwig Feuerbach’s essay “Principles of the Philosophy of the Future” (1843) as well as the introduction to his book The Essence of Christianity (1841). Featuring Mark, Wes, Dylan, and Seth.

Feuerbach is known primarily for his early influence on Karl Marx. Conventional wisdom has it that Marx took elements of Hegel (e.g. his historical determinism) but rejected Hegel's emphasis on ideas in favor of concrete historical conditions. Feuerbach was also a critic of Hegel and gave Marx some of the key terms in his early work such as "species being."

We're breaking our treatment of this figure into two discussions. In this first one, we talk about Feuerbach's revolution in religion, wherein he transforms it into anthropology. Though we have some disagreement about whether to call F. an atheist (as Marx surely was), he was expressly against theology: traditional types of religion that externalize God, and this God is then analyzed by theologians to try to make it make sense. F. describes religion as an authentic activity in the childhood of humanity whereby we take whatever it is we value (chiefly about ourselves, but also about nature and other things) and externalize it into an object of worship. So you can tell a lot about the values of a society by the character of its gods. F. of course wants us to keep on valuing appropriate things, and approves of the passion and dedication that go into religious practice, but he wants us to pierce the fundamental illusion of religion that this object of worship is anything other than the sensible world, including and especially ourselves.

So religion is basically an emotional act, and philosopher/theologians just make religion less religious by trying to make their idea of God rational. Monotheism itself reflects an intolerant, jealous disposition, and F. saw Judaism as an egoistic elevation of the believing community. All faith is putting a litmus test of belief above the moral qualities (love) that should really be the focus of Christianity. So already the religion that Medieval and modern philosophy are dealing with is highly flawed. In attempting to get over the superstition of common believers, theological philosophers like Maimonides and Aquinas stress that God is so great that He doesn't have any properties that we could understand; we can only truly speak of what He is not. For F., this removes the guts of religion; we're now no longer worshipping the best in humanity but an abstract nothing. The "philosopher's God" of Descartes, et al., is just defined abstractly as "the greatest possible being" and "the first cause of the universe." Against these views, F. praises the move of Spinoza to metaphysically rejoin our world with the Divine, and further praises Hegel for making Spinoza's God-as-Nature back into a thinking Subject, still somehow merged with us as in Spinoza's picture. So Hegel's religious philosophy, on F.'s account, is the best that philosophy has offered us modern people so far, but F. criticizes Hegel as wrongly seeing sensuous matter as just part of this world of Divine Thought. Actually, we should see this whole complex (God and world) as necessarily material, because only something that exists at a time and place with real properties actually exists at all.

So the end result is that we can think of ourselves as still religious (or "spiritual") in a loose sense, but our action should be directed at real people in the real world. It's this latter part that Marx ran with in devising his world-helping, thoroughly materialist system.

So what does this materialism mean for interpreting, for instance, mathematics? Feuerbach presages phenomenology in expanding the idea of experienced sensuous reality to include meanings, universals, and social entities.

Both of these selections are contained in The Fiery Brook: Selected Writings . Read the main essay online .

Image by Chris Warr (aka Solomon Grundy).

Learn about Mark's spring Core Texts in philosophy class at partiallyexaminedlife.com/class.

item.title: Ep. 355: Marx on Alienation (Part Three for Supporters)
item.description:
Your four hosts reconvene to talk more about "Private Property and Communism" (1844). Listen to parts one and two first.

After some comments about the relation between property, labor, and capital, Marx distinguishes his view from the "crude communism" of his contemporaries (e.g. Proudhon): Just getting rid of private property in favor of communal ownership won't fix a fundamentally messed up relationship we have towards things. We want to fix our relationship with nature, which would involve fixing alienation.

Finally, we get more of a picture of how humans would change under this new system: We would be acting in an authentically social manner, involving species being, i.e. self-consciousness.

item.title: Closereads: Sartre on Nothingness (Audio Part Four)
item.description:
We conclude our present treatment of Part One of Being and Nothingness, finishing ch. 3, "The Dialectical Concept of Nothingness," on Sartre vs. Hegel. Sartre concludes that Nothingness is parasitic upon yet conceptually and metaphysically separate from Being. The second half of our session tries to put this in perspective: What is phenomenological ontology, and how does it relate to pre-Kantian metaphysics?

Read along with us , starting on p. 47, i.e. PDF p. 98.

item.title: Closereads: Sartre on Nothingness (Audio Part Three)
item.description:
We continue reading Part One of Being and Nothingness, finishing ch. 2, "Negations," and starting ch. 3, "The Dialectical Concept of Nothingness." Sartre argues that non-being is not a product of human judgment, but something we discover, objectively in our world amidst being. In Ch. 3, he contrasts his view with that of Hegel, who argued that Being and Nothingness are basically identical, in that they are part of the same concept, introduced at the same time (like two sides of a coin or yin/yang).

Read along with us , starting on p. 42, i.e. PDF p. 93.

item.title: Ep. 355: Marx on Alienation (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
Continuing from part one on "Estranged Labor," "Private Property and Communism," and "The Power of Money on Bourgeois Society" with guest Lawrence Dallman.

So humanity is the working animal: the kind of productive work that we do--fed by feeling, expressing our capabilities, meeting our needs--is our essential nature, so we'd better be doing it in a way that doesn't mess us up!

One of Marx's points is that alienation is the root problem; it's not capitalism or private property or greedy bosses that give rise to alienation, but alienation gives rise to all those other things. Alienation might even be an inevitable historical development, in that our nature is to work, and efficiency of division of labor is going to give rise to these alienated work situations, even before capitalism comes on the scene. Even more radically, arguably for Marx, the very fact that work creates an external product at all means it's already alienated: we have externalized part of ourselves into a product that by its very separateness is likely to become something alien.

Another point Marx makes is that a necessary part of full-bore alienation is that the worker is oppressed not merely by the need to provide for his needs, i.e. by nature, but by another person: the capitalist. Is this really essential given the way I've characterized alienation above?

We finish up by considering a couple of Marx's arguments against other socialist thinkers who he thinks don't really solve the problem of alienation. A good sign of how we're doing as a society in that respect is how relations between men and women are typically structured: Are these fulfilling for all parties, or fundamentally exploitative?

In the supporter-only part three of this discussion, we get deep into the text of Marx's positive account psychology post-alienation in "Private Property and Communism."

For ep. 356 : We'll be discussing Ludwig Feuerbach's “Principles of the Philosophy of the Future” (1843), and the introduction to his book The Essence of Christianity (1841).

item.title: Ep. 355: Marx on Alienation (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
On three of Karl Marx's Economic and Philosophic Manuscripts of 1844 , "Estranged Labor," "Private Property and Communism," and "The Power of Money on Bourgeois Society." The full foursome are joined by returning guest Lawrence Dallman , who now teaches at Bryn Mawr College.

What exactly is the plight of the poor? It's not just that they don't have money, says Marx, and while the institution of money adds a particular flavor of dehumanization to our world, Marx argues (against other social theorists of his time) that even getting rid of all private property wouldn't address the root of the problem, which is human alienation from our work. If you take the initiative to create something, using your own resources, and you get to enjoy the result (whether we're talking about food or shoes or artworks), then that's great. When your instead sell your labor, aren't a full participant in the creative process, and you don't own either the product or the tools you're using to make it, then that's bad.

Marx (following Hegel) describes our relationship to ourselves as mediated by the objects we work on, so while creating authentically allows us to externalize something of ourselves that we can then look upon and understand ourselves, creating something in an alienated manner doesn't do this, and in fact we lose contact with (are alienated from) ourselves. Also, this relationship of boss to worker and even those between workers are degraded by this relationship; we're alienated from real social relationships that would, again, serve to help us reflect on ourselves and so develop ourselves as individuals. Using a term from Feuerbach (whom we'll cover in ep. 355), Marx says that what makes us human is our awareness of our "species-being," our essence as humanity. Animals don't have this, and if we sell all of our time into this inflexible system that isolates us, then we are reduced to the level of animals.

Image by Genevieve Arnold. Audio editing by The Podcast Doctors .

item.title: Closereads: Sartre on Nothingness (Audio Part Two)

We get some context and then jump into the classic question of whether existence in itself is just pure being, such that nothingness is just a result of human judgments on it, or whether nothingness is something objective that we grasp. We end by introducing the famous "absent Pierre in the café" example.

item.title: Ep. 354: Guest Tim Williamson on Philosophic Method (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
We continue from part one talking with Tim about Overfitting and Heuristics in Philosophy (2024).

We talk more about Tim's overall project: Does it allow philosophers to stop spinning their wheels considering outlandish counter-examples to philosophical theories, or does it in fact require more work, in that we now have to source all those alleged counter-examples to specific heuristics?

Instead of engaging in conceptual analysis, Tim wants philosophers to become familiar with scientific modeling and apply this in their theorizing. So what does that involve, exactly? Tim says some things about what public philosophy can and can't do. Philosophers should get out of their armchairs and connect to the scientific results and tools of the day.

Some of our final discussion concerns ethical theories and how extreme or personal "counter-evidence" should be dealt with (e.g. you might be against capital punishment, but what about the killer of your own family?). One figure that Mark brings up as a possible modeler is W.D. Ross .

Next time : We're reading three 1844 essays by Karl Marx : "Estranged Labor," "Private Property and Communism," and "The Power of Money in Bourgeois Society."

item.title: Ep. 354: Guest Tim Williamson on Philosophic Method (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
Oxford philosophy professor Timothy Williamson talks to Mark, Wes, and Seth about his new book, Overfitting and Heuristics in Philosophy .

How can we best apply the insights of philosophy of science to philosophy itself? Beginning with his earlier book The Philosophy of Philosophy , Tim has argued that the way philosophy uses alleged counter-examples to refute philosophical theories is naïve. The philosophy of science has moved past Popper's theory that a single experiment against a theory amounts to a refutation; there's always a choice whether to change the theory fundamentally, to revise just some peripheral aspect of it relevant to the experiment, or deny the validity or relevance of the experiment. Tim claims this should be applied to philosophy too: When a thought experiment produces alleged counter-evidence to the theory, we should try to figure out the source of the intuitions make the thought experiment look tempting. The first chapter of Tim's new book outlines several heuristics that people use to generate intuitions and how these heuristics can at times produce bad data.

In the arena of perception, for instance, a heuristic tells us (and Thomas Reid does too!) that when we see something, we take this perception as veridical. This usually works, but in cases of perceptual illusion (a straight stick looking bent when placed in water, a desert mirage), it doesn't. This doesn't mean we throw away the heuristic and become skeptics, but we have to be careful and try to diagnose what went wrong with the perceptual-environmental system in cases where the heuristic results in faulty belief.

That was an example of where the failure of a heuristic might produce a skeptical overreaction. A more straightforward case of the heuristic giving rise to a philosophical paradox is what Tim calls "the persistence heuristic," which is our assumption that things in general don't change, and in particular that small differences don't matter. Per the "ship of Theseus" (the sorties paradox), if you change out one plank of a ship, certainly it's still the same ship, but applying this principle repeatedly could mean you're calling "the same ship" something that has entirely new planks. Yes, it's useful for us to overlook small differences in keeping track of the world, and true in most circumstances that a minute change doesn't matter, but we need to understand that this is merely a heuristic, a rule of thumb, and not a reliable philosophical intuition.

A case where a heuristic could potentially come into play is Williamson's topic from our ep. 348 : knowledge as justified true belief (JTB). Gettier had come up with alleged counter-examples where in unusual circumstances a belief could be true and justified, yet still not knowledge. One might argue that some heuristic gone wrong is responsible for these Gettier cases, and we should just ignore them and say that the JTB theory of knowledge is a good one for all ordinary circumstances. Tim does not pursue this strategy in this case: It's hard to see which heuristic would be at fault, and JTB is already according to Tim an inelegant patchwork theory that is guilty of "overfitting," the idea which is central in the second chapter of Tim's book.

In science, if one makes a theory more and more complex in light of data countering the original theory, then that theory ceases to have much predictive power. If your wildly jagged graph of expected results matches point-for-point the data you actually achieve, then it's clear you've jiggered this "model" to take all your data at face value, whereas it's actually very likely that some data will be junk: outliers to be dismissed. In ethics, a rule like "you should not lie" might be tweaked and tweaked to include all the intuitively plausible individual cases where a lie seems like it would be morally OK, but a better approach would be to come up with some other way of phrasing the theory, e.g. "you should not lie maliciously" that approaches the simplicity of the original theory.

Another example of overfitting is Paul Grice's increasingly complicated theory of what "linguistic meaning" amounts to (as discussed in our ep. 325 ). Tim is convinced that giving these kinds of analyses is actually not what analytic philosophy should be doing. Either such philosophers are giving psychological theories, in which case it's implausible that the governing psychology could actually be that complicated, or they're trying to describe something metaphysical (about meaning, knowledge, truth, causation, or whatnot). But why assume that these very important metaphysical aspects of our lives are actually analyzable in more basic terms?

We also talk about the disquotational heuristic (interpreting someone's words according to our meanings even if the speaker's knowledge makes their meanings different than ours) to talk about Frege's sense-reference distinction . Another heuristic Tim gets into in his book involve the metaphor of weighing (e.g. reasons), such that intersectionality properly points out that the relation between anti-female discrimination and anti-black discrimination is not simply additive as the heuristic might tell us. Another involves how we interpret conditionals where the antecedent is false: We interpret "If the earth doesn't exist, then water is wet" as more reasonable to believe than "If the earth doesn't exist, then 2+2=5" even though these are both equally (trivially) true given that the earth does exist.

Buy the book . You can read the two chapters we read here and here .

item.title: Closereads: F.H. Bradley's "Appearance and Reality" (Audio Part Three)
item.description:
Now reading ch. 2, "Substantive and Adjective," and a bit of ch. 3, "Relation and Quality." Bradley considers problems that occur when we make the metaphysical distinction between substances and properties. How are these connected, and how are the various properties of a thing related to each other? Is it just our minds that hold these things together?

Read along with us , starting on p. 22.

item.title: Ep. 353: Reid on Visual Knowledge (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
Concluding our treatment of "Of Seeing" in Inquiry into the Human Mind on the Principles of Common Sense . Start with ep. 352 .

We continue to hammer at this idea of "resemblance." Given that there is some biological/physical encoding process whereby some aspect of an object in the world is sensed, should we say that the signal, and the brain state it brings about, "resembles" that thing. Of course, the thing is a physical object, not a brain state or mental entity, but if in particular a visual field corresponds point-by-point to a structure in the world as seen from a particular angle, wouldn't we want to say that the image, even if warped or transformed into non-imagistic encoding, does more than merely symbolize the original? The association between a word and what it symbolizes (e.g. "dog" and that animal) is entirely arbitrary, but the association between even the smell of a rose and the rose itself, and even moreso that between my visual idea of that rose and the rose, is natural and structurally informative. So is Reid wrong in characterizing our relation to external objects as mediated by sensations that act as "symbols" for these objects?

We consider more carefully Reid's level of support for the primary/secondary quality distinction, how he treats non-signifying feelings like pain and warmth, and finally we look at Reid's comparison of sense experience to testimony. Both cases have a natural component and a learned component. We naturally understand non-verbal communication, and we naturally are brought by a sensation to posit that the object exists. We learn language, and we learn lots of things about objects and how they relate to us, and so we're able to understand the testimony of people and of nature itself. In both cases, there's a necessary baseline assumption of veracity: If people weren't in general telling the truth, we wouldn't even learn language, and lying would literally make no sense. If perception weren't in general veridical, then illusion wouldn't make sense. (We ran into a similar argument when considering the Nyaya school .) Developmentally, it's very good for us that we in general believe our senses and other people, as these help our survival. It's only when we're older (and perhaps corrupted by philosophy) that doubts occur.

Next time : As a sequel to our past discussion of Tim Williamson , we're now interviewing him about the first two chapters of his new book, Overfitting and Heuristics in Philosophy (2024).

item.title: Ep. 353: Reid on Visual Knowledge (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
We're continuing from ep. 352 on Inquiry into the Human Mind on the Principles of Common Sense (1764), now discussing ch. 6: "Of Seeing."

The moral of Reid's previous treatment of the other senses was that the sensations that a perceived object causes in us do not resemble that thing. The physical rose and its odor have very little in common, and it's only because they are generally present together that think that that particular sort of odor is the odor of that kind of object.

But what about sight? In this case, the visual sensation we get of an object actually does resemble it as a picture resembles the object depicted. This is entirely what fooled other philosophers into thinking seeing the general relation between idea and object as one of resemblance (i.e. the image is a degraded copy of the physical original), which Reid argued had several counter-intuitive consequences ultimately leading to Humean skepticism about our ability to know mind-independent objects at all.

However, on closer attention to our visual experience, which Reid invites us to engage in, we see that our visual sensations, e.g. of shape, are still quite different than the shapes out in the world (which we could detect by touch). Only a painter typically has the patience to focus on sensations alone to be able to reproduce these on a canvas, instead of just using the image to take our minds straight to an object (like a signifier takes us to the signified).

We get a lot more detail about visual sensations. While there's a structural similarity between the visual sensory image and the object, the visual sphere actually has it own, non-Euclidean geometry to it, as if the images were projected onto the surface of a sphere. When we look down a street, the sides of the street are parallel, and we interpret them as such, yet the actual image we get is of the two converging at some point in the distance. The relation between this warped, two-dimensional image and the three-dimensional world is, as with all the other senses, only one we know from experiencing it, though Reid strangely emphasizes that a blind geometer could predict what this curved space would look like to a sighted person.

Image by Charles Valsechi . Edited by Sonic Hustle .

item.title: Closereads: F.H. Bradley's "Appearance and Reality" (Audio Part Two)
item.description:
We begin Bradley's argument for idealism: The world as we perceive it is appearance, not reality. In ch. 1, "Primary and Secondary Qualities," we see him give Locke's arguments for the distinction and Berkeley's response that both alike are in the mind, not the world.

We try to make sense of this given our recent reading for The Partially Examined Life of Thomas Reid, who argued for realism against Berkeley and others.

Read along with us , starting on p. 17.

item.title: Closereads: F.H. Bradley's "Appearance and Reality" (Audio Part One)
item.description:
Bradley was a prominent British Hegelian, best known now for being the springboard for Bertrand Russell, who was initially a follower but then rejected idealism entirely to co-create what is now known as analytic philosophy. Today we read just the Introduction to this massive 1893 tome, where Bradley argues that metaphysics is possible and worthwhile.

Read along with us , starting on PDF p. 5.

Folks in the $10/month tier can experience this as ad-free video and will get additional coverage to this reading as it's released, along with all the other Closereads content. item.title: Ep. 352: Thomas Reid on Smelling and Knowledge (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
Continuing from part one on Inquiry into the Human Mind , getting further into the chapter on smelling.

We start with the question about what exactly our relation with objects in the world is. Do we "construct" them out of our various sensations? What does Reid's theory of memory contribute to this?

Another point of contrast with past philosophy Reid makes is that we don't first merely "apprehend" an idea, e.g. the smell sensation of a rose and hence the rose, and then decide that a rose exists. The more complex mental operation (positing its existence) comes right at the same time as apprehending it.

Finally, we talk more about Hume and Reid's correspondence (the book was sent to Hume to review, and Hume didn't seem to get the main point), Reid's story of the history of philosophy, and the skepticism that Reid is arguing against.

Next episode : We're reading more of this book: the chapter on sight (sec. 1-12, 20, and 24).

item.title: Ep. 352: Thomas Reid on Smelling and Knowledge (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
On Inquiry into the Human Mind on the Principles of Common Sense (1764): the introduction, conclusion, ch. 2 "Of Smelling" ch. 4 "Of Hearing," and some correspondence between Reid and Hume. Featuring Mark, Wes, Seth and Dylan.

Reid was responding to so-called "modern philosophy" from Descartes through Hume and thought that something had gone terribly wrong. From Descartes' idea that the only thing we directly know is our own sensations comes, inevitably according to Reid, Hume's skepticism, not just about the external world (the existence of ordinary objects and their causal relations), but about even minds (ours and other people's). Common sense says that when we have a sensation, our mind is brought immediately to the object that that sensation is supposed to be of. We don't perceive the sensation itself and then infer the object; we gain immediate knowledge of the object. We can actually know causality, material objects, other minds, and our own self as existing over time.

Key to accepting this view is the insight (which he attributes to Berkeley ) that our sensations do not typically resemble material objects. While Berkeley insisted that similarity is the only way that objects could possibly cause sensations, and therefore material objects must not exist at all (it's just ideas in God's mind causing ideas in our minds), Reid says it's just a brute, inexplicable fact that causality between such unlike things occurs. Past philosophers have been deluded about the resemblance between ideas and things by focusing on sight, so instead Reid starts his book by analyzing smell. The noun "smell" is ambiguous, referring both to the sensation (qualia) that we experience in smelling something and also to the object of the act: the odor that is smelled. The latter is some physical property by which little bits of the thing are sent off into our noses, while the former is in the mind, and there's no way we could predict without experience that exactly THIS smell (e.g. of a rose) would match this object (the physical flower).

Instead of thinking of a sensation as a picture of the object it's a sensation of, Reid would prefer we think of it like a language: Yes, we literally directly encounter only our own sensations (so Reid is not a direct realist like Searle ), but we treat these as symbols for the thing we perceive as indicated by and associated with the sensation. Experiencing the sensation is not a purely receptive state, but involves the judgment that the object exists and is nearby. We could of course be wrong about this, e.g. if it's a rose-scented perfume instead of an actual rose, but we could then explain why we're wrong. This doesn't warrant any kind of general skepticism. If we were not in general right about roses being there when that scent is there, then we would never learn that it's the scent of a rose; many of us have some recognition of common scents used in candles and other items but may have no clear idea of their original source. (I have no ability to pick out a lavender plant.)

Reid distinguishes sensations from memory and imagination. While sensation involves a judgment that the object is present, memory involves a judgment that it was present, and imagination doesn't involve any judgment either way about the object's existence. Reid identifies memory in particular as something past philosophers got wrong: They think that when we have a memory, we're contemplating some current idea that is a faded copy of the original sensation. Reid thinks instead that we are thinking of that original sensation, which is of course long gone. The memory need not resemble the original sensation (after all, memories can be faulty); it is a memory that something happened which may or may not involve some current imagination about that thing (the scent actually "coming back to you").

Throughout all of this, Reid is arguing against the use of the term of art "ideas" as our sole mental content. For Hume , there are just impressions and ideas, and ideas are just faded impressions. So the only thing distinguishing memory from perception is that memory is about a more faded kind of idea. Reid thinks that the insistence on reducing mental life to just a few elements is a misguided attempt to apply the model of Newtonian science to philosophy. The mind is irreducibly complex, and there's a lot we don't know about it (even now). Reid suggests that philosophy engage in careful phenomenology to focus on things like the sensation of a smell and its distinction between that and its object (the objective odor) which common practice generally ignores. In this sense, despite the title of his book, Reid is not saying that his philosophy is merely an expression of "common sense." Rather, he claims that any philosophy that blatantly flies in the face of common sense, e.g. in claiming that we can't know the external world or at least can't rationally be certain that we do, is unsustainable for us. We simply can't pretend outside of philosophical armchairs that causality is not actually out in the world, or that the smell of something is only in our heads. When we smell something dreadful, we rightly assume that there's something decaying or otherwise awful out in the world that needs to be cleaned up if we want to get rid of that smell. Unless you're shown that he smelly sensation is experienced by you alone (maybe because you're having a stroke), common sense tells you that it is real, objective, and in the world, even if Locke says it's a mere "secondary quality" that's only in your head. If a tree falls in a forest and no one is around, obviously it makes a sound!

Buy the book . You can read this other version online .

Image by Chris Warr (aka Solomon Grundy).

item.title: Closereads: Merleau-Ponty on the Body (Audio Part Five)
item.description:
Completing our readthrough of "The Body as Object of Mechanistic Physiology" in the book "Phenomenology of Perception."

We make a final stab at figuring out the new existential-type of explanation M-P is trying to give that comes prior to the mind (psychic)-body (physiological) distinction, touching on habit, stimulus-response, associationism, our connection to the past, agency, and again with the phantom limb.  

Read along with us , starting on p. 98 (PDF p123).

item.title: Ep. 351: Guest Sophie Grace Chappell on Transgender (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
Mark, Seth and Dylan continue talking about philosophy surrounding trans phenomena in light of our interview with Sophie Grace about Trans Figured .

We start with Sophie's idea that biological sex is itself a cluster concept: several different biological characteristics that make it somewhat arbitrary to say when exactly someone who has undergone hormone treatments and surgery has "transformed" from one natural kind to another (and as we do not mention, she was including some as yet unrealized scientific possibilities whereby one might change chromosomes; see our episode on transhumanism ).

From here the discussion quickly moves to trans athletes, touching on the philosophy of sport and why we separate genders in sports in the first place. We then talk about the degree to which gender itself is a matter of natural kinds vs. various interests that are culturally relative (e.g. fashion) and not necessarily tied to some particular gender. What does "demanding respect" mean in the trans context, and how do the ethical issues compare with those involved in feminism and philosophy of race. We also touch on dress codes, pronouns, and bathroom use.

At the end of the discussion, you can hear me in real time decide that perhaps we should keep this behind our paywall. Thank you for your support and hopefully tolerance for our well-intentioned fumbling on this and many other sensitive issues. We welcome your recommendations of additional things to read and guests to include. I definitely want to continue exploring trans issues on Pretty Much Pop, as there's been a lot of trans representation in pop culture recently, most surprisingly to me the House of the Dragon appearance of Abigail Thorn from Philosophy Tube , who along with Natalie Wynn from Contrapoints was someone we long tried to contact for our trans episode. We are still open to speaking to either of them if anyone has a connection. This could be a potential topic for any of my podcasts. I had a non-binary Nakedly Examined Music guest scheduled who cancelled on me at the last minute, and some of my guests there have certainly been very candid in the music and our discussions about their LGBTQ+ experiences.

We are also of course open to talking to or reading work by a trans man. One point that didn't get made explicitly in our interview with Sophie is her take that trans men have it relatively easy compared to trans women: The community of men is generally fine with accepting a "tom boy" into their midst (reportedly G.E.M Anscombe was affectionately called "old man" by Wittgenstein and their contemporaries). But according to Sophie, men cannot in general understand why any other man would want to abandon masculinity and so have an immediate reaction of contempt for "girly men" of any sort. It might be interesting to determine to what degree this is the case and why: Is it just that homophobia is more acute among men than women? Sophie's book includes an open letter to J.K. Rowling, who is explicitly more concerned about the supposed rash of girls abandoning femininity based on her own experience of being ambivalent about being female herself when she was young and now thinking that was a misguided sentiment.

The image was cribbed from this article .

item.title: Ep. 351: Guest Sophie Grace Chappell on Transgender (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
Sophie Grace wrote and taught philosophy (chiefly ethics and epistemology) at several different British universities including Oxford and is now a professor at Open University. Mark, Seth, and Dylan interview her about her recently published book Trans Figured , which mixes autobiography, philosophy, and discussion of current political rhetoric surrounding transgender.

Her strategy is one of acknowledging facts and trying to avoid theories that would confuse or falsify these. As a child, she (among many other boys) experienced gender dysphoria, felt that she had been placed in the wrong body and social status, and now that she's able to present herself as a woman, she feels much more satisfied. Given that this sort of need is real and not something that people can talk themselves out of (she tried for many years to do this), the appropriate moral response is to treat people as they want to be treated. It is a simple matter of justice, respect, and compassion.

So Sophie has no "theory of gender," no ambitions a la Judith Butler to fundamentally reduce the emphasis on gender in society (though Sophie agrees of course that non-binary persons should also be treated with respect). But there is a role for philosophy here, and Sophie argues for a Wittgensteinian view of concepts that views them not as essential categories with necessary and sufficient conditions, but as having a history and being open to change. Just as one could not validly argue against gay marriage by saying "by definition, marriage is between a man and a woman," one cannot not effectively argue that one's sex is once-and-for-all settled by some particular biological characteristics at birth. Rather, Sophie argues on analogy to adoption that while of course "parenthood" has its origin and paradigm cases in biological parenthood, society should and does have little trouble finding space for adopted parents. We don't rudely point out whenever a child refers to an adopted parent, "but you know, that's not your real parent." We don't exclude adoptive parents from parent-teacher conferences or from any other social perks and duties involved in parenthood.

However, analogically against the rhetorical aggression of tans activists, there is no need to insist that adopted parents in all circumstances must be categorized as parents (e.g. an obvious exception is in giving medical family history). We also need not distort language to insist that all biological parents call themselves "bio-parents" to ensure that adoptive parents don't feel marginalized.

Another analogy Sophie gives is becoming a naturalized citizen (she is in fact trans-Scottish). It would be bigoted to insist that only a pureblood, biological Scot is a real Scot. What makes Sophie Scottish when she was born in England is that she's gone through a diligent process to align her outlook and interests with being a citizen of that community, and she should be (and is) welcomed into it.

We discuss essentialism, pragmatism, conceptual engineering (e.g. the invention of the term "sexual harassment"), moral progress, bodily phenomenology, biological sex as a cluster concept, inclusionary feminism, and hermeneutic justice.

In addition to reading Trans Figured , we all looked at an article called "Trans Without the Gender " (2022), which is a response to Rach Cosker-Rowland . Mark brings up Sophie's 2009 article "Ethics Beyond Moral Theory ," and she describes Trans Figured as essentially an application of her last book Epiphanes . She's currently promoting a new book on friendship that is the third in this trilogy. See her Open University page for many of her publications.

Sophie also refers to Jan Morris' Conundrum (1973), Rebecca Jane Morgan's Gender Heretics (2023), Danièle Moyal-Sharrock's Real Gender (2024).

In part two (exclusively for you supporters), the PEL guys will continue to hash through these issues.

item.title: Closereads: Merleau-Ponty on the Body (Audio Part Four)
item.description:
Continuing on "Phenomenology of Perception" , Part I: "The Body": "Experience and Objective Thought," Ch. 1, "The Body as Object of Mechanistic Physiology."

M-P thinks we can't do justice to our physical being-in-the-world through purely physiological/physical language. His examples include phantom limbs and anasognosia (when a patient is in denial about an injured part of the body or other deficiency). The alternative is not the language of mechanistic psychology (which he covers in ch. 2), but a pre-objective, phenomenological position.

Read along with us , starting on p. 87 (PDF p. 112).

item.title: Ep. 350: Rorty on Justification and Essentialism (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
Concluding on “Universality and Truth” from Richard Rorty’s Pragmatism As Anti-Authoritarianism . Start with the previous part , or better yet, ep. 349 .

Despite Rorty’s rejection of transcendent Truth, he claims not to be a relativist. An absolutist accusing someone of being a relativist is saying “either our beliefs are caused by things in the world or we are constructing beliefs regardless of the true state of the world, and you are doing the latter.” Rorty rejects this alternative: there is no distinction that makes any difference between these two views, if on either of them one can pursue science, look for evidence, and demonstrate or argue for some point. Rather Rorty has no theory of truth. Is this a coherent position? Do we need such a theory, or is such theorizing just another language game?

Next Time : We’re discussing the new book Trans Figured with its author, Prof. Sophie Grace Chappell .

item.title: Ep. 350: Rorty on Justification and Essentialism (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
On “Universality and Truth” and “Pan-Relationalism,” which are lectures 3-5 in Richard Rorty’s Pragmatism As Anti-Authoritarianism , which we began discussing last episode .

Mark, Wes, Seth, and Dylan continue to hash through Rorty’s pragmatism, which in this book is given in relation to how to best promote democracy. Rorty thinks democracy can “stand on its own two feet”; it has obvious advantages that we can refer to without bringing in an objective standard of morality that it is in accord with or anything else like that. All there is in political deliberation is human argumentation, and we humans are the only judges of what arguments are effective. We do not do this by reference to an objective standard; we are aiming for agreement, not transcendent Truth. If people raised outside of a liberal society don’t see the benefits of democracy (don’t judge that the effects we point to are benefits), then their opinions may only change given some change in their emotions (e.g. make Nazis read The Diary of Anne Frank ). Part of this is an argument against Habermas , who argues that communication itself implies an ethic of openness that is pro-democratic. You could therefore in a rather Kantian style argue that someone against democracy is being inconsistent, i.e. irrational.

The term pan-relationalism describes Rorty’s ontology: There is no distinction between a substance and its properties. Any way of referring to a substance is just pulling out more properties. A property may be more important to you for some particular purpose, but no property in itself is more “essential” than any other (contra essentialists like Aristotle and Ellis ). One implication of this view is that our relation to the world is irreducibly propositional (the term from Sellars is “psychological nominalism”); there is nothing we’d call knowledge that is merely pre-linguistic, since that would (according to Rorty) present an picture where we’re directly in touch with essences.

Image by Olle Halvars .

item.title: Closereads: Merleau-Ponty on the Body (Audio Part One)
item.description:
We begin a long series on Maurice Merleau-Ponty's "Phenomenology of Perception" (1945), focusing on Part I, "The Body": "Experience and Objective Thought."

M-P talks first about what seeing an object (like a house) in the world involves. It pre-supposes a relation to us as perceivers, which involves our situatedness in a body. Yet when we make our own body into an objective object in space and time (like the house), we've shifted it from this primordial center of perception into something described like perception. What is involved in this shift?

Read along with us , starting on p. 77 (PDF p. 102).

item.title: Ep. 349: Rorty's Pluralistic Pragmatism (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
Continuing from part one on Richard Rorty’s Pragmatism As Anti-Authoritarianism , ch. 1, “Pragmatism and Religion” and 2, “Pragmatism as Romantic Polytheism.”

Rorty evaluates James, Dewey, and Peirce on religion and finds Dewey’s approach most fruitful toward promoting democracy. While James promoted tolerance, Dewey thought that we should regulate our actions and beliefs by the need to join with other people in cooperative projects. Whereas our recent reading of James pointed to the need to recognize and grapple with suffering, so religion is needed to essentially relieve us from what Rorty calls “original sin,” Dewey is more straightforwardly optimistic, focused on hope. Rorty, contra James, claims that to be rational is to submit all of one’s beliefs to the judgment of one’s peers; religion cannot be “privatized” the way James would like. At the same time, Rorty acknowledges that private beliefs can be used to make your own personality coherent, which is part of the thriving diversity that democracy shoots for.

Rorty also gives us a Freudian take on the evolution of religion, saying that when God the Father (or the literal tyrannical father of an ancient tribe) is slain, ideally we want a fraternity of dependents to take over, i.e. democracy instead of a new-boss-same-as-the-old-boss situation. So replacing religious ethics with Kantian ethics is still a lateral move, according to Rorty; we want to be communal creators of values.

He also has some comments about Nietzsche, who was all about that “creators of values” philosophy but who looked down on democracy. Nietzsche (according to Rorty) thought that once you think of people as just “clever animals,” you have no reason to wish for the good of all human beings. Rorty obviously disagrees. In our next episode , we’ll take on such political (and epistemic) issues more directly, reading lectures 3-5 (i.e. the next two chapters): “Universality and Truth” and “Pan-Relationalism.”

item.title: Ep. 349: Rorty's Pluralistic Pragmatism (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
On Richard Rorty's Pragmatism As Anti-Authoritarianism (written 1997), ch. 1-2. Should democracy be defended on absolutist grounds, e.g. by reference to God-given or natural rights, the nature of Man, or the dictates of Reason?

Throughout this book (adapted from a series of 1997 lectures but not published until 2021 after Rorty's death), Rorty argues that democracy, ethics, and even truth itself are a matter for societies to decide for themselves. There is no truly non-human authority that we can refer to in defending a way of life or even a scientific theory.

Of course, these two types of claim (normative for ethics vs. descriptive for science) sure look like they'd have different grounds for defense. To prove a matter of fact, I might point you to a relevant perception or calculation and invite you to confirm this. To prove a moral claim, I might point to some sentiment or moral precept that I know you have (and that presumably we share). What these have in common is that they're referring to some shared practice, and they presuppose some particular audience for justification. If your moral intuitions have nothing in common with mine, I won't be able to convince you that some action is wrong, and if you claim to perceive or reason differently than me, then you won' t find my scientific arguments convincing. For a pragmatist, it's simply unnecessary and in fact counter-productive to think about justification as comparison of a belief with "the truth." We have no access to truth beyond the particular methods of verification and justification which we engage in, and so maybe we should just talk about those methods.

Does this mean that Rorty and other pragmatists are relativists? Rorty follows Donald Davidson in denying that there's any sense to be made in two people having fundamentally different conceptual schemes such that they can't reason together. But he doesn't attribute this to our all having some "human nature" objectively in common such that Reason as something objectively binding on all of us compels us to agree. Specifically with regard to democracy, Rorty doesn't think that a commitment to egalitarian consideration of everyone's opinions and interests (everyone gets a vote) is somehow implied in the way we speak and reason with each other. He just thinks it's a good idea, which means that it produces the kind of society that we at this point in history and in this part of the world think is desirable. If we want to convince someone in a repressive, elitist society that democracy is good, we could try to show that the people who are marginalized in his society are just as worthy, just as human, just as easy to sympathize with, as the people his society currently respects. Do we know in advance that everyone will (or should?) be convinced by these argumentative moves? Is it necessary that our arguments be designed to convince all possible audiences ? Rorty says no.

We'll further consider the epistemological and political aspects of this book in ep. 350, covering the next three lectures. In this part in discussion, we're focusing on Rorty's claim that appeals to Truth are quasi-religious in the sense that, like the Divine Command Theory of morality , they appeal to some non-human authority. This is the kind of move that authoritarians make: THIS is the law because we the rulers know God's will. Rorty considers alternative, pragmatist approaches to religion, such as William James' in "The Will to Believe ," where James "privatizes" religion, removing it from a position where it can do damage to our cooperative projects, and in The Varieties of Religious Experience , where he (wrongly, according to Rorty) argues that religious tenets in their broad outlines can be objectively established as true.

Even the "privatization" of religion to the sphere of belief is not great, according to Rorty, as our beliefs as expressing positions in public language games (e.g. observation, evidence) tend to impinge on those among our projects that are relevant other people (most of them are, after all). You can't just "believe" that the world is flat without this affecting your behavior in ways that will undermine social efforts. You can't just believe that you are a member of a chosen people that will be rewarded after death, with all unbelievers punished, without this affecting how you treat others, the respect you have (or don't have) for them. All of these gods compete, for Rorty, with democracy as something for us all to strive for as a group. While democracy should encourage and protect diversity of opinion, any opinion is subject to discussion and debate with others; that's part of the language game as laid out in Mill's "On Liberty."

The two lectures/chapters we read for this discussion include "Pragmatism and Religion" and "Pragmatism as Romantic Polytheism." Re. the second of these essays, Rorty says that traditional deference to The Truth and The Good is a form of monotheism. Rorty prefers the idea that there is more than one ideal, dependent on what purposes we adopt. We've seen this idea ethically in Nietzsche, who instead of urging us to attain to some single ideal of behavior (e.g. "What would Jesus do?" Or Confucius, or Socrates...) instead encourages us to "become you we are," where each of us has some different path, and we have some freedom to choose and even create that path. What counts as a relevant truth when we're looking at non-moral "facts" is dependent on why we want to know. Is this physical object mostly solid? If you want to pick it up, yes it is. If you want to analyze its microstructure, one relevant truth is that it's mostly empty space, and so not "solid."

Buy the book . Read the first chapter online .

The image is by Corey Mohler .

item.title: Ep. 348: Tim Williamson's Knowledge-First Epistemology (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
Continuing from part one , we finish up "Knowledge First Epistemology" (2011), and delve further into "Justifications, Excuses, and Sceptical Scenarios" (2015), and "Morally Loaded Cases in Philosophy" (2019).

How does Williamson's approach compare to Goldman's reliabilism ? (Note that Goldman just passed away .) Williamson distinguishes between actually following a norm and being the kind of person who generally follows norms. Morally, we can distinguish between someone who is generally morally praiseworthy and someone who actually does the right thing. One can intend to do the right thing, but because of a lack of knowledge, in fact do the wrong thing. Pointed at the case of knowledge, having knowledge is like actually obeying the norm, and merely having a reliable knowledge procedure (how Goldman defines justification) is comparable to being in general virtuous.

Consequently, while Goldman allows the possibility of justified belief that is yet untrue and so not knowledge, Williamson this out. No matter what your intention or your how good your knowledge-gathering habits maybe, you still have not successfully justified a belief unless that belief ends up being true. What the false-but-seemingly-justified believer has is an good excuse, just as the virtuous person who acts on bad knowledge and so ends up doing evil has an excuse. It doesn't make the bad act actually good (as Kant might insist, being wholly fixated on the moral value of motives), or in this case does it not make a brain-in-vat who seriously investigates his (illusory) surroundings actually justified in the many incorrect beliefs it has about its environment.

Williamson does have things to say actually about ethics here too. Is is possible to be, morally, in a situation analogous to the brain in a vat? The brain in a vat simply has no way of seeing through its illusions, no resources to draw on. Could a self-consistent Nazi with Nazi sensibilities be cut off from any moral reactions that would provide reason to question his moral assumptions? We would not blame the brain for being ignorant, but we probably feel like we can blame the Nazi.

We finish up by talking about whether Williamson has a good argument against relativism or skepticism (or needs one).

Next time: We're reading the first two lectures in Richard Rorty's Pragmatism and Anti-Authoritarianism .

item.title: Ep. 348: Tim Williamson's Knowledge-First Epistemology (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
On "Knowledge First Epistemology " (2011), "Justifications, Excuses, and Sceptical Scenarios " (2015), and "Morally Loaded Cases in Philosophy " (2019).

Does it really make sense to try to define knowledge in terms of belief and justification, as we did in ep. 344 , or should we instead take Williamson's advice and consider knowledge as basic: something to be examined, sure, but not defined in terms of component parts? Mark and Wes are joined by guests Russell Ming and Chris Heath to cover this important current figure in analytic epistemology.

This position is another breed of externalism (like Nyaya ), which means saying knowledge is a matter of an actual connection to the world, as opposed to an internalist picture whereby an individual knower is in a position to know that knowledge is taking place. A piece of internalist advice might be "you should only believe what you have evidence for." But this assumes that we know whether any given observation or belief counts as evidence. Williamson, however, wants to define even evidence externally. Misleading or false evidence actually doesn't count as evidence at all, but pseudo-evidence. More generally, we should understand false belief by first understanding knowledge, which involves true belief.

Is belief itself "external" in the way that on this view evidence and knowledge are? Yes, if our belief involves words, which involve meanings that are essentially public, and not always clear to the speaker (see Wittgenstein on private languages ). Williamson sums this up by saying that virtually no mental concept is actually "luminous": fully understood by the thinker, i.e. internal. For example, if I believe that the snow over there is white, but actually it's not snow but a group of white moths, then on Williamson's example, my belief is not about the thing I thought it was about; it's about moths instead of snow. It's certainly not about a snow-appearing sensory experience that may or may not be actually connected with snow.

A result of all this is that while you might have thought that the "mental" in general is characterized by luminous (I prefer "transparent") content -- the contents of consciousness -- while something like knowledge that also involves the external criterion of truth would only be partially mental and partly metaphysical, it turns out that much of our mental life is not known to us. A prime characteristic of the mental is intentionality in the sense of aboutness: This belief or perception or hope or whatnot is about some external thing or state of affairs or possible state of affairs. Since the intentional content will in most cases be something public, whether a proposition or a state of affairs in the world, then we should expect all intentional mentality to have an external component. This doesn't mean that it isn't truly "mental."

We also touch on Williamson's 2022 essay "Where Did It Come From? Where Will It Go?" from Putting Knowledge to Work: New Directions for Knowledge-First Epistemology .

Image by Charles Valsechi . Edited by Sonic Hustle .

item.title: Ep. 347: Nyaya Sutra Against Buddhist Skeptics (Part Three for Supporters)
item.description:
Mark and Dylan reconvened a couple days after part two to finish discussing personal identity (ch. 4) in Nyaya Sutra: Selections with Early Commentaries . Whereas in the previous discussion, we were largely focusing on the metaphysical and logical arguments for the existence of an enduring self, here we go into a bit more depth about the moral arguments: There needs to be a self to make sense of our practices of praise and blame.

The religious background of this discussion involved reincarnation, which interestingly gets a new-to-us argument that has a parallel to Plato's arguments about recollection. How is instinct possible? Our authors here claim that for us to know how to smile, for instance, must be based on our having learned it, and since babies seem to do this spontaneously (not having learned it from their parents), then they must have learned it before birth.

In addition to responding to Buddhists, the Nyayas are also responding to materialists who don't believe in the soul at all. Admitting that consciousness has to root in something, because it's a characteristic that needs a substance, could consciousness be the quality of the material body? The Nyaya argument response is that the body is still a body when it's dead. If the existence of body were all that were required for consciousness, then all bodies, even dead bodies, would have consciousness. Listen to hear why we think this Nyaya argument is obviously lame!

item.title: Ep. 347: Nyaya Sutra Against Buddhist Skeptics (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
Mark, Seth, and Dylan now turn to ch. 4 of Dasti/Phillips' Nyaya Sutra: Selections with Early Commentaries about the self. Buddhism famously claims that there is no self.

Metaphysically, we can take the pro-self position (atman) as involving something like a soul that exists over time. As we'll get into further in part three of this discussion, this is morally problematic in the Indian tradition, since they (Buddhists included) believe in karma and re-incarnation. If there is no self, what is it that endures through rebirths, and even in this life, what sense would there be in punishing someone (whether through divine or human justice) if there is no persistent entity to hold the blame (or praise) for actions.

In this part of the discussion, we focus on the more experiential and inferential arguments. It certainly seems that there must be something that makes my various experiences belong to me and yours belonging to you. If consciousness were just a single, universal subject (whether purusha or God) that happens to be peering out of various eyes, i.e. we really all are One, then it'd be a significant task to explain why we certainly appear to be many different, persistent people. (This Oneness doctrine is actually Vedantin, not Buddhist.)

Buddhism has a term for this, however, which is "conventional reality," which they contrast with ultimate reality. This should sound familiar from Hume: we do perceive a succession of experience, and my succession no doubt differs from yours, but we are not justified in positing some underlying substance that makes that succession hang together. It's merely useful for us to talk as if there are such substances, not the least because we have separate bodies, our memories differ, and we do want to keep track of people based on their separate characters and actions so we can form relationships, make promises, know who to watch out for, etc. While Hume stops with the skeptical point that we don't know what, if anything, underlies on this, and so we can't be using a primordial sense of this underlying self to identify ourselves and distinguish ourselves from others, a Buddhist alternative involves the positive assertion that we can know the reality behind these appearances: that it is all Void or One (these would amount to the same thing; a "thing" requires differentiation from other things, so everything being a singular All and everything being Nothing are the same claim).

The Nyaya position argues, for instance, that since we have desire (and other psychological characteristics), and throughout our experience, all characteristics (properties) have a bearer, something that HAS the property, then something must have these psychological characteristics. This is not just some convenient fiction, but an evident reality, per the Nyaya methodology of relying on knowledge sources unless you have a good reason to deny their verdict. We seem to both directly perceive a self (the mind) through apperception, or if you deny this, you still have to admit this inference to the best explanation given all these otherwise free-floating psychological characteristics.

Complicating this is the idea that reality might not be ultimately made up of things, but of processes. Maybe "the mind"/"the self" is just something that our body (our brain) does: an activity that's happening as our embodied brains walk around perceiving, thinking, and acting. This might be a way to think about the self not being a persistent substance, but just some representation that develops through brain activity, not through mere "convention," but essentially given the kinds of creatures we are. Per our Robert Wright interview , some scientists see the brain as modular in such a way that there's no single control center that corresponds to our pre-scientific notion of a self. Maybe the self is a self-representation that occurs via a complex network of processes, and so not a persistent thing at all, much less a soul that would persist beyond death. Per our Parfit episode , maybe our everyday concept of personal identity is simply incoherent.

Next episode: We're reading three articles by Timothy Williamson, whose groundbreaking book Knowledge and Its Limits came out in 2000. These articles expound on the views developed there: "Knowledge First Epistemology " (2011), "Justifications, Excuses, and Sceptical Scenarios " (2015), and "Morally Loaded Cases in Philosophy " (2019).

item.title: Ep. 347: Nyaya Sutra Against Buddhist Skeptics (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
We're continuing to explore Nyaya epistemology, in this part focusing on ch. 3, "In Defense of the Real," in Nyaya Sutra: Selections with Early Commentaries (2017). Featuring Mark, Wes, and Seth.

In our last episode , we laid out the "knowledge sources" (perception, inference, testimony) and established that each of these is defined as successful contact with the world. If you perceive a mirage as water (or a person as a post, the example in the text), then you are not perceiving what you think you see. This "externalist" view is at variance with the Cartesian, "internalist" tradition according to which what we perceive is some mental content which may or may not hook up with the real world.

Our authors are engaging with Buddhists in ancient India who argue either that there literally is nothing, that all we perceive is illusion (see our Nagarjuna episode ), that it's all in our mind, or that we simply aren't equipped to know the reality of the world.

The Nyayas respond that even to entertain the idea that we might be deluded (e.g. that we're right now in a dream), we have to refer to the known real world by contrast with illusion. On top of that, in actual dreams, all the elements come from our waking life; we must be acquainted with reality in order to have these ideas. When we do suffer an illusion, we can explain the origin of this, e.g. we can talk about the physics of mirages. A way of characterizing all of these is that illusion is parasitic on reality, so claiming that all of reality is unreal is simply incoherent.

In part two (actually a different conversation on a different day), Mark, Seth, and Dylan deal specifically with Buddhist skepticism regarding the self. Nyayas argue that the self is evidently real and offer several arguments to that effect.

A nice, concise presentation of the central arguments here is given in a 2012 article by one of our book's editors, Matthew Dasti, "Parasitism and Disjunctivism in Nyaya Epistemology ."

Image by Charles Valsechi . This part was edited by The Podcast Doctors .

item.title: Ep. 346: Nyaya Sutra on Knowledge (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
Continuing from part one on ch. 1, “Knowledge Sources,” of the Matthew Dasti/Stephen Phillips presentation of the Nyaya-Sutra: Selections with Early Commentaries .

We continue discussing modalities of perception (why no love for a smell-based philosophy?) and further consider the Sutra’s dictum that perception must be inerrant and how this dovetails with the overall Nyaya approach: Consider a claim that someone makes based upon a knowledge source “established” unless someone then has a legitimate reason to challenge it, i.e. can also refer to a knowledge source to claim the contrary. So perception is a legitimate knowledge source, but I can legitimately ask you when you claim to have seen something if you really got a good look at it. What I can’t do is act the skeptic and ask you to doubt all your perceptions. There is no reason to do this; I have no standing — no practical worry — to demand this more global re-examination.

We then move on to inference, which is exemplified in these texts as a matter of induction: I have seen smoke and fire consistently together in the past, so when I see smoke (the inferential mark) now, I conclude there must be fire. However, another example given is the inference that there is a self based on the presence of desire and other mental activities. Descartes’ “I think, therefore I am” is certainly not induction, i.e. not based on past experiences of seeing my thoughts and my self always together, as any past experience would require the same proof of a self. We’ll get into this argument about self more in the second part of our ep. 347, but the point here is just that inference must refer to any kind of reasoning: an inference to the best explanation for something we perceive. Desire seems to be a property, and we know from past experiences that properties have substances, so a desire must inhere in something, and we call that something a self.

But is there a clean line between perception and inference? When I perceive an apple and recognize it as an apple, I am inferring that this thing I now see must be an apple because it looks like previous objects that I and others coupled with the word “apple.” Or if we stick to the requirement that perception is not in itself verbal, does any use of memory necessarily involve an inference?

This may be why the text actually gives “comparison” as a separate knowledge source. For instance, if someone has told me about a bison being “like a cow but bigger, furrier, and brown,” then when I see a bison for the first time, I might use this comparison to attach the word to the animal. This is surely a form of inference, and it’s a specific enough kind of case that it’s unclear that it helps us decide whether recognizing a particular fruit that we’ve seen a lot but which no one’s ever told us the name of counts as mere perception or perception plus some kind of inference.

Finally, we briefly consider testimony, which was especially important and independent of the others because the authors wanted to leave room for the inerrancy of the holy Vedic scriptures. So testimony is not reducible to perception, at least not of the ordinary kind; the scriptural authors had supernatural powers of perception and are reporting those perceptions to us. In ordinary cases, we are relying on the perception or valid reasoning of someone who knows what they’re talking about in the relevant sense, whether because they have first-hand perceptual knowledge of the thing or have the expertise to make valid inferences in that domain (as when we listen to scientists or other experts). Is the decision to accept someone’s testimony itself an inference, such that we should really consider testimony a flavor of inference? If I have often see a certain politician lie, it’s reasonable for me to infer that the thing he’s saying now is also a lie. However, as with all the knowledge sources, a lie wouldn’t actually be considered testimony at all, just pseudo-testimony. These analyses are about classifying the sources of legitimate knowledge, when this is present, and do not actually help us as knowers to distinguish the real thing from an imitation in particular cases. To gain these skills, we’d have to use our perceptions over time and the advice (testimony) of experienced teachers. We’d assume (reasonably, on the Nyaya view) that the information from these sources is usually reliable. Truth is the default, and doubt is introduced only when there’s some reason to challenge an assertion.

Next Time: We’re reading more of this book, covering chapters 3 (“In Defense of the Real”) and 4 (“Self”).

item.title: Ep. 346: Nyaya Sutra on Knowledge (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
On the Nyaya Sutra: Selections with Early Commentaries . While the original Sutra, reputed to be by someone named Akṣapāda (which means "looking at his feet") Gautama was written somewhere around 150 CE, this 2017 edition by Matthew Dasti and our previous guest Stephen Phillips features many more words by the commentators Vatsyayana (450 CE), Uddyotakara (550), and Vācaspatimiśra (900), and by the editors themselves.

In this discussion, we look into Ch. 1 "Knowledge Sources," which are chiefly perception, inference, and testimony. Perception gets by far the most lengthy treatment, differentiating between perceptions of different ontological categories of things like a pot vs. the individual brown swatch of color that inheres in the pot vs. the universal property brown. These differences matter because the Nyaya Sutra is giving us an externalist account of perception, where the point is not that a perceiver has a sensation that may or may not actually be connected to the world, but that in a legitimate case of perception, the sense organ comes into direct contact with the item perceived. So this raises physical and metaphysical questions about how our senses connect with objects at a distance, and we get to hear, for instance, about how ancient Indians thought of sound as the vibration of the ether, which is one, massive, undifferentiated substance (so not like air or water which are made up of particles) such that by making the noise I move the either that moves your eardrum not unlike if I were poking it with a long stick.

Perception also occurs, according to the sutra, without language, which is a weird thing to say if we want to include the possibility of perceiving the metaphysically universal brown, which seems tied to the verbal concept brown. Uddyotakara explains this by saying that a perception typically has three moments to it: I non-verbally perceive a thing, then I recall memories similar to that thing, then these memories overlay my perception such that I identify it as a perception of that type of thing. So some perceptions might stop at the first moment, or someone (certainly a pre-verbal child or sophisticated animal, but really, anyone) could potentially go through all three steps without having a specific name for the thing in question. An interesting twist is that one of the types of perception listed is perception of an absence: I expect to see something, don't see it, and so conclude that it isn't there. But yet we're supposed to interpret this as similarly non-verbal and immediate.

Unlike for Western thinkers like Locke, on the Nyaya account, color and sound are not "secondary qualities" that are essentially subjective. To successfully perceive a color is just like perceiving a shape or anything else: If you perceive a color differently than I do, one of us is just wrong, and we could look at what environmental or physiological factors led to one (or both) of us failing.

Buy the book . For an overview, read the Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy article on Epistemology in Classical Indian Philosophy .

Image by Chris Warr (aka Solomon Grundy).

item.title: Closereads: William James on Asceticism and Saints (Audio Part Two)

We bring up Dostoevsky's The Idiot and Nietzsche, who according to James had only contempt for saints (but we know better ).

Does the saint represent the feminine/maternal, while Nietzsche's warlike man is the masculine/paternal (such that we need both for a balanced society), or is the saint in contrast the Apollonian (the organized/lawlike/"name of the father") while the ubermensch is the Dionysian (the more primal, chaotic, feminine Other)? Does it matter?

Read along with us , starting on p. 361.

item.title: PEL Mid-Summer Nightcap 2024
item.description:
In this time of vacations and election anxiety, Mark, Wes, and Seth joined up on July 3 to talk about:

  • Whether it's legit to fundamentally worry (aloud, taking up podcast time) about the utility of the type of philosophy we're studying in a given week. In particular, what was the utility of the analytic approach in the Gettier/Goldman discussion ?

  • Dr. Drew's recent interview with Seth , where he (Seth) was put on the spot many times to address philosophical points he had not prepared for. (Wes and Mark also appeared prior on Drew's podcast.)

  • In a philosophical setting, if you're giving a historical account or otherwise using factual details, how many of these details can be wrong before you decide that the text is not philosophically worthwhile?

  • Seth's writing project about how non-representational communication (like art) might lessen the violence inherent in language.

  • Finally, our various concerns about this moment in American political history: our poor choice of candidates, the potential end of democracy, disorganization of the Democrats, Trump qua joke-teller, and how much mental energy we all spend on things like this that we have little to no control over.

item.title: Ep. 345: William James on Religious Experience (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
Continuing from part one on The Varieties of Religious Experience (1902). Does James' claim that science and culture shouldn't ignore the subjective point of view really mean that the religious objects that motivate people are real , and that each of us should be open to religious sentiments in others a nd require them of ourselves? James describes the sole focus on objectivity as comparable to just studying a menu when we really want to act actual food with our own mouths (our subjective life).

When people are subjectively reacting to an "unseen realm," are they in fact reacting to one and the same metaphysical facts (e.g. the actual existence of a God who can have various relations with us)? Or is the thing that we share a psychological fact about the unconscious? Does it make sense to consider that the unconscious of each of us may be connected to some shared metaphysical feature of the world (as in Jung's collective unconscious ), and is James committed to something like this? The view even seems to provide potential legitimacy to synchronicities like the effectiveness of rain dances (as discussed in our American Indian philosophy episode ).

Next Time: We're reading The Nyaya-Sutra: Selections with Early Commentaries , translated and edited by Matthew Dasti and Stephen Phillips in 2017, chapter one on "knowledge sources."
