item.title: Ep. 345: William James on Religious Experience (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
On The Varieties of Religious Experience (1902), focusing on lectures 1-3 and 20. What is religion and how should philosophers study it?

James describes a religion as a full-life reaction to the world and distinguishes it from philosophy by saying it must be serious (so Voltaire's "Who cares?" philosophy or anything too steeped in irony doesn't qualify) and must enthusiastically accept the universe (no Schopenhauerian pessimism or even the grudging acceptance he attributes to Marcus Aurelius). It must involve some kind of personal, emotional involvement and not just a set of beliefs, rituals, and practices. According to this view, many just practice religious second-hand as part of their social lives, but insofar as we feel the divine (whatever that means to us; it needn't involve a deity), we are getting at the experiences that gave rise to religion in the first place. James' task in this lecture series is to examine those "religious geniuses" who had such experiences to an extreme degree, and his scope includes mystical experiences, sainthood, conversion, the (minor) place of religious philosophy, and other topics.

James is of course known as a psychologist (see our eps. 179 and 180 ), and he's writing at the tail end of when introspective psychology was considered scientifically respectable (he had some issues with such psychologists himself despite his arguably being one of them). Most of this book is just lengthy quotes from writings or speeches by people reporting on their religious feelings and experiences, and James concludes that "the unseen" can be a real force in human psychology. Is he committed to the literal existence of unseen forces (God or ghosts or whatever), or just how ideas about these affect behavior and beliefs? Probably the former, but James' pragmatism makes this difficult to determine, since according to strict pragmatism, the existence of something just is its effects on people.

James is more definite in saying that mystical experiences, while often perceived as conveying definite information to the individual having them, contain "no specific intellectual content whatever." They do not provide evidence of religious claims that can be legitimately conveyed to others, and in fact they tend to just reinforce what someone already believes: A Christian will most likely interpret their experience as involving Jesus, while a Buddhist will report experience of the Void or the Buddha, etc. James describes specific theologies as "overbeliefs," not actually justified by these experiences. Moreover, James acknowledges that these theological and philosophical aspects are not in themselves sufficient to motivate acceptance of religion. This is not to say that religion isn't aided by words or images (certainly for religions to spread), but the religious attitude is at bottom emotional. It could be (for what he called the "once-born") an optimistic determination to ignore evil and interpret the world as a gift, or it could be (for the "twice-born") a proper recognition of the tragedy and evil in life (we're all going to die, after all) but yet a use of religion as an emotional recompense: For example, there is sin, but Christ died for my sins, and feeling his glory and forgiveness can make it on sum a positive experience, or there is earthly suffering, but I can feel my Buddha-nature and see beyond and thus transcend suffering. In talking about ascetics, James says that the religious could even purposely make the suffering worse through sacrifice or self-torture because doing so makes the recompense all the grander. These shifts between optimism and pessimism back to optimism certainly have to involve words and doctrines, but theodicy-type arguments that we should all look on the bright side will be just as powerless to convince as arguments about God's existence.

This emphasis on the emotional and subjective is not a dismissal of religion as merely irrational. James is very much a proponent of religion, and argues against scientistic views that would rule out the utility or even necessity of religious feelings and beliefs. James argues that religious enthusiasm ("sthetic feeling") is the unique antidote for nihilism in the face of our mortality and suffering.

Listen also to our early episodes on James' pragmatism and on his essay from a few years earlier than the current text, "The Will to Believe."

item.title: Ep. 344: Gettier and Goldman on Justified True Belief (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
On "What Is Justified Belief?" (1979) by Alvin Goldman, where he tries to come up with a "function" for justification: If a belief has such-and-such non-epistemic properties, then it counts as justified. This discussion continues from part one , where we discussed the Gettier problems that (in part) motivate Goldman's account.

What makes a property "epistemic" in this sense is not just that it has something to do with knowledge. "True" counts as a metaphysical property, while "feels certain of" is a psychological property. The epistemic ones are all normative, as in good or bad as these words apply to knowledge. So Goldman doesn't want us just to say that a belief is justified if it's probable or self-evident, as these latter terms just restate that there's something good knowledge-wise about the belief. Instead, just like an ethicist might want to try to define moral value in terms of non-moral properties (e.g. good = bringing maximum pleasure), he wants to define epistemic value in non-epistemic terms. It might be that (just as some philosophers claim about the moral case) that this simply isn't possible.

So the paper goes through and rejects many different possibilities for defining justification, and his solution is that a belief is justified if it is obtained using a reliable method, i.e. one that yields truth in most cases. Again, truth is not itself an epistemic term, but just a way of categorizing beliefs. This sounds weird, I know; aren't the true beliefs the good ones? Isn't "true" just a way of saying a belief is good? But not according to Goldman; a belief is true if it corresponds to some state of affairs in the world, and there's nothing inherently normative about that. Also, keep in mind, we're not saying that any belief is justified just because it's true; this was the whole thing Plato objected to (even a broken clock is right twice a day). We're saying that, for instance, if you carefully examine a physical object, and maybe confirm your observation with some other people, and again if it makes at a later time if it's possible to do so... All this is a pretty reliable way of determining at least obvious properties about that physical object (e.g. it's a good way of gaining true knowledge that a particular cat is on a mat at some particular time).

So justification and hence knowledge will be a matter of degree. For instance, testimony is a pretty good way of getting true knowledge, but because people lie, or we might misunderstand, it's not fool-proof.

Goldman's answer helps with some Gettier cases: If I look and see a red barn and think "this is a red barn," that's a pretty reliable way of getting knowledge, right? But if unbeknownst to me, I'm in a part of the country where there are many barn facades, so most "barns" I might look at in fact are not barns at all, then in that situation , simply looking at what appears to be a barn and commenting on it as such ends up not being a reliable way of getting knowledge, because most times I do that, I will be wrong. It doesn't matter that I don't know this; Goldman's account is "externalist," in that it has to do with the actual knowledge situation and not just what I as believer am aware of about that. This example also shows that a "reliable method" needs to be carefully defined; the method of simple observation is reliable only if the situation has not been manipulated specifically to deceive, just as testimony is reliable only when the testifier is not lying.

Goldman's account actually has two parts: I've given a "base clause" for a belief's being justified, but then there's a "recursive clause," which just says that there can be a chain of beliefs, each based on the previous one. If the original one was attained using a method that tends toward truth, then any other belief that is entailed by the first one or otherwise connected to it by legit means (means tending toward truth), then it also counts as justified. This seems obvious, but such is analytic philosophy.

Some processes that don't tend to lead to reliable beliefs include wishful thinking and psychic clairvoyance. As the Stanford article enumerates, subsequent philosophers argued a bit about these. What if we live in a world with a "helpful demon" that actually makes anything we wish for come true? In that case, we would be in a world where that sort of method was reliable. So we can either say, yes, in that world, such people can use that to ground knowledge, or we can say that we as theorists are referring to what is reliable in our world, so we'd say of that other world that those people still don't have knowledge (justification), even though the demon makes them lucky enough to be right.

Re. clairvoyance, what if someone claims to be clairvoyant, and their predictions invariably become true? Well, we could say yes, I guess if that's the case, that person and those relying on that person's utterances do have knowledge, or we could say that what gets defined as a "reliable process" depends on what people think in general is reliable, and we don't think clairvoyance is legitimate, or we don't understand how it could be, which comes to the same thing.

Next episode : We're reading William James' The Varieties of Religious Experience , concentrating on lectures 1-3 and 20. We used this online edition .

item.title: Ep. 344: Gettier and Goldman on Justified True Belief (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
On “Is Justified True Belief Knowledge?” (1963) by Edmund Gettier, “What Is Justified Belief?” (1979) by Alvin Goldman, and “The Inescapability of Gettier Problems” (1994) by Linda Zagzebski.

What is knowledge? A formulation going back to Plato distinguishes between opinion and knowledge. Even if one's opinion is true, it's not knowledge if it lacks justification. In his famous three-page paper, Gettier showed that even if a belief is true and justified, in some cases we still wouldn't consider it knowledge. Suppose you tell me that you have COVID, and I have no reason to think you would lie, but in fact you are lying (you don't think you have COVID). Unbeknownst to you, you actually do have COVID. According to Gettier, even though I believe you have COVID with good reason (you told me so, and you've been trustworthy in the past), and even though my belief is true (you do have it), my reason is disconnected from what actually makes it true, so it's not knowledge.

This led many philosophers to try to determine how to characterize justification to avoid such cases. Goldman says that a person's belief has to have been caused by a "reliable cognitive process." In Gettier cases, it's merely luck that makes the belief true, which is not in general a great way to establish reliable beliefs. (You can't set out to be lucky, using luck as a tool to gain knowledge.)

Zegzebski claims that as long as justification does not guarantee the truth of a belief (and it doesn't: even a belief that you have a very good reason to believe may in fact be wrong), then there's always a space where luck can turn a well-grounded belief false or turn one that should not count as knowledge true. Gettier problems are thus unavoidable, and that's OK.

Read the Gettier paper . Read Zagzebski's response to the literature on this .

Most of our discussion of the Goldman paper is in part two. We also read the Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy article on Reliabilist Epistemology , also written by Goldman, plus Bob Beddor (2021), which describes more of the responses from philosophers to Gettier and Goldman.

Image by Chris Warr (aka Solomon Grundy). Audio editing by Sonic Hustle .

item.title: Ep. 343: Plotinus the Neo-Platonist (Part Three for Supporters/Closereads Audio Part One)
item.description:
On "The Intelligence, The Ideas, and Being" from the Enneads (270 C.E.), about the various elements of Neo-Platonist cosmology: You've got The One, which is so awesome that it has literally no properties (so you can't even say it's awesome), then The Intelligence, which is the repository of the Forms (these first two together serve the same function as Aristotle's Unmoved Mover), then The Soul (the World Soul) that actually exists in time and creates things, then lots of little souls, individual Forms that are transmitted around via "the seminal reasons," and the grubby material world that nonetheless may have received enough Form to make us look up the chain of Being toward its divine elements.

Read along with us , starting on p. 46 (PDF p. 48).

Folks in the $10/month tier can experience this as video and will get additional coverage to this reading as it's released, along with all the other Closereads content. Some episodes behind that paywall are being released over time on our new Evergreen Podcasts public Closereads feed: see closereadsphilosophy.com .

item.title: Closereads: Levinas on Buber (Audio Part Four)
item.description:
Concluding "Martin Buber and the Theory of Knowledge," covering "Truth," "The Formal Nature of the Meeting," and "Some Objections," where we finally hear how Levinas differs from Buber.

Read along with us , starting on p. 68.

item.title: Ep. 343: Plotinus the Neo-Platonist (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
Continuing from part one with guest Chris Sunami, mostly discussing "The Good or The One," though we start off by completing "The Descent of the Soul" about why there is something rather than nothing, given that materiality is so undesirable compared to The One.

This is related to some other issues about how the Forms and matter interact. For Aristotle, each individual organism has an embedded Form, which is what makes it an entity at all, but for Plotinus, non-physical things like Forms are numerically identical if they don't have any properties. So the Form of humanity in Socrates and the one in me are different only because they have embedded themselves in those individuals, but considered separately, they are all not just identical but one and the same Form, which is why when we focus on what we have in common, ignoring all our material peculiarities, we can feel that we are all One.

Also, Plotinus says there are Forms not just for species like humanity but for individual, heritable characteristics, like the shape of one's nose. But we also know that a Form, as it is embodied, makes some compromises with matter, and so might in some cases result as deformed due to some biological accident in development. Is it always the case that variations in appearance (e.g. different skin tones, as our bodies produce melanin in response to different levels of sunlight) are hierarchical, i.e. one is the "real" instantiation of the Form, and one is a degraded version? Or are all material appearances of the Form compromised, just in different ways? How does this affect the issue of beauty, which Plotinus and Plato describe as us grasping the perfection of a true form through its partially realized material manifestation?

In discussing The One, Plotinus first tells us that we can't actually say anything about it, that it is better and beyond even Being. He then tells us that while we can't know it (which would require knowing the properties which it does not have), we can experience it mystically, so we talk about whether that kind of talk is useful to philosophers.

Next time: We're talking about the Gettier problem via "Is Justified True Belief Knowledge ?" and some other articles.

item.title: Ep. 343: Plotinus the Neo-Platonist (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
On selections from the Enneads (270 C.E.), as presented by Elmer O'Brien as the first four essays in The Essential Plotinus : "Beauty," "The Intelligence, Ideas and Being," "The Descent of the Soul," and "The Good or The One." Featuring Mark, Wes, Dylan, Seth, and guest Chris Sunami (editor of the PEL book ).

What is our metaphysical relationship to the good and the beautiful? 600 years after Plato, Plotinus has inherited Plato's views through the lens of Aristotle, so we get an interesting hybrid of the two that takes Plato's cosmological views in the Timeaus and Phaedo as straightforward, literal accounts.

Though Plotinus was a pre-Christian Roman, his vision of the material world as an imperfect, degraded copy of a pure, changeless, heavenly realm very much jibed with Christian thinking and so was influential on Middle Ages philosophy and was taken up wholly by Christian Neo-Platonists like Ficino a millennium later). According to this cosmology, God is The One, as conceived by Parmenides : Ultimate reality has to be entirely unified, which means we can't even attribute any properties to it (a property would be a part of something), not even of its having "being," so ultimately we can only talk about it in negative terms. But then there are intermediate divinities that we can know a lot about: The Intelligence (what Plato calls the Demiurge) is the source of all the Platonic Forms and is in effect the God that can actually create and do things, but He does this through The World-Soul, which in turn acts on (or through?) individual souls which provide the forms to matter (as Aristotle describes).

Just to schematize the four essays: #2 ("The Intelligence, Ideas and Being") lays out this hierarchy, while #4 ("The Good or The One") goes into detail about how even though the One can't be spoken of, we can still know it by realizing that we literally ARE it (along with everything else) through mystical experience (this part wasn't taken up so directly by Christianity, whose mysticism stresses that mortals are not themselves in any sense God; this is more like Eastern or Transcendentalist mysticism). #1 ("Beauty," which we really didn't get around to talking much about here) talks a la the Symposium about how our knowledge and feelings can move up the hierarchy from physical to spiritual things, while #3 ("The Descent of the Soul") speculates about why a soul would metaphysically debase itself by becoming associated with lowly matter, which Plotinus seems to hold in contempt.

A point that Plotinus takes from Aristotle is seeing The One as an unmoved mover (which we discussed re. Aristotle in #338 ). Since the One can't do anything, and is literally us, or rather the special, spiritual core of us, we have to see our relation to The One as one of magnetic attraction in an orbit; The One is the center of us, and so the rest of your personality, the part compromised by its association with matter, metaphorically orbits around it, ever attracted by its greatness but unable to fully coincide with it, lest we all cease existing as distinct individuals. Of course, when we die, we can actually achieve our goal, our orbit decaying, allowing us to crash and merge into the divine. (The crashing image is of course not Plotinus' words; Dylan adds the metaphor of a tuning fork here; we vibrate in time with the Forms... though again, The One cannot itself vibrate or otherwise move or do anything.)

Plotinus stresses Plato's Pythagorean heritage. The numbers themselves are these abstract, otherworldly entities that do not ever themselves change but which provide patterns for lower things to accord (vibrate) with. As Aristotle pointed out (see #335 ), a number as static can't itself get things moving, so this is why we need in Plotinus' system The Intelligence as a dynamic entity that can get things moving, somehow reflecting The One in a way we can't understand. Using a metaphor from Plato's Republic , Plotinus says The One emits rays of Goodness like the sun, which on the Greek conception was an everlasting source, left totally unchanged by this discharge, yet changing all that the rays hit, making them more like the source (i.e. the sun warms us, The One makes The Intelligence qua The Good).

Using another metaphor, Plotinus describes the latter as "the vestibule to The One." The lack of a non-metaphorical account of the relation between The One and The Intelligence is a pretty glaring hole in the system, and Plotinus doesn't make as much of an effort as Aristotle to try to explain how a fundamental reality (The One or The Unmoved Mover) can be dynamic enough to kick off motion in the world, to effect the creation of things, or even to be related to some other nearly-as-divine entity that can do such things. Parmenides himself was aware of this problem, and this is why he posited that we can look at metaphysics from "the way of truth" (i.e. there's only truly a singular One) vs. "the way of seeming" (how we are forced the the nature of thinking to theorize about the cosmos, which involves two forces that can thus provide fundamental dynamism). However, it doesn't appear that Plotinus thinks that The Intelligence is merely some illusion, but it's part of his divine furniture, embodying The Good and in so doing supplying all of the other Platonic Forms. This will be a fundamental problem of any kind of monism, whether Spinoza's or Vedic (i.e. Hindu): If there's ultimately only One, then why do so many things appear to us as distinct. (We just saw a different way that things could be One yet multiple in Zhuangzi ; they're not literally one but just interrelated and coming from the same ultimate source.)

Chris our guest compares this metaphysical problem to the Problem of Evil: Given the ultimate perfection of the universe, why does anything distinct exist at all, when the interaction of distinct entities is what then unavoidably results in collisions that don't in themselves look like evidence of a grand, designed pattern? To answer a question we had about Platonic forms: Are there Forms of gross things like mud? Well, no: these are not natural kinds, as later philosophers might put it. You could have a nicely Formed (ensouled!) molecule, but if a bunch of these beauties clump together in an arbitrary way, you might get just a heap (mud) and not a proper entity at all.

Plotinus' response to why this degradation from perfection to matter occurs is that something is not fully actualized until it springs out in material form, so it's part of the inherent nature of higher things (and ultimately The One) that they unfold, as sort of a gift to the universe, and that the good that comes out of this (the existence of the material world) is greater than the inevitable evils that come with embodiment. (For a more developed theodicy of this sort informed by Plotinus, see Leibniz .)

Buy the book or try this version online .

Image by Charles Valsechi . Audio editing by Tyler Hislop .

item.title: Closereads: Levinas on Buber (Audio Part Three)
item.description:
Continuing on "Martin Buber and the Theory of Knowledge," with two sections: "The Ontology of the Interval, or the 'Between'" and "Communication and Inclusion."

We've been talking about how Buber and Levinas are trying to get us out of a first-person, Cartesian point of view, and now we finally get to how meeting another person is supposed to be ontologically fundamental for us. Your "self" is fundamentally something in relation to other people, not just for Hegelian reasons about how you only know you're a person if other people treat you that way, but because we are fundamentally in dialogue with others, which unifies us with them even as it asserts them as an irreducible Other whose otherness needs to be respected. This is the only kind of union worth anything, according to Levinas (contra an Emersonian or Eastern idea that we are literally the same organism).

Read along with us , starting on p. 65.

item.title: Closereads: Levinas on Buber (Audio Part Two)
item.description:
Continuing on "Martin Buber and the Theory of Knowledge," with the "Experience and Meeting" section, whereby we try to make sense of the theory that the self is metaphysically a relation to other people. How does a model of philosophy based on the cogito (first person perception) necessarily objectify other people? How does speaking "to" someone provide a break from this intentional (objectifying) speaking "of" others? Does this relation to others actually require language? Is bringing in animals off-limits in talking about the phenomenology of consciousness?

Read along with us , starting on p. 63.

item.title: Ep. 342: Zhuangzi on Knowledge and Virtue (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
Continuing from part one , still with Theo Brooks. We talk more about the metaphysical boundaries between things, which could less pretentiously be redescribed as an issue about whether words have clear and consistent meanings. Importantly, is there really a difference between "good" and "bad"? And are any of the Courses (Daos, Ways) really clearly defined (and should they be?): Zhuangzi has been clear that to follow a strict recipe for action, which is how Confucianism for one is often portrayed by Daoists, is to impose something foreign on yourself, but Zhuangzi's use of Confucius as a character suggests that Confucianism properly interpreted is, like Daoism, a type of virtue ethics wherein the Utmost Person will have the wisdom to react flexibly to novel situations, not just chant and enact rigid dogma. The Dao (our Course of action) can and should be a zig-zag path.

This leads us to the distinction between the human and the Heavenly. The latter is nature, which is our true origin and should be the guide for our action, whereas the "human" (The Chinese word here is "ren") is the social customs that we've come up with, which often pull us away from what's natural. So what does this natural/Heavenly way of being entail, in contrast to following explicit ethical commands? It's not just "do what you feel" and certainly not "follow you whims," but involves "nurturing life." Part of life, though, is death, and Zhuangzi's emphasis on the interrelatedness of all things means that nurturing life in general doesn't mean that you get really hung up on preserving your own life or the life of a specific loved one. So coupled with this idea referred to in part one of this discussion that Zhuangzi advocates real, face-to-face encounters (like Buber !), is a Stoic acknowledgment that all in this material world is fleeting, and (like Marcus Aurelius in particular) we're part of a great natural system whose directives dwarf our puny, individualistic objections about right and wrong, fair and unfair. So does this lead the Daoist to quietism, or worse, to a lack of moral grounding?

Next time : We're reading the first four essays in The Essential Plotinus .

item.title: Ep. 342: Zhuangzi on Knowledge and Virtue (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
Mark, Seth, and Dylan are joined again by Theo Brooks to further explore this classic Daoist text, now covering books 1-6 (and parts of 17-19), which brings together the material covered for ep. 341 with what a couple of us previously discussed back in 2009 on ep. 12 .

We start with an extended discussion of the "happy fish" story, which comes at the end of book 17 and is about knowledge. How do I know your mind, and vice versa, and can either of us know a fish's mind? Zhuangzi (like Heidegger ) seems to say that skepticism about such things makes no sense; our position in the world presupposes that there are other subjectivities that we can know quite a bit about. Though someone might fool us sometimes about their mental state (not a fish, that has no capacity to deceive), our minds are largely part of the public world. We each have a unique perspective on this world, but we also have the ability to change our perspectives and so (maybe) understand others.

This positive statement about our ability to know, however, is undermined by Zhuangzi's Cratylus -like position whereby the things that our words purport to pick out are constantly changing, so we can't claim any firm, foundational knowledge about the things we experience. Zhuangzi thinks that philosophy of that sort is groundless and pretentious. In the text (Ch. 33, as Theo mentions), Zhuangzi makes fun of his interlocutor from the fish story, Huizi, by describing the latter's philosophy: "Hui Shi had many theories: his writings filled five carts. But his course was uneven and mottled, and his words were wide of the mark." The chapter describes Huizi as using these theories to make himself famous and inspire lots of useless debate.

These epistemic concerns lead us to then talk about ethics: Does Zhuangzi's Daoism require us to be compassionate to one another? Certainly we need not follow ethical rules a la Confucius, but Daoism does countenance having real encounters with one another, whereas the abstractions of ethical rules might actually blind us to others' concrete reality.

Daoist virtue thus has to do flexibly being able to move between perspectives so as to keep centered in reality. And what is "reality," given that things are constantly changing? It's a dynamic reality, where each thing has its own natural pattern of growth (telos, to use the Greek word), and the goal is to recognize that in others, and to retain the suppleness so that you can effectively grow yourself in whatever environment you find yourself. Ironically, the most effective way to become yourself (to grow in the most natural, healthy way) is to lose yourself (to stop trying to cultivate your growth along predetermined lines as Confucianism recommends).

Metaphysically, reality involves the interpenetration of opposites. The concept "horse" for instance, is only defined in terms of its contrast to non-horses, so in essence the horse is carrying around non-horseness with it. You can't think of a horse, and a horse itself cannot exist, in isolation from its opposite. More precisely, by indicating an individual being, you're breaking it out from a background, and so you're implicating (implicitly pointing out) all that cannot be pointed out, all that can't be articulated because it isn't an object at all.

Image by Chris Warr (aka Solomon Grundy). Audio editing by Tyler Hislop .

item.title: Closereads: Levinas on Buber (Audio Part One)
item.description:
We read the first pages of Emmanuel Levinas' 1958 article, "Martin Buber and the Theory of Knowledge."

In these initial sections, subtitled "The Problem of Truth" and "From the Object to Being," he's recounting how Heideggerian phenomenology argued that being (including our unarticulated awareness of being) is more fundamental than knowledge (a verbalized, objectifying attitude toward the world attributed to a tradition initiated by Descartes).

Read along with us , starting on p. 60 (PDF p. 66).

For more about Levinas, you can listen to PEL eps. 145 and 146 , plus ep. 71 on Buber .

Folks in the $10/month tier can experience this as video and will get additional coverage to this reading as it's released, along with all the other Closereads content.

item.title: Closereads: Zhuangzi, Ch. 19: "Fathoming Life" (Audio)
item.description:
How does Daoism compare in its worldview and advice to Stoicism and Existentialism? We read a couple of pages of a chapter referred to tangentially in Partially Examined Life ep. 341 .

Read along with us,starting on PDF p. 188.

item.title: Ep. 341: Guest Karyn Lai on Daoism in the Zhuangzi (Citizen Edition)
item.description:
This is the first of two discussions we're recording on the 4th century BCE Chinese text Zhuangzi. Mark, Dylan, Seth, and returning guest Theo Brooks are joined for this hour by UNSW Sydney professor Karyn Lai to discuss how to read this text, whether and how Daoists should engage with political matters, and what Zhuangzi's model of virtue is. This is our first foray back to this text since 2009's episode 12 , and we chose largely different chapters this time: 4, 5, and 19.

As with the Dao De Jing and Laozi, we don't really know if this was written by a single person (it probably wasn't), and don't know whether Zhuangzi was a real person, must less the author of this. Sometimes Zhuangzi appears as a character as if (like the Analects ) this were a collection of the master's teachings. Sometimes in the chapters we chose, the main character is Confucius himself, so we discuss whether these appearances are meant to show that Confucius was wrong, or that perhaps he did or should have accepted the superiority of Daoism over Confucianism.

Whereas Confucianism purportedly gives us a specific Dao or Way (or Course, in the 2020 translation by Brook Ziporyn that we all used at Karyn's suggestion) to order our lives, Daoism says that strictly following such a recipe constitutes overlaying something foreign on our constitutions. We're better off following our own personal destiny, being open to the environment and other people to determine what to do next. while retaining our personal integrity.

Ch. 4 connects the Zhuangzi to the past Chinese texts that purport to advise political leaders and advisors. Instead of directly providing advice, Zhuangzi includes anecdotes of people asking for advice (typically from Confucius). Really, the Daoist should just avoid political service (as Zhuangzi himself supposedly did ), but if you are going to advise a (probably very flawed) ruler, you need to be careful, because you'll want to be honest and flaunt your virtue, but this will probably get you executed. Confucius (the character) points out a disabled person who everyone is attracted to even though this person doesn't actually teach anything. This is one of many demonstrations of the virtue of wu wei , the idea of accomplishing without action, just by being authentically yourself, following the course of nature. Confucius refers to a practice of "fasting the mind," which is emptying ideology (like the Confucian Dao) out of your mind so you can better listen to nature and engage in wu wei.

Ch. 5 includes several stories about disabled people (mostly those who got a foot chopped off as punishment for some crime) who nonetheless are wiser than Confucius. We talk a bit about perspectivism and get a bit into Ch. 19 about people who become very graceful at mundane physical tasks.

Karyn is co-authoring the Chinese philosophy portion of the History of Philosophy Without Any Gaps podcast .

Buy the translation we read , or try this online version .

In ep. 342 (a regular, two-part discussion with Theo but without Karyn), we'll continue considering these chapters but will also add back ch. 2, 3, and 6 that were officially covered for our first treatment of the book in ep. 12. (Theo's audio will be higher fidelity for that discussion.)

item.title: Closereads: Peter Railton's "Moral Realism" (Audio Part Three)
item.description:
After some lengthy retrospection on what we've learned so far, we get into what metaphysical realism about values might look like. How can there be "moral facts" which are actually connected to our motivations?

Read along with us , starting on PDF p. 10.

item.title: Closereads: Peter Railton's "Moral Realism" (Audio Part Two)
item.description:
We discuss the fact-value distinction, both with regard to ethics but also epistemology, i.e. how the search for facts depends on what we're looking for.

Read along with us , starting on p. 6.

item.title: Ep. 340: Brian Ellis on the Implications of Essentialism (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
Concluding on The Philosophy of Nature: A Guide to the New Essentialism (2002) with guest Chris Heath. This continues from part one , but listen to ep. 339 first.

Are we OK with the idea that our natural laws must be the same in all possible worlds, i.e. the ones that have the same THINGS in it that our world does? This change ends up negating the entire program of 20th century logical construction (e.g. Carnap ), which maybe is not a great loss. How do Ellis' mind-independent fundamental objects in the world relate to higher level things, whether biological species or human nature or even things like colors?

Next time, we're talking about the Daoist philosopher Zhuangzi, previously covered in ep. 12 . We're using the Brook Ziporyn translation (2020), covering primarily the "inner chapters" (1-7).

item.title: Ep. 340: Brian Ellis on the Implications of Essentialism (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
Continuing on The Philosophy of Nature: A Guide to the New Essentialism (2002), now featuring Wes, Seth, Dylan (our resident physicist returns!), and guest Chris Heath.

Essentialism, as described in ep. 339 , is the metaphysical doctrine that there are objective natural kinds in the world, at least at the level of physics and chemistry. No "social construction" or anything like that goes into the fact that the the atoms of the various elements are irreducibly different. So what are the implications of this seemingly common sense observation for philosophy?

For one thing, to define what a thing is, we have to say what its dispositions are: What it IS to be a hydrogen atom, for instance, is to react in certain predictable ways with other atoms in various situations. Second, natural laws aren't metaphysically fundamental, but are just descriptions characterizing these behaviors and dispositions of things. Third, these laws of nature must be true in all possible worlds: They are metaphysically necessary, given that the natural-kind entities that they describe necessarily behave the way they do.

Most of the above was actually already covered in ep. 339, so we're just getting clearer on that so far in part one here. In the final part this discussion, we talk more widely about the scientific and philosophical implications of the theory.

item.title: Closereads: Peter Railton's "Moral Realism" (Audio Part One)
item.description:
We're reading a 1984 essay by Mark's U. of Michigan undergrad advisor, included among the most cited philosophy papers in some list that Wes found. Railton's goal is to give a naturalistic account of ethics (i.e. ethics within a framework of natural science) that both connects tightly to observed empirical facts and also makes moral facts real parts of our world, not merely reducible to non-moral facts about pleasure, social norms, or the like.

In this first part, Railton lays out what naturalism in ethics amounts to and begins to explain why past empiricists like Hume don't provide an account of morality that is adequately normative: Merely describing what people tend to shoot for doesn't explain why such a norm is binding on us.

Read along with us .

item.title: PEL 15th Anniversary and Book Release
item.description:
Mark, Wes, Seth, Dylan, and our guest book editor Chris Sunami reflect on a decade and a half doing this podcast and the making of our new book , which you should order exactly on its release date of Thursday, April 25, so we can all drive it up the bestseller list.

The book is a fine way to revisit some classic episodes in a fresh form, and brings together our various celebrity contacts, big-time philosopher author-guests, and treatments of canonically central and marginalized philosophers. Chris' editor voice is not subtle: He inserts himself as a post-hoc participant to move the dialogue between topics. There are also some supporting essays and lots of great graphics.

Do you remember the three rules for PEL discussion? Do we? Why don't we actually create transcripts for all our episodes? Can there be a PEL card game? What other ambitions do we have?

If you want to hear some perhaps purer retrospection, minus the book infomercial aspect, check out our 5-year and 10-year episodes of this sort.

item.title: Closereads: Descartes' "Passions of the Soul" (Audio Part Four)
item.description:
We're concluding this reading on mind-body interaction. What actually is the role of the gland the supposedly connects the two? Are emotions and desires actually possessed by the soul, or are they bodily processes that the mind can choose not to react to?

Read along with us , starting on article 46.

item.title: Ep. 339: Brian Ellis on the Metaphysics of Science (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
Continuing from part one on The Philosophy of Nature: A Guide to the New Essentialism (2002), still with guest Chris Heath.

We get further into the text, covering Ellis' argument for scientific realism (as opposed to scientists just constructing models as a shorthand for displaying their data without actual metaphysical commitments), his strict criteria for a natural kind, whether water really has to be without admixture to be counted as water, so-called variable natural kinds (which have essential properties even though they're not all identical like hydrogen atoms), whether Ellis' picture is actually a descendent of Aristotle, how the world is fundamentally dynamic (with natural kinds having their own internal movement, which is undeniably Aristotelian), the ontology of facts (like Wittgenstein !), predicates vs. properties (is "being a horse" a property?), and how dispositions are not reducible to structure. We'll get more into that last issue in our next episode when we cover the rest of the book, which further explores dispositions, natural laws, and philosophical implications of Ellis' essentialism.

item.title: Ep. 339: Brian Ellis on the Metaphysics of Science (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
On The Philosophy of Nature: A Guide to the New Essentialism (2002), featuring Mark, Wes, Seth, and guest Chris Heath. What kind of metaphysics underlies chemistry and physics? Ellis says that mainstream philosophy of science is still under the spell of Descartes, Newton, and their contemporaries, especially Hume.

According to this view, the fundamental metaphysical entities are just passive entities with shape, which are then manipulated by forces. Laws of nature, according to Hume, are just brute, inexplicable correlations between events. Ellis wants to argue, following Aristotle, that the basic metaphysical entities are dynamic. They have inherent dispositions to behave in certain ways, and those dispositions and other essential properties are what make those things what they are. A nominalist about electrons, for instance, might say that we talk about electrons just as a shorthand of modeling a lot of complex observational data. Ellis says on the contrary that electrons are real entities, defined by their charge and other behaviors. Anything that did not behave that way would not be an electron. These basic entities and processes are real, they act the way they do necessarily, and scientific laws are just a way we describe their activity. This means that scientific laws, too, are necessary: There is no possible world in which they could work differently than they do, unless there were different fundamental entities and processes.

One key implication of this is that there are natural kinds: groupings of things that are given by the things themselves, not just about our semi-arbitrary customary ways of grouping them. For instance, the chemical elements are absolutely, objectively distinct from each other and precisely defined via their atomic numbers. Per our Putnam episode , water is essentially H2O, so if some other world had a different substance served the identical functional role that water has here, and had the appearance of water, so that visitors from our world to that world mistook it for water, yet that substance had a different molecular makeup, then that would not be water. Whereas Plato and Aristotle thought that essences are something we intuitively grasp when we understand what water (or whatever) is, Ellis (and Putnam and Kripke) see essences as something science has to discover, i.e. as a posteriori.

This doesn't mean that all of our concepts represent natural kinds. Ellis says that while there are many predicates, only some of them represent properties, which are real things in the world. So you might think that being fragile is obviously a property that fragile things have, but for Ellis, this is a concept covering numerous different structural features that could cause something to easily break. So fragility is not a property at all, according to Ellis' technical use of the word "property."

You also might think that an animal would have an essence, i.e. its DNA. While an individual has such an essence, a species does not, as members of a species will have differences in their DNA, so a species is not defined precisely enough to be a a natural kind. As Darwin theorized, there is no sharp line between species, as small variations are introduced throughout a species' history until a species has gradually morphed into something else.

Of course it's still useful for us to refer to particular species or properties like fragility, but these concepts really are grouped according to human needs, whereas the truly natural kinds are independent of human minds and needs. This is enough to ground an metaphysical objectivity: It is not the case according to Ellis that humans synthesize our worlds including all of our scientific models. If we're doing science correctly, we're reading these essential properties off of the world, not imposing them on it.

Buy the book or check out this online version .

Image by Charles Valsechi . Audio editing by Tyler Hislop .

item.title: Ep. 338: Aristotle on Potential vs. Actual and the Unmoved Mover (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
To conclude our discussion of Aristotle's Metaphysics , we finish discussing potency by talking about our potential to learn, i.e. the Meno problem: How can we learn something (have the potential to know it) unless we already in some sense know it? Aristotle dismisses this as "sophistical": we have the potential to kick off the learning process and then actually learn through habituating to thing we're trying to learn (which itself pre-exists our attempt to learn it, e.g. the art of flute playing exists before I try to learn it).

We then finish up "priority in substantiality"; which is metaphysically primary, the chicken or the egg? It's the chicken, because it has the completed form.

Moving on to book 12, we talk about the whole universe and eternal entities as also being primary being, not just animals and plants. What makes the universe itself strive toward its own completion? Aristotle says that the universe is actively trying to be like the unmoved mover, which is a concept of God as pure thought.

Start with part one , or better yet, ep. 335 .

Next episode : We're reading Brian Ellis' The Philosophy of Nature: A Guide to the New Essentialism .

item.title: Ep. 338: Aristotle on Potential vs. Actual and the Unmoved Mover (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
For our fourth and final discussion of Aristotle's Metaphysics , Mark, Wes, and Dylan read portions of books 9 (Theta) and 12 (Lambda). The first of these covered Aristotle's notion of energeia, sometimes translated as actuality, but by our translator Joe Sachs as "being-at-work." An example of this is eudaimonia, the word we've discussed as the goal of ancient Greek ethics: "flourishing" or "happiness." Relatedly, the obscure English word "entelechy" was Aristotle's original word that (entelechia) that combines the very relevant notion of telos (an end, i.e. purpose) with the Greek word for persistence (endelechia), which Sachs translates as "being-at-work-staying-the-same." This is the final piece in Aristotle's characterization of what being amounts to: the primary beings (individual plants and animals) doing the things characteristic of what kind of beings they are.

The contrast is to mere potency or potential (the Greek is "dunamis"; you can look at this wiki page to get all these Greek words straight). One question we start with is whether the notion of potency is actually explanatory in any way: Why does an acorn grown into an oak tree? "Because it has the potential (or we could say "the power") to do so." This type of answer seems to give us no specific information.

These concepts are supposed to enable us to better talk about causality and change. For causality to occur, the cause needs to have the potential to cause, and the effected object needs to have the potentiality to be effected in that way. Something self-moving (a plant or animal) has its own potential to grow into its next form, so long as nothing is preventing it from doing so (e.g. a lack of nutrition).

Book 12 is about the famous cosmological argument by which Aristotle proves the existence of God by saying that there has to be something that kicked off the whole chain of causation. However, this can't itself be something that moves, i.e. something that has any potency at all; God must be fully actual all the time, and so really be standing outside the chain of efficient causes (outside time?). Instead, this fundamental type of causality that makes all other causality possible is more like that of a magnet, where all things are "oriented" or "revolve around" this Unmoved Mover, which Aristotle peculiarly thinks must be "thought thinking itself." This is essentially the same as the Form of the Good for Plato, though it's supposed to be somehow more dynamic (which seems to contradict the idea that it doesn't move). All things in their growth and development are essentially striving toward the Good: toward their own fullness and completion. Is this really a better explanation for how movement gets kicked off in the universe than the supposedly static explanations provided by Plato (the Forms) or other ancient cosmologists (e.g. the four elements themselves inherently contain movement), as we discussed in episode 335 as the first topic explored in this book?

In any case, focusing on God is supposed to complete Aristotle's consideration of how to characterize metaphysics: the nature of Being, since God (if there is one) would of course be primary among beings metaphysically, even if it's the individual plants and animals he's been calling primary being, because it's their being that enables us to understand the rest of being.

Image by Sterling Bartlett . Audio editing by Tyler Hislop .

item.title: Ep. 337: Aristotle on Primary Being (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
Continuing from part one on Aristotle's Metaphysics , Book 7 (Zeta), on essences and what sorts of things have them.

Contrasting with Plato, Aristotle believes that some changing, visible things have forms. How do they get them? Well, they're received from some previous thing that has a comparable form, e.g. a child from its parents, or perhaps a form could come from a creator's mind.

Thanks for listening to this most essential episode (in that it's about essences, a topic that is probably optional at best).

item.title: Ep. 337: Aristotle on Primary Being (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
Continuing for our third session on Aristotle's Metaphysics , now covering Book 7 (Zeta). Start your journey with ep. 335 . We're back to the full four hosts for this discussion.

In our last episode , we explained Aristotle's position about how to talk about being (what it is for something to exist), which, since it doesn't actually contrast with anything (not even nothingness, which is just defined as a different being than you were looking for), seems like it should be indescribable. But we learned that Aristotle thought that some instances of being are what being is really all about (things), while others (properties, relations, absences, etc.) are only being because they're related to the things in the first category.

We also learned that being means being something specific, something defined. So how can we describe these primary beings? What distinguishes an individual one of these? What about it makes it primary and determines what exactly it is? Aristotle considers various possibilities: Is it the substratum, i.e. whatever it is that has the various properties? For Aristotle, this would be matter: a bronze statue is basically a lump of bronze that then has the form of a statue, so you might think the matter is primary, and the form is just a set of attributes, along with the location of the statue, its color, its weight, etc. Aristotle rejects this theory.

Could it be the form in the sense that Plato described it? As we discussed , Aristotle doesn't understand how an individual thing could be related to its form if forms are external to the things. (For Plato, Forms were primary being, physical objects only secondarily so.) The answer ends up being "substantial forms": the essence of the statue is its form as it is instantiated in that particular statue. But really, statues don't have forms, because the form is also supposed to have causal power. In the case of plants and animals, the form of the entity makes it what it is, determines how it will change and grow, and accounts for its identity over time.

For a person, the substantial form, the person's essence, is that person's humanity: the form of rational animal. So interestingly, even though Socrates' form can be described as "rational animal," and Wes' form can also be described in this same way, they are clearly different people. The form as described doesn't distinguish one person from another, but each person has a numerically unique substantial form: one rational animal here, another there, another for each of us.

Aristotle also has to explain why this personal substantial form is metaphysically basic. It seems like a human has many parts: bones, blood, viscera, etc. Why aren't these parts more basic? Or the definition itself, "rational animal"; doesn't that have two parts, rational and animal? Why aren't those basic?

Aristotle says that those parts really only make sense in light of the whole. Creation of the whole is the point when that individual thing comes into existence. The component matter that makes us up and the component concepts that make up the definition of our form are not primary, with their compounds being secondary. Instead, the individual animal or plant is primary being, whose essence is described by its definition. A person is not just an amalgam of organs, but instead a hand, for instance, is defined by the purpose it serves in the larger system that is the person.

Image by Chris Warr (aka Solomon Grundy). Audio editing by Tyler Hislop .

This discussion continues with part two .

Continuing on "Two Concepts of Liberty" (1969), we finish up the negative conception ("freedom from") and give Berlin's strange account of positive freedom ("freedom to"), which involves an identification of some part of you (e.g. for Plato, your rationality), the obeying of which makes you free, even if what you "want" goes against this.

item.title: Ep. 336: Aristotle on Being and Non-Contradiction (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
Continuing from part one on Book 4 (Gamma) of the Metaphysics . We discuss the relation between the logical principle that no statement or belief can legitimately contradict itself and the metaphysical principle that something can't both be and not be at the same time and in the same respect.

Aristotle argues against the relativists of his day, such as Protagoras whose famous doctrine is "man is the measure of all things." Aristotle interprets this as saying that whatever seems true to someone is in fact true. Because people disagree, this belief implies a denial of the law of non-contradiction. I not only believe that I'm right, but I believe that your opposing view is wrong, and you believe likewise, so if we're both in fact right, then you're both right and wrong, speaking truly and falsely in the very same statement. But is this a charitable take on relativism?

Next time we'll be reading Book 7.

item.title: Ep. 336: Aristotle on Being and Non-Contradiction (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
On Aristotle’s Metaphysics , book 4 (aka Gamma) (ca. 340 BCE), featuring Mark, Wes, and Dylan. Our treatment of this book starts with the previous episode .

What does studying “being” entail? When we study a particular kind of thing, e.g. an animal species, we say things about it that distinguish it from other animals, and animals from other types of things. But since everything counts as “being,” then it’s hard to see what we could possibly say about what it is for something to be.

Aristotle’s solution is to say that to be is to be a distinct individual of a certain type. This contrasts with the view of reality as flux (attributed to Cratylus , following Heraclitus) which says being is just a constantly shifting mass, and that when we name things, we’re erroneously pointing at some part of this mass and pretending that it’s stable. If something is a distinct individual, then we can state true facts about it, or alternatively misdescribe it, i.e. utter falsehoods. So even though you might have thought the principle of non-contradiction was a purely logical notion about propositions (a proposition can’t be both true and false at the same time), this logical point is derived from a metaphysical point: It’s not possible for the same thing to both belong and not belong to the same thing, at the same time and in the same respect. Some individual both be a boat and not a boat, though conceivably something (some wood and nails) could become a boat, or something could be a boat in some respects but not in others (a model boat).

Aristotle says that we can’t prove the principle of non-contradiction, because any proof would make use of that principle, and so be circular. There must be some place that inquiry stops. However, he’s comfortable showing that the alternative views have absurd consequences, so this goes some way to providing an indirect proof.

So if something is (is real), it’s a distinct individual, and so subject to the principle of non-contradiction, but is everything a distinct individual? Not exactly: Everything must be either be an individual, unified substance (Aristotle calls this primary being) or related to (dependent on) a substance, like an attribute, relation, an idea about the relation, etc. So everything real partakes of being, but some things have more being than others, or rather they are paradigm cases of being or merely derived cases. Even an absence can be a being, because (per Plato’s Sophist ), an absence of one thing that you were expecting means the presence of something else.

Image by Charles Valsechi . Audio editing by Tyler Hislop .

item.title: Ep. 335: Aristotle on Fundamental Explanations (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
Continuing from part one on Aristotle’s Metaphysics , book 1. We get seriously into Aristotle’s four types of causation and how previous philosophers in leaving out one or most of these made a mistake. This includes a critique of Platonic forms, which as eternal, unchanging patterns can’t actually explain why change occurs in the world.

Parmenides famously only thought there was one fundamental, unchanging substance, but when talking about the experienced world, he expanded this to saying we need to talk about light and dark. So are these material substances (like fire and air), or are they forces? Either way, for Aristotle, their presence can’t adequately explain “being-at-work” in the world: the fact that things don’t just exist, and don’t just move randomly, but move in purposeful, often predictable ways.

As a third part of this, Mark and Wes have recorded a more detailed treatment of Aristotle’s arguments in this book against Platonic forms. This discussion is the first of (we think) four that we’ll be having about this book. For next episode, we’re reading book 4 (Gamma).

If you enjoy this episode, try our past episodes on Heraclitus , Aristotle’s Categories , Parmenides , and Plato’s dialogue The Parmenides .

item.title: Ep. 335: Aristotle on Fundamental Explanations (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
On Aristotle’s Metaphysics , book 1 (aka Alpha) (ca. 340 BCE). What constitutes a basic explanation of the universe? Featuring Mark, Wes, Dylan, and Seth.

Aristotle famously give us four types of causation; the Greek word is “aitia,” which is perhaps better translated as “explanation,” and in this book, Aristotle (or whoever put this book together based on Aristotle’s teachings) considers the work of past philosophers to see if the types of explanations they give are sufficient.

For instance, Thales said that everything is fundamentally made of water, and other Pre-Socratics likewise argued that there is some one (or two or three) fundamental material types of stuff. But these explanations, says Aristotle, can’t explain why change occurs. He similarly criticizes the Pythagoreans who say that numbers are somehow the fundamental constituents of the world. Since numbers are static, how can they explain how things in the world get moving? This is why other philosophers such as Empedocles introduced two warring forces as the fundamental explanation of the world, such as love and strife. This too is still not a complete account of the “why” of things, for Aristotle; we’re going to need all four of his type of explanation: not just the material causes (the fundamental matter that makes things up) and the efficient cause (what sets something moving), but also a formal cause (what makes something have the pattern it has; this is where Plato’s forms will come in, and Aristotle’s revisions of that doctrine) and final cause (the purpose for which something comes into being; also relevant to the form, which is not just a matter of the structure of something, but what it’s internally trying to become, such as an acorn “trying” to become a tree, and an eye being designed to effectively see).

We actually spend most of our time in this first half talking about not metaphysics but epistemology: What kind of knowledge of something do we consider most comprehensive and wise? Following Plato, Aristotle criticizes people for merely having techne, which is experiential knowledge that allows them to work with some material, such as knowing how best to raise horses or build boats through having simply done a lot of this and learned practical techniques. As good an artisan as someone with this kind of knowledge might be, Aristotle claims that we regard a greater understanding than this as including the theoretical underpinnings of these practical endeavors:

We officially read the Joe Sachs translation (1999). Many of us also read the relevant portions of Routledge Philosophy GuideBook to Aristotle and the Metaphysics by Vasilis Politis (2004).

Image by Genevieve Arnold.

item.title: Ep. 334: Gabriel Marcel's Christian Existentialism (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
Continuing from part one on "On the Ontological Mystery" (1933), we talk more about problems (the character of whose solution is pre-defined) vs. mysteries (the dense conundrums of experience like "How free is my will?" and "How is real intimacy possible?"). Re. the problem of evil: A theodicy like Leibniz's treats this as a puzzle to be solved in terms of the logically possible will of God (allowing evil to optimize overall good). But for Marcel, this approach doesn't take evil seriously enough: Once evil affects you directly, you feel its presence in a deep way, and this can't merely be banished by abstract argumentation. This is the characteristic of mystery: We are not mere observers, but are directly involved, and this complicates the inquiry.

Instead of trying to unravel and solve mysteries, we just cope with them, and for Marcel, we do this through recollection, which is a meditative way of pulling oneself out of the circumstance we were formerly in the midst of so as to be able to examine it. He sees this as very different from the jarring character of abstraction.

As another example, what is love? To be a Freudian or other type of analyst who reduces love to libido, to survival mechanism, or anything like that, is to falsify what love as experience is.

What makes Marcel an existentialist? Like Kierkegaard, he talks about how despair and the recognition of absurdity can give rise to a leap to hope and faith. Unlike Sartre , there's good reason for us to take this leap; Marcel's existentialism doesn't mean that the movement away from nihilism is entirely unmotivated, or free in a vertiginous sense. If you think carefully about your life, a key datum is "you are not your own" (a quote from the Apostle Paul), and once you realize this deeply, you won't be tempted to kill yourself or otherwise fall into despair.

We also talk about Being (how much is Marcel just parroting Heidegger?), pride, creativity, faith (does Marcel help us understand Kierkegaard?), being present to another person (what are ways that therapists, for instance, might or might not meet Marcel's requirements?), and how Christianity is actually involved with all of this.

Next Episode : We're starting in on Aristotle's Metaphysics, and will follow St. John's College reading list to do this over three episodes, the first of which will be on Book I (Α): 1–7 (980a21–988b22) and II (α): (993a30–995a20). We're all reading the Joe Sachs translation .

item.title: Ep. 334: Gabriel Marcel's Christian Existentialism (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
Discussing "On the Ontological Mystery" (1933) about our need for meaning, featuring Mark, Wes, Seth, and Dylan. Against the emphasis in our lives on our functions (our jobs and duties) and our technological approach to problems that stresses practical solutions, Marcel asserts that we all have an "ontological need," which is a need for some content in our lives that is not merely accidental and contingent.

Marcel distinguishes "problems" that we've broken down into elements that can be analyzed and solved technologically from "mysteries" that are the problems in our lives that have not been falsified through analysis. These are more fundamental, "meta-problematical," and required as an underlying ground for the more technical approach.

These mysteries include all the perennial philosophical problems, including what the value of life is, the mind-body relation, the problem of evil, true love, and more. For example, what is hope? Marcel says that hope is an assertion that "there is at the heart of being, beyond all data, beyond all inventories and all calculations, a mysterious principle which is in connivance with me, which cannot but will that which I will, if what I will deserves to be willed and is, in fact, willed by the whole of my being" (p. 28). So if your loved one is gravely ill, you might hope (have faith) that they will be OK, despite the data. We have a fundamental need for feelings of this sort, and if we insist on being "reasonable" in such a circumstance and merely looking objectively at the likelihood of a positive outcome, we're missing out on something, being less than human.

The technical point of view is very valuable, but we need to understand that it's not our originary position as human beings, but an abstraction that we engage in for particular purposes. This originary position is not merely a primitive state that the scientific worldview has overcome, but is fundamental such that we can't even think scientifically if we weren't also underlyingly in this less articulated position.

Though Marcel is Christian, Christianity comes up explicitly only in a small way in this essay. For instance, he places great importance to the idea of "presence," giving the example that some people that you talk to really are present to you: It's not just that they're listening carefully or willing to help. Someone can do those latter things and yet still not be present to you, not really available, not making a human connection. Marcel then uses this idea of presence to talk about our relation to the dead: Having a dead loved one continue to be an active force in your life is not just about preserving a static memory of them, like a photograph. The fundamental notion of "Being With" is possible not just between people but with the dead. Clearly Marcel wants to extend this to be able to admit that God is simply "present" to a faithful believer, but he doesn't actually use that example in the text.

Buy the book or read it online . It's the first essay in a collection that includes (in the second essay) a specific critique of Sartre, so that makes it clear how Marcel's existentialism is not Sartre's.

Image by Chris Warr (aka Solomon Grundy). Audio editing by Tyler Hislop .

item.title: Closereads: Al-Kindi on Dispelling Sorrows (Audio Part One)

We're reading a 9th century Arabic philosopher (from what's now Iraq), in fact the "father of Arab philosophy," Yaqub ibn Ishaq Al-Kindi, writing about how we can immunize ourselves to the sorrows of life through some means akin to Stoicism, which Al-Kindi as scholar of the Greeks new all about.

Read along with us .

item.title: Closereads: Hegel on Jesus and Kant (Audio Part Five + Reflections on Recent PEL Episodes)
item.description:
We conclude our reading of "The Spirit of Christianity and Its Fate," ch. 2: "The Moral Teaching of Jesus: The Sermon on the Mount Contrasted with the Mosaic Law and with Kant’s Ethics," discussing wealth, "judge not yet you be judged," and the final section of The Sermon on the Mount, which includes law-like pronouncements that seem to contradict Hegel's interpretation of Jesus as wanting us to transcend law (Kantian ethics) through love.

We're sharing this episode among the full Citizenry even though it's part five in a series because a) you won't need to hear the rest of the series to understand it, and b) we use the end of our time here to connect this reading to our recent Kierkegaard Fear and Trembling and forthcoming Marcel PEL episodes. Is love the kind of positively individualistic attitude that Kierkegaard has in mind when he says that faith transcends the ethical? Marcel puts this in terms of presence: A person (or God?) can be present before us in an undeniable way, and this affects us in a way different than the mediated relations to people that ethics provides.

Read Hegel along with us , starting PDF p. 240 (text p. 222). We also read the Sermon from Matthew ch. 5 in the New American Standard Bible , starting on PDF p. 1323.

item.title: Ep. 333: Kierkegaard’s “Fear and Trembling” on Faith (Part Two for Supporters)
item.description:
Continuing from part one on Kierkegaard’s perhaps most famous book, how focusing largely on the section called “Problem One: Is There a Teleological Suspension of the Ethical?”

Kierkegaard (writing as Johannes de Silentio) describes this “unmediated” access to God that constitutes faith. It’s not obeying moral law (which would be a mediator), which characterizes tragic heroes who also kill their kids, such as Agamemnon in the Iliad , who sacrifices one moral rule (don’t kill your kid) for a greater, but still public moral rule (do what provides greater good for society).

Abraham’s act of faith, by contrast, suspends all ethical considerations in favor of a private end (telos): one that is just between him and God. One could explain what happened as a “trial,” and perhaps even describe the duty to obey God as an ethical one, just as easily explainable to others as any other ethical dilemma (so if you were faced with this command, you’d do the same). Kierkegaard thinks this act of translating faith to something publicly explainable falsifies it. The moment of faith (on this account) is fundamentally singular, individual, and paradoxical.

One possible interpretation here is a Nietzschean, pluralistic virtue ethics, according to which there are various incommensurable ways of being virtuous. Being ethical in the traditional sense is one way of being good, and being faithful is another way, and the two ways might conflict (though in practice they rarely do).

Next episode: We decided not to do a second episode on the second half of this book. Instead, next time we’re covering a 1993 paper “The Ontological Mystery,” by the French, Christian existentialist Gabriel Marcel, who among other topics covers hope and “creative fidelity,” which is how he describes faith.

item.title: Ep. 333: Kierkegaard’s “Fear and Trembling” on Faith (Part One for Supporters)
item.description:
Ending our treatment of Soren Kierkegaard, we consider the religious stage of personal development through consideration of this 1843 text analyzing the Biblical story of Abraham faithfully following God’s directive to sacrifice his long-promised, much-cherished son Isaac. Can we observers possibly understand that kind of faith?

This text was released close on the heels of Either/Or , and we were interested in reading it as a third book of that, showing how the religious stage advances on the ethical which had previously advanced on the aesthetic. In moving to the ethical stage, an individual comes to define himself not just in terms of his private standards (his perceptions of beauty) but in social, i.e. universal terms. Any lapse from the universal is from the ethical standpoint seen as sin. But in the case of Abraham, his call to this horrific act (which he didn’t end up having to go through with, but that’s beside the point) was entirely private. It could not be “justified” insofar as justification refers to publicly available norms. If he was tempted to ignore God’s call, that would not be a lapse into private desire, i.e. sin (though of course he did personally love his son), but it would be a “lapse” into the ethical, into recognition of the normal ethical law that you don’t kill the innocent, don’t betray your duty to your child, etc. So Kierkegaard (or rather his avatar for this book, Johannes de Silentio) asks whether the ethical can be suspended due to a justification that is purely private? Where the individual for the ethical person was superseded by the universal, can this again be superseded by the individual in the act of faith?

This makes it sound like the religious stage is a synthesis of the previous stage. We get back some of the passion and individuality back from the aesthetic stage. However, K’s account of the ethical stage was already pretty complete. It was not about effacing your individuality in favor of the faceless universal, but about defining yourself as an authentic individual within a social context: We can only be individuals in the context of real relationships with others, and real relationships are different than merely (a la Kant) imagining that your actions are guided by universal laws; that’s more like acting in parallel with other people than actually relating to them.

Fear and Trembling complicates this issue because Silentio is a character who claims not to understand faith. Perhaps it cannot be understood, because it’s positively singular, so Abraham’s faith is sui generis. Moreover, there aren’t a lot of other examples of faith in the book, so while we (with Silentio) are clearly supposed to find Abraham to be “great,” impressive, an inspiration, it’s unclear whether or how we’re supposed to try to emulate Abraham and live the religious life. Our ethical reading in Either/O r was full of very direct advice, but this is just a description of faith as a phenomenon that Kierkegaard is arguing is much stranger than is suspected by his the bourgeois Protestants of his time who think that faith is just a simple matter of assenting to church doctrine.

Silentio says he does understand (and is presumably recommending to us as an attitude) the “knight of resignation” who has given up trying to control things. Being ethical involved taking up projects (the self being a central project), but how do you stay invested enough in projects such that they’re meaningful while not worrying about them. How do we not worry about our own deaths? Is the “posterity through the social” that the ethical promised enough for us? Being resigned to the possibility (or inevitability?) of misfortune is resignation: what Nietzsche called the love of fate (amour fati). Understanding this attitude is a step toward understanding faith, which not pessimistic resignation, but unwavering optimism that either everything is going to be all right. Abraham was confident that somehow he would get the lineage owed to him, and sure enough, his son was fine, but again, this outcome is not the point. He would have been laudably faithful even if God had ordered him to go ahead with the sacrifice, because ultimately, faith is about believing that God makes everything happen according to a wise plan, and that plan is always being fulfilled even if it makes no sense to Abraham or to us observing the situation.

Is this picture of faith something that you can understand or sympathize with? If not, is that just because there is something wrong with it, or merely because you lack faith (as Silentio claims he lacks it)? Since the “justification” for faith is entirely individual, Kierkegaard seems to have presented us with an unbridgeable epistemic gap. We cannot sympathize with the person of faith; we cannot see that person’s “reasons” for faith. Perhaps (per Kierkegaard’s reputation as proto-existentialist) there is no justification that can be cited for having faith, and a mere, unmotivated leap by the individual is required. But is faith something that each of us can just will? Silentio’s attitude (that he’s in awe of faith of this extreme sort but can’t get his head around it) suggests that we can’t, but the point is likely to leave the question to each reader.

Buy the Hong translation of the text that we used or you can try this other translation online .

Listen to our earlier discussion that touched on this book (though moreso The Sickness Unto Death , another religious text written several years later).

Image by Corey Mohler of Existential Comics .

item.title: PEL Winter Nightcap (Concluding 2023)
item.description:
Mark, Wes, Seth, and Dylan set ourselves as part of our ongoing Kierkegaard reading to re-listen to our 2010 episode 29 on The Sickness Unto Death . This leads us to our personal histories regarding faith and how the idea of faith intersects with our philosophy studies.

Does a thinker like Kierkegaard defy treatment via our format? Given that we cover typically one short work (whether essay or the beginning of a book) by an author, even with repeated revisits, do we ever get anything like a global picture of the thinker?

This year has tried more to take on that problem, with runs on not only Kierkegaard, but language, Chinese philosophy, German Romanticism, and we started off with Moore/Wittgenstein. We conclude by thinking about what sorts of runs we want to do next year. (OK, actually we conclude by talking about our health problems, but you can ignore that.)
